shlokas.name: Shloka 1
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
मय्यासक्तमनाः पार्थ योगं युञ्जन्मदाश्रयः ।
असंशयं समग्रं मां यथा ज्ञास्यसि तच्छृणु ॥
shlokas.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca mayy āsakta-manāḥ pārtha yogaṁ yuñjan mad-āśrayaḥ asaṁśayaṁ samagraṁ māṁ yathā jñāsyasi tac chṛṇu
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks the beginning of Chapter 7, where Krishna introduces the concept of divine knowledge and realization. He emphasizes the importance of devotion and practice of yoga with complete focus on Him. Krishna promises Arjuna that by following this path, he will gain complete and doubtless knowledge of the Supreme Being. This verse sets the stage for the revelation of Krishna's divine nature and the path to understanding it fully.
shlokas.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: O Partha (Arjuna), now hear how you shall know Me fully without any doubt, with your mind attached to Me, taking refuge in Me, and practicing yoga.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of focused dedication in our spiritual journey. In our daily lives, we can apply this by setting aside time for meditation or prayer, focusing our minds on a higher purpose, and seeking guidance from spiritual teachings. It encourages us to approach our goals with unwavering commitment and to seek knowledge with an open and devoted mind. This approach can help in overcoming doubts, achieving clarity in decision-making, and finding a sense of purpose and direction in life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 2
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ज्ञानं तेऽहं सविज्ञानमिदं वक्ष्याम्यशेषतः।
यज्ज्ञात्वा नेह भूयोऽन्यज्ज्ञातव्यमवशिष्यते॥
shlokas.transliteration: jñānaṁ te'haṁ sa-vijñānam idaṁ vakṣyāmy aśeṣataḥ yaj jñātvā neha bhūyo'nyaj jñātavyam avaśiṣyate
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces Krishna's promise to impart complete knowledge to Arjuna. It emphasizes the comprehensive nature of the wisdom about to be shared, suggesting that once understood, there will be nothing more to know. This indicates the profound and all-encompassing nature of spiritual knowledge, which, when fully grasped, leads to complete understanding and liberation.
shlokas.meaning: I shall now declare unto you in full this knowledge, both phenomenal and numinous. This being known, nothing further shall remain for you to know.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to seek comprehensive understanding in our pursuits, whether spiritual or worldly. It teaches that true knowledge is holistic and transformative, capable of answering all our fundamental questions. In practical life, this principle can be applied by striving for in-depth understanding in our fields of work or study, rather than superficial knowledge. It also motivates us to look beyond mere information and seek wisdom that can bring about a profound change in our perspective and way of living.

shlokas.name: Shloka 3
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मनुष्याणां सहस्रेषु कश्चिद्यतति सिद्धये।
यततामपि सिद्धानां कश्चिन्मां वेत्ति तत्त्वतः॥
shlokas.transliteration: manuṣyāṇāṁ sahasreṣu kaścid yatati siddhaye yatatām api siddhānāṁ kaścin māṁ vetti tattvataḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the rarity and difficulty of attaining true spiritual knowledge. It emphasizes that among thousands of people, only a few strive for spiritual perfection, and among those who strive, even fewer truly understand Krishna's divine nature. This underscores the importance of sincere spiritual practice and the value of those who achieve genuine realization.
shlokas.meaning: Among thousands of men, scarcely one strives for perfection; and of those who strive and succeed, scarcely one knows Me in truth.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages perseverance in spiritual practices, reminding us that true understanding is rare and valuable. It teaches us not to be discouraged by slow progress or lack of immediate results in our spiritual journey. It also emphasizes the importance of seeking authentic knowledge and guidance, as true understanding of the divine is not easily attained. In daily life, this can inspire us to be patient with our personal growth, to value wisdom, and to approach our goals with determination and humility.

shlokas.name: Shloka 4
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
भूमिरापोऽनलो वायुः खं मनो बुद्धिरेव च।
अहङ्कार इतीयं मे भिन्ना प्रकृतिरष्टधा॥
shlokas.transliteration: bhūmirāpo'nalo vāyuḥ khaṁ mano buddhireva ca ahaṅkāra itīyaṁ me bhinnā prakṛtiraṣṭadhā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse outlines the eightfold division of Krishna's lower nature (apara prakriti). It represents the material manifestation of the divine, encompassing both gross physical elements and subtle psychological aspects. This classification provides a comprehensive understanding of the cosmos and human existence, bridging the physical and metaphysical realms.
shlokas.meaning: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and ego - these are the eight divisions of My material nature.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals recognize the interconnectedness of all aspects of existence. It encourages a holistic approach to problem-solving, considering both material and psychological factors. This knowledge can be applied in fields like environmental conservation, personal development, and conflict resolution, promoting a balanced and comprehensive perspective on life's challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 5
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अपरेयमितस्त्वन्यां प्रकृतिं विद्धि मे पराम् ।
जीवभूतां महाबाहो ययेदं धार्यते जगत् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: apareyam itas tvanyam prakrtim viddhi me param jivabhutam maha-baho yayedam dharyate jagat
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of two natures of the Divine: the lower (apara) material nature and the higher (para) spiritual nature. Krishna explains that beyond the material elements, there exists a superior spiritual energy, which is the essence of all living entities. This higher nature sustains the entire universe and is the source of consciousness in all beings. The verse emphasizes the distinction between matter and spirit, highlighting the supremacy of the spiritual essence over material existence.
shlokas.meaning: Besides this inferior nature, O mighty-armed Arjuna, know that there is a superior energy of Mine, which comprises the living entities who sustain this world.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the two natures can help individuals recognize their true spiritual identity beyond the physical body. This knowledge can lead to a more balanced life, where one doesn't overly identify with material possessions or bodily concerns. It encourages spiritual practices and self-realization, promoting inner peace and a higher purpose in life. In practical terms, it can help in dealing with stress, anxiety, and existential questions by shifting focus from temporary material concerns to eternal spiritual truths.

shlokas.name: Shloka 6
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
एतद्योनीनि भूतानि सर्वाणीत्युपधारय |
अहं कृत्स्नस्य जगत: प्रभव: प्रलयस्तथा ||
shlokas.transliteration: etad-yonīni bhūtāni sarvāṇītyupadhāraya | ahaṁ kṛtsnasya jagataḥ prabhavaḥ pralayastathā ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the omnipresence and supreme nature of the Divine. Krishna declares that He is the source of all creation and dissolution, establishing His role as the ultimate cause behind the entire cosmic manifestation. This reinforces the concept of God's immanence in all beings and His transcendence beyond the material world.
shlokas.meaning: Know that all beings have their origin in these two natures (material and spiritual). I am the source of the entire creation and also of its dissolution.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals develop a sense of unity with all beings, recognizing the divine essence in everything. It encourages respect for nature and all life forms, promoting environmental consciousness and compassion. This knowledge can also alleviate fear of death by understanding the cyclical nature of creation and dissolution, leading to a more peaceful and purposeful life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 7
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मत्तः परतरं नान्यत्किञ्चिदस्ति धनञ्जय |
मयि सर्वमिदं प्रोतं सूत्रे मणिगणा इव ||
shlokas.transliteration: mattaḥ parataraṁ nānyat kiñcid asti dhanaṁjaya mayi sarvam idaṁ protaṁ sūtre maṇi-gaṇā iva
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the supreme nature of Krishna as the ultimate reality. It illustrates the concept of God's omnipresence and the interconnectedness of all existence. The analogy of gems strung on a thread beautifully conveys how the entire universe is held together by the divine, highlighting the philosophical idea of unity in diversity.
shlokas.meaning: There is nothing higher than Me, O Arjuna. Everything in this universe is strung on Me like pearls on a thread.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a sense of unity and interconnectedness with all beings, fostering compassion and reducing ego. It encourages seeing the divine in everything, which can lead to greater respect for nature and all forms of life. In problem-solving, it suggests looking for underlying connections and holistic approaches rather than isolated solutions.

shlokas.name: Shloka 8
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
रसोऽहमप्सु कौन्तेय प्रभास्मि शशिसूर्ययोः।
प्रणवः सर्ववेदेषु शब्दः खे पौरुषं नृषु॥
shlokas.transliteration: raso 'ham apsu kaunteya prabhasmi shashisuryayoh pranava sarvavedeu shabdah khe pauruam nru
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the omnipresence of the Divine in various aspects of nature and human experience. Krishna identifies himself with the essence of different elements and phenomena, emphasizing his pervasive presence in the universe. By equating himself with these fundamental aspects, Krishna illustrates the concept of divine immanence, suggesting that the Supreme Being is not separate from creation but intimately woven into its fabric.
shlokas.meaning: Krishna says: O son of Kunti, I am the taste in water, the radiance in the moon and sun, the sacred syllable Om in all the Vedas, the sound in ether, and the ability in humans.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to recognize the divine presence in everyday experiences and natural phenomena. It can help in developing a deeper appreciation for nature, fostering a sense of interconnectedness with the universe, and cultivating mindfulness in daily life. By seeing the divine in the ordinary, one can find greater meaning and purpose in life, leading to increased gratitude, respect for the environment, and a more harmonious existence with the world around us.

shlokas.name: Shloka 9
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पुण्यो गन्धः पृथिव्यां च तेजश्चास्मि विभावसौ।
जीवनं सर्वभूतेषु तपश्चास्मि तपस्विषु॥
shlokas.transliteration: punyo gandhah prthivyam ca tejascasmi vibhavasau jeevanam sarvabhuteshu tapascasmi tapasvishu
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the omnipresence of the Divine in various aspects of nature and life. It emphasizes that the Supreme Being manifests in the most fundamental and essential elements of existence. By listing these manifestations, Krishna is conveying to Arjuna that divinity is not distant or separate from the world, but is intimately woven into the fabric of creation. This understanding promotes a sense of reverence for all aspects of life and nature.
shlokas.meaning: I am the pure fragrance in earth and the brilliance in fire. I am the life in all beings and the austerity in ascetics.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to recognize the divine in everyday experiences and natural phenomena. It can help in developing mindfulness and appreciation for the world around us. By understanding that the divine permeates all aspects of life, we can cultivate respect for nature, practice conservation, and treat all living beings with compassion. It also inspires us to seek the extraordinary in the ordinary, finding spiritual significance in our daily lives and actions.

shlokas.name: Shloka 10
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
बीजं मां सर्वभूतानां विद्धि पार्थ सनातनम् |
बुद्धिर्बुद्धिमतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: bījam mām sarvabhūtānām viddhi pārtha sanātanam buddhir buddhimatām asmi tejas tejasvinām aham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes Krishna's omnipresence and His role as the fundamental essence of all existence. It illustrates the concept of divine immanence, suggesting that the Supreme Being is present in all things as their essential nature or seed. Krishna identifies Himself as the eternal seed of all beings, the intelligence of the intelligent, and the brilliance of the brilliant, highlighting His all-pervasive nature and His manifestation as the supreme quality in all entities.
shlokas.meaning: Know Me, O Arjuna, as the eternal seed of all beings. I am the intelligence of the intelligent, and the brilliance of the brilliant.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to recognize the divine essence in all beings and things, fostering respect and unity. It inspires one to cultivate intelligence and brilliance, understanding these as manifestations of the divine. In practical terms, it can motivate people to strive for excellence, knowing that their highest potential is a reflection of the divine. It also promotes a holistic worldview, seeing interconnectedness in all of creation, which can lead to more compassionate and mindful living.

shlokas.name: Shloka 11
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
बलं बलवतां चाहं कामरागविवर्जितम् |
धर्माविरुद्धो भूतेषु कामोऽस्मि भरतर्षभ ||
shlokas.transliteration: balaṁ balavatāṁ cāhaṁ kāmarāgavivarjitam | dharmāviruddho bhūteṣu kāmo'smi bharatarṣabha ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestation in various aspects of creation. He identifies himself as the strength of the strong, devoid of desire and attachment. Krishna also reveals that he is the desire in all beings that does not transgress dharma (righteousness). This shloka emphasizes the omnipresence of the divine in both physical and ethical realms, showcasing how even seemingly contradictory elements can be unified in the supreme being.
shlokas.meaning: I am the strength of the strong, free from desire and attachment. In all beings, I am the desire that is not contrary to dharma, O best of the Bharatas.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to cultivate strength without ego, to pursue desires that align with ethical principles, and to maintain balance in our actions. It encourages individuals to channel their strengths and desires towards righteous goals, promoting personal growth and societal harmony. By understanding that even our positive qualities and ethical desires are divine manifestations, we can develop a sense of humility and purpose in our daily lives.

shlokas.name: Shloka 12
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ये चैव सात्त्विका भावा राजसास्तामसाश्च ये ।
मत्त एवेति तान्विद्धि न त्वहं तेषु ते मयि ॥
shlokas.transliteration: ye caiva sāttvikā bhāvā rājasās tāmasāś ca ye | matta eveti tān viddhi na tv ahaṁ teṣu te mayi ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the all-pervasive nature of the Divine while maintaining its transcendence. It illustrates the concept of 'unity in diversity' by stating that all qualities and states of being, whether pure, passionate, or ignorant, ultimately originate from the Supreme. However, it also establishes a subtle distinction between the Divine and its manifestations, highlighting the philosophy of 'qualified non-dualism' or 'Vishishtadvaita'.
shlokas.meaning: Know that all states of being - whether of goodness, passion or ignorance - are manifested from Me alone. I am not in them, but they are in Me.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can help individuals understand the inherent divinity in all aspects of life, fostering respect and acceptance for diverse human qualities and experiences. It encourages a balanced perspective, recognizing that both positive and negative attributes have a place in the grand scheme of existence. This understanding can lead to reduced judgment of others, increased self-awareness, and a more harmonious approach to life's various situations and challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 13
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
त्रिभिर्गुणमयैर्भावैरेभिः सर्वमिदं जगत् |
मोहितं नाभिजानाति मामेभ्यः परमव्ययम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: tribhir guṇamayair bhāvair ebhiḥ sarvam idaṁ jagat mohitaṁ nābhijānāti mām ebhyaḥ param avyayam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the pervasive influence of the three gunas (sattva, rajas, and tamas) on the material world and how they veil the Supreme Reality. It emphasizes the transcendental nature of the Divine, which exists beyond these material qualities. The verse also points to the ignorance that results from being entangled in these gunas, preventing one from recognizing the eternal, unchanging nature of the Supreme.
shlokas.meaning: The entire world is deluded by the states of being born of the three gunas (qualities of material nature). As a result, it fails to recognize Me, who am beyond these gunas and imperishable.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching encourages individuals to look beyond surface-level experiences and material attractions. By understanding the influence of the gunas on our perceptions and actions, we can strive to transcend these material qualities. This awareness can help in making more conscious choices, developing detachment from worldly illusions, and focusing on spiritual growth. It also emphasizes the importance of seeking higher knowledge and understanding to overcome the limitations imposed by our material existence.

shlokas.name: Shloka 14
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया ।
मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते ॥
shlokas.transliteration: daivī hy eṣā guṇamayī mama māyā duratyayā | mām eva ye prapadyante māyām etāṁ taranti te ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of Maya, the divine illusion that veils the ultimate reality. Krishna explains that his Maya, composed of the three gunas (sattva, rajas, and tamas), is extremely difficult to overcome. However, he also provides the solution: those who surrender completely to him can transcend this illusion. This emphasizes the importance of devotion (bhakti) and complete surrender (prapatti) in spiritual practice.
shlokas.meaning: This divine illusion of Mine, consisting of the three modes of material nature, is difficult to overcome. However, those who surrender unto Me alone can easily cross beyond it.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied to overcome life's challenges by recognizing that our perceptions and struggles are often a result of Maya or illusion. By cultivating a sense of surrender to a higher power or purpose, one can gain the strength and clarity to navigate through life's complexities. It encourages developing detachment from material entanglements and focusing on spiritual growth, which can lead to greater peace and understanding in daily life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 15
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
न मां दुष्कृतिनो मूढाः प्रपद्यन्ते नराधमाः।
माययापहृतज्ञाना आसुरं भावमाश्रिताः॥
shlokas.transliteration: na māṁ duṣkṛtino mūḍhāḥ prapadyante narādhamāḥ māyayāpahṛtajñānā āsuraṁ bhāvamāśritāḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the contrast between those who seek divine knowledge and those who are deluded by ignorance. It emphasizes that individuals who engage in evil deeds, are foolish, or have their wisdom stolen by illusion (maya) do not surrender to Krishna. These people, described as the lowest among mankind, cling to demonic qualities and fail to recognize the supreme nature of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: The evil-doers, the deluded, the lowest of men, do not seek Me. Their wisdom has been taken away by illusion, and they have embraced an demonic nature.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages self-reflection and the cultivation of positive qualities. It teaches us to be aware of our actions and thoughts, striving to overcome ignorance and delusion. In practical life, it reminds us to seek knowledge, question our beliefs, and avoid harmful behaviors. It also emphasizes the importance of surrounding ourselves with positive influences and pursuing spiritual growth to avoid falling into destructive patterns of thinking and behavior.

shlokas.name: Shloka 16
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
चतुर्विधा भजन्ते मां जनाः सुकृतिनोऽर्जुन |
आर्तो जिज्ञासुरर्थार्थी ज्ञानी च भरतर्षभ ||
shlokas.transliteration: caturvidhā bhajante māṁ janāḥ sukṛtino 'rjuna ārto jijñāsur arthārthī jñānī ca bharatarṣabha
shlokas.interpretation: This verse categorizes devotees into four types, suggesting that all sincere seekers, regardless of their initial motivation, are on the path to spiritual growth. It implies that devotion can arise from various life circumstances and inner drives, and that the Divine accepts all forms of sincere approach. The verse also hints at a hierarchy of spiritual evolution, with the seeker of knowledge being considered the highest.
shlokas.meaning: Four types of virtuous people worship Me, O Arjuna: the distressed, the seeker of knowledge, the seeker of wealth, and the wise.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in understanding and respecting diverse spiritual paths and motivations. It encourages inclusivity in spiritual communities and personal growth, reminding us that everyone's journey is valid. In leadership and mentoring roles, it suggests tailoring guidance based on an individual's current spiritual state and motivation. It also promotes self-reflection on one's own spiritual journey and motivations, encouraging progression towards wisdom and selfless devotion.

shlokas.name: Shloka 17
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तेषां ज्ञानी नित्ययुक्त एकभक्तिर्विशिष्यते |
प्रियो हि ज्ञानिनोऽत्यर्थमहं स च मम प्रिय: ||
shlokas.transliteration: teṣāṁ jñānī nityayukta ekabhaktir viśiṣyate priyo hi jñānino 'tyartham ahaṁ sa ca mama priyaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the superiority of the jnani (the wise one) among the four types of devotees mentioned earlier. It emphasizes the deep, reciprocal love between the jnani and Krishna, suggesting that true wisdom leads to unwavering devotion and a profound connection with the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: Among these devotees, the wise one who is ever united with Me through exclusive devotion is the best. I am extremely dear to such a wise person, and he is equally dear to Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to cultivate both knowledge and devotion in our spiritual practice. It teaches that true wisdom leads to a deep, loving relationship with the Divine, which can provide comfort, guidance, and purpose in life. By striving to understand the nature of reality and developing a sincere devotion to a higher power, we can find inner peace and navigate life's challenges with greater clarity and resilience.

shlokas.name: Shloka 18
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
उदाराः सर्व एवैते ज्ञानी त्वात्मैव मे मतम् |
आस्थितः स हि युक्तात्मा मामेवानुत्तमां गतिम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: udārāḥ sarva evaite jñānī tvātmaiva me matam | āsthitaḥ sa hi yuktātmā māmevānuttamāṁ gatim ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the superiority of the enlightened devotee (jnani) among all types of devotees. While Krishna appreciates all forms of devotion, he considers the jnani as his very self. This is because the jnani, with unwavering devotion and complete understanding, recognizes Krishna as the ultimate reality and the highest goal. The verse emphasizes the importance of knowledge combined with devotion in spiritual practice.
shlokas.meaning: All these devotees are indeed noble, but I regard the wise man as My very Self. With steadfast mind, he remains fixed on Me alone as the supreme goal.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to cultivate both knowledge and devotion in our spiritual journey. It teaches that while all sincere spiritual practices are valuable, striving for a deeper understanding of the divine nature can lead to a more profound connection with the supreme. In daily life, this can be applied by combining intellectual pursuit of spiritual knowledge with heartfelt devotion, leading to a more balanced and fulfilling spiritual practice. It also emphasizes the importance of setting the highest spiritual goal and remaining steadfast in our pursuit, which can help in maintaining focus and determination in all aspects of life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 19
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
बहूनां जन्मनामन्ते ज्ञानवान्मां प्रपद्यते |
वासुदेवः सर्वमिति स महात्मा सुदुर्लभः ||
shlokas.transliteration: bahūnāṁ janmanām ante jñānavān māṁ prapadyate | vāsudevaḥ sarvam iti sa mahātmā sudurlabhaḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the rarity and significance of true spiritual wisdom. It suggests that after numerous lifetimes of spiritual evolution, a person finally realizes the omnipresence of the Divine (Vasudeva) and surrenders to it. This realization is not easily attained and marks the pinnacle of spiritual journey, emphasizing the value of persistent spiritual seeking across multiple lifetimes.
shlokas.meaning: After many births, the wise one surrenders to Me, realizing that everything is Vasudeva (the Divine). Such a great soul is very rare.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages perseverance in spiritual practices and self-improvement, reminding us that true wisdom and enlightenment may take time but are ultimately achievable. It teaches us to see the divine in everything, promoting a sense of unity and respect for all creation. This perspective can help in developing patience, humility, and a broader understanding of life's purpose, leading to better decision-making and more harmonious relationships in daily life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 20
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
कामैस्तैस्तैर्हृतज्ञाना: प्रपद्यन्तेऽन्यदेवता: |
तं तं नियममास्थाय प्रकृत्या नियता: स्वया ||
shlokas.transliteration: kāmais tais tair hṛta-jñānāḥ prapadyante 'nya-devatāḥ taṁ taṁ niyamam āsthāya prakṛtyā niyatāḥ svayā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the nature of those whose wisdom is clouded by material desires. It explains that such individuals, driven by their inherent nature and specific longings, turn to various demigods or lesser deities. This practice stems from a lack of complete understanding of the Supreme Being. The verse indirectly emphasizes the superiority of devotion to the Supreme God over worship of lesser deities, while also acknowledging the role of one's innate tendencies in shaping their spiritual choices.
shlokas.meaning: Those whose knowledge is stolen by material desires surrender to other deities, following various rules and regulations according to their own nature.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in understanding and respecting diverse spiritual practices while recognizing the importance of transcending material desires for true spiritual growth. It encourages self-reflection on our motivations behind religious practices and the pursuit of a higher understanding beyond immediate material gains. In practical life, it suggests examining our goals and desires, ensuring they align with our deeper spiritual nature rather than being driven solely by temporary material wants.

shlokas.name: Shloka 21
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यो यो यां यां तनुं भक्तः श्रद्धयार्चितुमिच्छति।
तस्य तस्याचलां श्रद्धां तामेव विदधाम्यहम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: yo yo yāṁ yāṁ tanuṁ bhaktaḥ śraddhayārcitum icchati tasyatasyācalāṁ śraddhāṁ tām eva vidadhāmy aham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the concept of divine accommodation, where Krishna acknowledges and supports the diverse forms of worship chosen by devotees. It emphasizes that regardless of the form or deity one chooses to worship with faith, it is ultimately the Supreme Being (Krishna) who strengthens that faith. This teaching promotes religious tolerance and underscores the unity of all spiritual paths.
shlokas.meaning: Whatever form of deity a devotee wishes to worship with faith, I strengthen that very faith of his.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied to promote religious harmony and respect for diverse spiritual practices. It encourages individuals to be tolerant of others' beliefs while remaining steadfast in their own faith. In a multicultural society, this teaching can help reduce religious conflicts and foster mutual understanding. On a personal level, it reassures devotees that their sincere faith, regardless of its form, is recognized and supported by the divine, which can provide comfort and confidence in one's spiritual journey.

shlokas.name: Shloka 22
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
स यया श्रद्धया युक्तस्तस्याराधनमीहते।
तस्य तामेव श्रद्धां तां स्थिरां करोम्यहम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: sa yayā śraddhayā yuktas tasyārādhanam īhate | tasya tām eva śraddhāṁ tāṁ sthirāṁ karomy aham ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the divine reciprocity in spiritual practices. It emphasizes that regardless of the form or deity one chooses to worship, it is ultimately the Supreme Being who strengthens the devotee's faith. This demonstrates the inclusive nature of spiritual pursuit and the underlying unity of all forms of worship.
shlokas.meaning: Endowed with the faith of their choice, devotees worship a particular deity. I, the Supreme Being, make their faith steady and unwavering in that very form.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied to promote religious tolerance and respect for diverse spiritual practices. It encourages individuals to deepen their own faith while acknowledging the validity of others' beliefs. In personal spiritual journeys, it reassures that sincere devotion, regardless of the form, is recognized and supported by the divine, helping to overcome doubts and strengthen one's spiritual resolve.

shlokas.name: Shloka 23
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अन्तवत्तु फलं तेषां तद्भवत्यल्पमेधसाम् |
देवान्देवयजो यान्ति मद्भक्ता यान्ति मामपि ||
shlokas.transliteration: antavat tu phalaṁ teṣāṁ tad bhavaty alpa-medhasām devān deva-yajo yānti mad-bhaktā yānti mām api
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the distinction between those who worship lesser deities and those who worship Krishna directly. It emphasizes the temporary nature of rewards gained from worshipping demigods, contrasting it with the eternal benefit of devotion to Krishna. The verse also implies a hierarchy in spiritual pursuits, suggesting that direct devotion to the Supreme is the highest form of worship.
shlokas.meaning: The fruit gained by those of limited understanding who worship demigods is temporary. The worshippers of demigods go to the demigods, but My devotees ultimately come to Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to focus on long-term spiritual goals rather than short-term material gains. It encourages us to develop a deeper understanding of the divine and to cultivate direct devotion to the Supreme. In practical life, this can be applied by prioritizing actions and relationships that have lasting value over those that offer only temporary satisfaction. It also reminds us to seek wisdom and expand our understanding to make better life choices.

shlokas.name: Shloka 24
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अव्यक्तं व्यक्तिमापन्नं मन्यन्ते मामबुद्धयः।
परं भावमजानन्तो ममाव्ययमनुत्तमम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: avyaktaṁ vyaktim āpannaṁ manyante mām abuddhayaḥ paraṁ bhāvam ajānanto mamāvyayam anuttamam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the misconception of those who fail to understand Krishna's transcendental nature. It emphasizes the limitation of human perception in comprehending the supreme, unchanging form of the Divine. The verse points out that ignorant people, unable to grasp the eternal, unmanifested aspect of Krishna, mistakenly believe that He has taken a temporary, manifested form. This misunderstanding stems from a lack of knowledge about Krishna's supreme, imperishable nature.
shlokas.meaning: The unintelligent think that I, the Unmanifested, have assumed a manifest form, not knowing My supreme nature, which is changeless and unsurpassed.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to look beyond surface-level appearances and seek deeper understanding in all aspects of life. It encourages us to question our perceptions and not be limited by our immediate senses or preconceived notions. In practical terms, this can be applied to personal relationships, where we should strive to understand the true nature of people rather than judging them based on outward appearances. In problem-solving, it reminds us to look for underlying causes rather than focusing solely on symptoms. This approach can lead to more comprehensive solutions in various life situations, from personal growth to professional challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 25
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
नाहं प्रकाशः सर्वस्य योगमायासमावृतः |
मूढोऽयं नाभिजानाति लोको मामजमव्ययम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: nāhaṁ prakāśaḥ sarvasya yogamāyāsamāvṛtaḥ mūḍho'yaṁ nābhijānāti loko māmajamavyayam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse reveals the concept of divine concealment. Krishna explains that He is not manifest to everyone due to His Yogamaya (divine illusory energy). This highlights the idea that spiritual knowledge and perception of the divine is not equally accessible to all, but depends on one's level of consciousness and devotion. It also emphasizes the transcendental nature of God, being unborn and imperishable, which is beyond the comprehension of the deluded minds.
shlokas.meaning: I am not manifest to all, being veiled by My divine potency (Yogamaya). The deluded world does not recognize Me, the unborn and imperishable.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in understanding why different people have varying levels of spiritual awareness or faith. It encourages seekers to cultivate devotion and spiritual knowledge to pierce through the veil of illusion. In daily life, it reminds us to be patient and non-judgmental towards those who may not share our spiritual understanding, recognizing that everyone is at different stages of their spiritual journey. It also motivates us to continually strive for higher spiritual awareness and not be complacent in our current understanding of the divine.

shlokas.name: Shloka 26
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
वेदाहं समतीतानि वर्तमानानि चार्जुन |
भविष्याणि च भूतानि मां तु वेद न कश्चन ||
shlokas.transliteration: vedāhaṁ samatītāni vartamānāni cārjuna bhaviṣyāṇi ca bhūtāni māṁ tu veda na kaścana
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's omniscience and the limitations of human knowledge. It emphasizes the transcendental nature of the Supreme Being, who exists beyond the confines of time. The verse also underscores the difficulty for ordinary beings to fully comprehend the divine, suggesting that true knowledge of God comes through devotion and divine grace rather than mere intellectual pursuit.
shlokas.meaning: Krishna states that He knows all beings of the past, present, and future, but no one truly knows Him in His entirety.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching encourages humility in our pursuit of knowledge and understanding. It reminds us to approach life's mysteries and challenges with an open mind, recognizing that our perception and knowledge are limited. In practical terms, it advocates for continuous learning, spiritual growth, and the cultivation of devotion as means to gain deeper insights into the nature of reality and our own existence.

shlokas.name: Shloka 27
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
इच्छाद्वेषसमुत्थेन द्वन्द्वमोहेन भारत |
सर्वभूतानि सम्मोहं सर्गे यान्ति परन्तप ||
shlokas.transliteration: icchā-dveṣa-samutthena dvandva-mohena bhārata sarvabhūtāni sammohaṁ sarge yānti parantapa
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the fundamental cause of delusion in the material world. Krishna explains that all beings are born into a state of confusion due to the duality arising from desire and aversion. This duality is the root of attachment and suffering, clouding one's judgment and preventing the realization of one's true spiritual nature. The verse emphasizes the universal nature of this delusion, affecting all living entities at the time of creation.
shlokas.meaning: O Arjuna, all beings are born into delusion, overcome by the dualities of desire and hate.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals recognize the source of their confusion and suffering in life. By becoming aware of how desires and aversions create a dualistic mindset, one can work towards detachment and equanimity. This awareness can lead to better decision-making, reduced stress, and a more balanced approach to life's challenges. Practicing mindfulness and self-reflection can help in identifying and transcending these dualities, leading to greater peace and spiritual growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 28
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
येषां त्वन्तगतं पापं जनानां पुण्यकर्मणाम् ।
ते द्वन्द्वमोहनिर्मुक्ता भजन्ते मां दृढव्रताः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: yeṣāṁ tv antagataṁ pāpaṁ janānāṁ puṇya-karmaṇām te dvandva-moha-nirmuktā bhajante māṁ dṛḍha-vratāḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of righteous actions and their impact on spiritual progress. It suggests that those who have consistently performed virtuous deeds gradually purify themselves, freeing their minds from the dualities of material existence. This purification leads to unwavering devotion to the Divine, emphasizing the interconnection between karma (action), jnana (knowledge), and bhakti (devotion) in spiritual evolution.
shlokas.meaning: Those persons whose sinful actions have come to an end, and who are freed from the dualities of delusion, worship Me with determination and firm resolve.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to persistently engage in virtuous actions, as they lead to mental clarity and spiritual growth. It teaches that by consistently choosing ethical behavior, one can overcome inner conflicts, develop stronger willpower, and cultivate a deeper connection with their higher self or the Divine. This principle can be applied in daily life by consciously making ethical choices, practicing mindfulness to recognize and transcend dualities, and maintaining unwavering commitment to one's spiritual or personal growth goals.

shlokas.name: Shloka 29
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
जरामरणमोक्षाय मामाश्रित्य यतन्ति ये ।
ते ब्रह्म तद्विदुः कृत्स्नमध्यात्मं कर्म चाखिलम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: jarāmaraṇamokṣāya māmāśritya yatanti ye | te brahma tadviduḥ kṛtsnamadhyātmaṁ karma cākhilam ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of seeking refuge in the Divine (Krishna) for liberation from the cycle of birth, old age, and death. It suggests that those who earnestly strive for this liberation through devotion to the Supreme gain comprehensive knowledge of Brahman, the self, and the nature of all action. This holistic understanding leads to ultimate freedom from material bondage.
shlokas.meaning: Those who take refuge in Me and strive for liberation from old age and death come to know Brahman in its entirety, along with the complete knowledge of the self and all aspects of action.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to focus on spiritual growth and self-realization as a means to overcome the fear of aging and death. By cultivating a deeper connection with the Divine and gaining spiritual knowledge, one can find peace and purpose in life. It teaches that through sincere spiritual practice and devotion, we can attain a comprehensive understanding of existence, leading to inner tranquility and freedom from existential anxieties.

shlokas.name: Shloka 30
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
साधिभूताधिदैवं मां साधियज्ञं च ये विदुः ।
प्रयाणकालेऽपि च मां ते विदुर्युक्तचेतसः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: sādhibhūtādhidaivaṁ māṁ sādhiyajñaṁ ca ye viduḥ prayāṇakāle'pi ca māṁ te vidur yuktacetasaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of complete knowledge of Krishna, including His manifestations in the material world (adhibhuta), His divine form (adhidaiva), and His presence in sacrifices (adhiyajna). It suggests that those who possess this comprehensive understanding can maintain their focus on Krishna even at the time of death, ensuring spiritual liberation.
shlokas.meaning: Those who know Me as the Supreme Lord of the material manifestation, the celestial gods, and all sacrifices, can remember Me even at the time of death, with their consciousness united with Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to cultivate a deep, all-encompassing understanding of the Divine in various aspects of life. By recognizing the presence of the Supreme in material elements, celestial beings, and sacred rituals, one can develop a constant awareness of the Divine. This practice helps in maintaining spiritual focus during challenging times, especially when facing death, leading to peace of mind and spiritual progress. It teaches us to integrate spiritual awareness into our daily lives, seeing the Divine in all aspects of existence.
