shlokas.name: Shloka 1
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अर्जुन उवाच
किं तद्ब्रह्म किमध्यात्मं किं कर्म पुरुषोत्तम |
अधिभूतं च किं प्रोक्तमधिदैवं किमुच्यते || 1||
shlokas.transliteration: arjuna uvācha kiṁ tad brahma kim adhyātmaṁ kiṁ karma puruṣhottama adhibhūtaṁ cha kiṁ proktam adhidaivaṁ kim uchyate
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks the beginning of Chapter 8, where Arjuna seeks clarification on several fundamental concepts of spiritual knowledge. His questions demonstrate a deep curiosity about the nature of existence, the self, and the divine. By addressing Krishna as 'Purushottama' (Supreme Person), Arjuna acknowledges Krishna's divine status and his ability to provide authoritative answers to these profound inquiries.
shlokas.meaning: Arjuna asks: O Supreme Person, what is Brahman? What is the Self? What is action? What is the material manifestation? And what are the celestial gods?
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to cultivate a spirit of inquiry and seek deeper understanding of life's fundamental questions. In our daily lives, we can apply this teaching by regularly reflecting on our existence, actions, and relationship with the divine. By questioning and seeking answers about our true nature and purpose, we can gain clarity and make more conscious decisions aligned with our spiritual goals.

shlokas.name: Shloka 2
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अधियज्ञः कथं कोऽत्र देहेऽस्मिन्मधुसूदन |
प्रयाणकाले च कथं ज्ञेयोऽसि नियतात्मभिः ||
shlokas.transliteration: adhiyajñaḥ kathaṁ ko 'tra dehe 'smin madhusūdana prayāṇakāle ca kathaṁ jñeyo 'si niyatātmabhiḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse raises two profound questions about the nature of the Divine and its relationship to the individual soul. Arjuna seeks to understand the concept of Adhiyajna (the Lord of all sacrifices) and how it relates to the physical body. He also inquires about how self-controlled individuals can remember the Divine at the time of death. These questions delve into the core of spiritual practice and the ultimate goal of union with the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: O Madhusudana, who is the Lord of sacrifice, and how does He dwell in this body? And how can those of steadfast mind know You at the time of departure?
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to cultivate a constant awareness of the Divine presence in our lives, not just in moments of worship but in our everyday existence. It teaches us to live with the end in mind, preparing ourselves spiritually for the ultimate transition. By developing self-control and steadfast devotion, we can face life's challenges and uncertainties with greater equanimity. This approach can help in reducing anxiety about death and fostering a more meaningful and purposeful life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 3
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अक्षरं ब्रह्म परमं स्वभावोऽध्यात्ममुच्यते।
भूतभावोद्भवकरो विसर्गः कर्मसंज्ञितः॥
shlokas.transliteration: akṣaraṁ brahma paramaṁ svabhāvo'dhyātmam ucyate | bhūta-bhāvodbhava-karo visargaḥ karma-saṁjñitaḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse delves into the fundamental concepts of Brahman, Adhyatma, and Karma. It emphasizes the eternal nature of Brahman as the supreme reality, introduces the concept of individual nature (Svabhava) as the essence of the self, and explains Karma as the creative force behind the manifestation of beings. This shloka provides a concise yet profound explanation of the cosmic order and individual existence within it.
shlokas.meaning: The indestructible, transcendental living entity is called Brahman, and its eternal nature is called Adhyatma, the self. Actions pertaining to the development of the material bodies of the living entities are called Karma, or fruitive activities.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals recognize their true nature beyond the physical body, encouraging spiritual growth. It promotes self-reflection on one's inherent qualities (Svabhava) and mindfulness of how actions (Karma) shape one's life and future. This knowledge can lead to more conscious decision-making, reduced attachment to material outcomes, and a greater sense of purpose aligned with one's spiritual essence.

shlokas.name: Shloka 4
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अधिभूतं क्षरो भावः पुरुषश्चाधिदैवतम् |
अधियज्ञोऽहमेवात्र देहे देहभृतां वर ||
shlokas.transliteration: adhibhūtaṁ kṣaro bhāvaḥ puruṣaścādhidaivatam adhiyajño 'ham evātra dehe dehabhṛtāṁ vara
shlokas.interpretation: This verse explains the different aspects of the manifest world and their relationship to the Supreme. It introduces the concepts of Adhibhuta (physical manifestation), Adhidaiva (the controlling deities), and Adhiyajna (the Supreme Lord as the overseer of all sacrifices). Krishna reveals that He is present in every living being as the Supersoul, overseeing all actions and sacrifices.
shlokas.meaning: The perishable physical manifestation is called Adhibhuta, the universal self is called Adhidaiva, and I, the Supreme Lord, am the Adhiyajna present in the body of all living entities, O best of the embodied beings.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse helps one recognize the temporary nature of the physical world and the eternal presence of the Divine in all beings. It encourages individuals to look beyond material attachments and cultivate a deeper spiritual awareness. This knowledge can lead to a more balanced approach to life, where one performs their duties as a form of sacrifice to the Divine, fostering inner peace and harmony with the cosmic order.

shlokas.name: Shloka 5
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम् |
यः प्रयाति स मद्भावं याति नास्त्यत्र संशयः ||
shlokas.transliteration: antakāle ca mām eva smaran muktvā kalevaram | yaḥ prayāti sa madbhāvaṁ yāti nāsty atra saṁśayaḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of one's final thoughts at the time of death. It suggests that if a person remembers Krishna (the Supreme Being) at the moment of leaving their body, they will attain His divine state. This teaching underscores the power of devotion and the significance of maintaining spiritual consciousness throughout life, as our last thoughts are often a reflection of our deepest attachments and most ingrained habits.
shlokas.meaning: And whoever, at the end of their life, quits their body while remembering Me alone, at once attains My nature. Of this there is no doubt.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to cultivate a consistent spiritual practice and devotion throughout their lives. It teaches that by regularly remembering and connecting with the divine, one can develop the habit of maintaining spiritual consciousness even in challenging times. This practice can help in facing death with calmness and clarity, and also in dealing with daily stresses and anxieties by maintaining a higher perspective. It emphasizes the importance of living mindfully and purposefully, always being aware of one's ultimate spiritual goal.

shlokas.name: Shloka 6
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यं यं वापि स्मरन्भावं त्यजत्यन्ते कलेवरम् |
तं तमेवैति कौन्तेय सदा तद्भावभावितः ||
shlokas.transliteration: yaṁ yaṁ vāpi smaran bhāvaṁ tyajatyante kalevaram | taṁ tam evaiti kaunteya sadā tad-bhāva-bhāvitaḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the power of one's final thoughts at the moment of death. It suggests that our predominant thoughts and attachments throughout life shape our consciousness at death, which in turn influences our next birth or spiritual destination. This teaching underscores the importance of cultivating positive, spiritual thoughts and detachment from worldly desires throughout one's life.
shlokas.meaning: Whatever state of being one remembers when quitting the body at the time of death, that state he will attain without fail, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), being always absorbed in that thought.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to live mindfully and cultivate positive thoughts and spiritual practices consistently. It can be applied to overcome fear of death by focusing on spiritual growth, practicing meditation, and maintaining a positive mindset. In daily life, it motivates one to be conscious of their thoughts and actions, knowing that these shape their character and future. It also emphasizes the importance of staying focused on one's goals and aspirations, as persistent thoughts and efforts lead to their realization.

shlokas.name: Shloka 7
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु मामनुस्मर युध्य च।
मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्मामेवैष्यस्यसंशयम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: tasmāt sarveṣu kāleṣu mām anusmara yudhya ca | mayy arpita-mano-buddhir mām evaiṣyasy asaṁśayam ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of constant remembrance of the Divine while performing one's duties. It suggests that by maintaining a continuous connection with the Supreme Being, even amidst life's challenges and battles, one can achieve ultimate union with the Divine. The verse also highlights the concept of surrender, indicating that when one's mind and intellect are fully devoted to the Divine, the path to spiritual realization becomes clear and certain.
shlokas.meaning: Therefore, always remember Me and fight. With your mind and intellect surrendered to Me, you will undoubtedly come to Me.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life by maintaining awareness of a higher purpose or spiritual goal while engaging in work or facing challenges. It encourages individuals to cultivate a practice of mindfulness, where they remain connected to their spiritual center even during mundane activities. This approach can help in reducing stress, improving focus, and finding meaning in all aspects of life. By surrendering the ego and aligning one's thoughts and actions with higher principles, a person can navigate life's complexities with greater clarity and purpose.

shlokas.name: Shloka 8
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अभ्यासयोगयुक्तेन चेतसा नान्यगामिना।
परमं पुरुषं दिव्यं याति पार्थानुचिन्तयन्॥
shlokas.transliteration: abhyāsayogayuktena cetasā nānyagāminā | paramaṁ puruṣaṁ divyaṁ yāti pārthānucintayan ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of consistent spiritual practice (abhyasa yoga) and unwavering focus on the Divine. It suggests that through regular meditation and by keeping one's mind fixed on the Supreme Being, one can attain the highest spiritual realization. The verse highlights the power of devoted thought and the transformative nature of consistent spiritual discipline.
shlokas.meaning: By engaging in the practice of yoga with a mind undistracted by anything else, and by constantly meditating on the Supreme Divine Person, one attains that Supreme Divine Being, O Partha (Arjuna).
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied to achieve success in any endeavor by emphasizing the power of focused practice and unwavering dedication. In daily life, it encourages developing a routine of mindfulness or meditation, setting clear goals, and maintaining consistent effort towards them. It also teaches the importance of avoiding distractions and maintaining a singular focus on one's chosen path or objective, whether in career, relationships, or personal growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 9
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
कविं पुराणमनुशासितार-
मणोरणीयांसमनुस्मरेद्यः ।
सर्वस्य धातारमचिन्त्यरूप-
मादित्यवर्णं तमसः परस्तात् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: kavim purāṇam anuśāsitāram aṇor aṇīyāṁsam anusmared yaḥ sarvasya dhātāram acintya-rūpam āditya-varṇaṁ tamasaḥ parastāt
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of meditating on the Supreme Being's transcendental nature. It describes the Divine as the omniscient poet, the primeval, the controller, subtler than the subtlest, the sustainer of all, inconceivable in form, self-luminous, and beyond all darkness of ignorance. The verse encourages seekers to constantly remember these qualities of the Divine to attain spiritual realization.
shlokas.meaning: One should meditate upon the Supreme Person as the one who knows everything, as He who is the oldest, who is the controller, who is smaller than the smallest, who is the maintainer of everything, who is beyond all material conception, who is inconceivable, and who is always a person. He is luminous like the sun and, being transcendental, is beyond this material nature.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in daily life to cultivate a deeper spiritual practice and perspective. By regularly contemplating the divine attributes mentioned, one can develop humility, expand consciousness, and find inner peace. It encourages individuals to look beyond the material world and seek a higher understanding of existence, which can help in overcoming ego, reducing stress, and finding purpose in life. The practice of remembering these qualities can also serve as a form of meditation, improving focus and mental clarity in various life situations.

shlokas.name: Shloka 10
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
प्रयाणकाले मनसाचलेन
भक्त्या युक्तो योगबलेन चैव ।
भ्रुवोर्मध्ये प्राणमावेश्य सम्यक्
स तं परं पुरुषमुपैति दिव्यम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: prayāṇa-kāle manasācalena bhaktyā yukto yoga-balena caiva bhruvor madhye prāṇam āveśya samyak sa taṁ paraṁ puruṣam upaiti divyam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the process of leaving the body at the time of death for an advanced yogi. It emphasizes the importance of unwavering focus, devotion, and yogic practices in achieving union with the Supreme Divine Being. The verse highlights the significance of controlling one's life force (prana) and directing it to the space between the eyebrows, a practice known as samadhi in yoga.
shlokas.meaning: At the time of departure, with an unwavering mind, filled with devotion and by the power of yoga, properly placing the life breath between the eyebrows, one attains to the Supreme Divine Person.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of maintaining focus and devotion in our spiritual practices, especially during challenging times. It encourages developing mental strength through yoga and meditation, which can help in facing life's difficulties with calmness and clarity. The practice of controlling one's breath and focusing the mind can be applied in daily life to reduce stress, improve concentration, and achieve a sense of inner peace. It also reminds us to live with awareness and purpose, as our state of mind at critical moments can significantly impact our life's journey.

shlokas.name: Shloka 11
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यदक्षरं वेदविदो वदन्ति
विशन्ति यद्यतयो वीतरागाः।
यदिच्छन्तो ब्रह्मचर्यं चरन्ति
तत्ते पदं संग्रहेण प्रवक्ष्ये॥
shlokas.transliteration: yadakṣaraṁ vedavido vadanti viśanti yadyatayo vītarāgāḥ yadicchanto brahmacaryaṁ caranti tatte padaṁ saṅgraheṇa pravakṣye
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of the Supreme Absolute Truth, or Brahman, as the ultimate goal of spiritual seekers. It emphasizes the importance of Vedic knowledge, renunciation, and celibacy in attaining this highest state. The verse also highlights that this supreme state is beyond the material world and can be reached through dedicated spiritual practice and detachment from worldly desires.
shlokas.meaning: That which is described as imperishable by the knowers of the Vedas, which the great sages enter when they are free from all material desires, and to attain which people practice celibacy, I shall now explain to you briefly.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to pursue higher knowledge and spiritual growth. It teaches that by cultivating discipline, practicing detachment from material desires, and focusing on spiritual studies, one can overcome life's challenges and find true purpose. This approach can help in managing stress, improving self-control, and developing a more balanced and fulfilling life perspective.

shlokas.name: Shloka 12
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सर्वद्वाराणि संयम्य मनो हृदि निरुध्य च ।
मूर्ध्न्याधायात्मनः प्राणमास्थितो योगधारणाम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: sarva-dvārāṇi saṁyamya mano hṛdi nirudhya ca mūrdhny ādhāyātmanaḥ prāṇam āsthito yoga-dhāraṇām
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the process of yogic meditation and the control of life force for achieving union with the Divine. It emphasizes the importance of sensory withdrawal, mental concentration, and the regulation of vital energy (prana) in spiritual practice. The verse suggests that by mastering these techniques, one can attain a state of deep meditation and ultimately, liberation.
shlokas.meaning: Closing all the gates of the body, confining the mind in the heart, drawing the life-breath to the head, and engaging in the practice of yogic concentration.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in daily life to manage stress, improve focus, and enhance overall well-being. By practicing sensory control and mindfulness, one can reduce distractions and increase productivity. The breathing techniques mentioned can be used for relaxation and anxiety management. Regular meditation as described can lead to better emotional regulation, clearer thinking, and a more balanced approach to life's challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 13
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ओमित्येकाक्षरं ब्रह्म व्याहरन्मामनुस्मरन् |
य: प्रयाति त्यजन्देहं स याति परमां गतिम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: om ity ekākṣaraṁ brahma vyāharan mām anusmaran yaḥ prayāti tyajan dehaṁ sa yāti paramāṁ gatim
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of remembering the Divine at the time of death. It suggests that by uttering the sacred syllable 'Om' and meditating on the Supreme Being while leaving the body, one can attain the highest spiritual destination. The verse highlights the power of focused consciousness and devotion at the final moment of life, indicating that one's last thoughts can significantly influence their spiritual journey after death.
shlokas.meaning: One who leaves the body while uttering the single syllable 'Om', which is Brahman, and remembering Me, attains the supreme goal.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied to cultivate a constant awareness of the Divine in daily life, not just at the time of death. It encourages individuals to practice mindfulness, meditation, and devotion regularly, so that remembering the Divine becomes second nature. This practice can help in reducing fear of death, maintaining calm in difficult situations, and living a more purposeful and spiritually aligned life. It also emphasizes the importance of maintaining positive and elevating thoughts, as our mental state significantly influences our experiences and outcomes.

shlokas.name: Shloka 14
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अनन्यचेताः सततं यो मां स्मरति नित्यशः ।
तस्याहं सुलभः पार्थ नित्ययुक्तस्य योगिनः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: ananyacetāḥ satataṁ yo māṁ smarati nityaśaḥ tasyāhaṁ sulabhaḥ pārtha nityayuktasya yoginaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of unwavering devotion and constant remembrance of the Divine. It suggests that spiritual realization is not about complex rituals or practices, but about maintaining a continuous connection with the Supreme. The verse also implies that God is easily accessible to those who are sincerely devoted, breaking down the notion of God being distant or difficult to reach.
shlokas.meaning: For one who always remembers Me without deviation, I am easily attained, O Partha, because of his constant engagement in devotional service.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life by encouraging individuals to maintain focus on their goals or spiritual practices amidst distractions. It promotes the idea that consistency and dedication in any endeavor, be it personal, professional, or spiritual, leads to success. The verse also offers solace to those feeling distant from their spiritual path, assuring them that sincere effort and constant mindfulness can bridge any perceived gap.

shlokas.name: Shloka 15
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मामुपेत्य पुनर्जन्म दुःखालयमशाश्वतम् |
नाप्नुवन्ति महात्मानः संसिद्धिं परमां गताः ||
shlokas.transliteration: mām upetya punar janma duḥkhālayam aśāśvatam | nāpnuvanti mahātmānaḥ saṁsiddhiṁ paramāṁ gatāḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the ultimate goal of spiritual practice in Hinduism - liberation from the cycle of birth and death. It suggests that those who attain the highest realization by reaching Krishna do not have to return to the material world, which is characterized by impermanence and suffering. The verse implies that true spiritual perfection leads to a permanent state of bliss and freedom from worldly afflictions.
shlokas.meaning: Great souls who have attained the highest perfection by reaching Me do not take birth again in this temporary world of misery.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to pursue spiritual growth and self-realization as the ultimate solution to life's problems. It teaches that by focusing on spiritual practices, cultivating devotion, and striving for union with the Divine, one can overcome the cycle of suffering and attain lasting peace. In practical terms, this can motivate people to prioritize inner development over material pursuits, practice detachment from temporary pleasures, and seek meaning beyond worldly achievements.

shlokas.name: Shloka 16
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
आब्रह्मभुवनाल्लोकाः पुनरावर्तिनोऽर्जुन |
मामुपेत्य तु कौन्तेय पुनर्जन्म न विद्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration: ā-brahma-bhuvanāl lokāḥ punar āvartino 'rjuna | mām upetya tu kaunteya punar janma na vidyate ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the cyclical nature of existence within the material universe and contrasts it with the permanent liberation achieved by reaching Krishna. It emphasizes the impermanence of even the highest material realms and the supreme goal of attaining Krishna's eternal abode.
shlokas.meaning: All worlds, up to the realm of Brahma, are subject to rebirth, Arjuna. But upon reaching Me, O son of Kunti, there is no rebirth.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to seek spiritual growth and ultimate liberation rather than temporary material pleasures. It can motivate people to focus on long-term spiritual goals, practice detachment from worldly pursuits, and cultivate devotion to the Divine. This teaching can help in overcoming fear of death, finding purpose in life, and maintaining equanimity in the face of life's ups and downs.

shlokas.name: Shloka 17
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सहस्रयुगपर्यन्तमहर्यद्ब्रह्मणो विदुः ।
रात्रिं युगसहस्रान्तां तेऽहोरात्रविदो जनाः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: sahasra-yuga-paryantam ahar yad brahmano viduh ratrim yuga-sahasrantam te 'ho-ratra-vido janah
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of cosmic time scales, specifically Brahma's day and night. It emphasizes the vast difference between human perception of time and the cosmic reality. The verse suggests that our understanding of existence and the universe is limited, and there are greater cycles of creation and dissolution beyond our immediate comprehension.
shlokas.meaning: Those who understand the cosmic cycles know that Brahma's day lasts for a thousand yugas (ages), and his night also extends for a thousand yugas.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to broaden our perspective and think beyond our limited lifespan. It can help in dealing with immediate problems by reminding us of the vastness of existence, potentially reducing anxiety about short-term issues. It also promotes humility by highlighting the limitations of human understanding, encouraging continuous learning and spiritual growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 18
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अव्यक्ताद्व्यक्तय: सर्वा: प्रभवन्त्यहरागमे |
रात्र्यागमे प्रलीयन्ते तत्रैवाव्यक्तसंज्ञके ||
shlokas.transliteration: avyaktad vyaktayah sarvah prabhavantyaharagame | ratryagame praliyante tatraivavyaktasamjnake ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the cosmic cycle of creation and dissolution, emphasizing the eternal nature of existence. It illustrates how all manifested beings emerge from the unmanifest at the beginning of Brahma's day and dissolve back into the unmanifest at the onset of Brahma's night. This cycle represents the continuous process of evolution and involution in the universe, highlighting the impermanence of the manifest world and the eternal nature of the unmanifest.
shlokas.meaning: All manifested forms come forth from the unmanifest at the coming of the cosmic day, and at the coming of the cosmic night, they merge back into the same unmanifest.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand the transient nature of life and material possessions, encouraging detachment and acceptance of change. It teaches us to focus on the eternal, unchanging aspects of existence rather than temporary manifestations. This perspective can reduce anxiety about loss and change, promoting inner peace and resilience in facing life's ups and downs. It also inspires a broader, more cosmic view of existence, helping to put personal problems into perspective.

shlokas.name: Shloka 19
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
भूतग्रामः स एवायं भूत्वा भूत्वा प्रलीयते |
रात्र्यागमेऽवशः पार्थ प्रभवत्यहरागमे || 19||
shlokas.transliteration: bhūta-grāmaḥ sa evāyaṁ bhūtvā bhūtvā pralīyate rātry-āgame 'vaśaḥ pārtha prabhavaty ahar-āgame
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the cyclical nature of creation and dissolution in the universe. It emphasizes the concept of cosmic time and the impermanence of all material manifestations. The verse suggests that all beings are subject to the cosmic cycle of creation and destruction, which is beyond their control. This cycle is likened to the coming of day and night, symbolizing the eternal nature of existence and non-existence.
shlokas.meaning: The same multitude of beings repeatedly come into being at the arrival of the cosmic day and are inevitably dissolved at the arrival of the cosmic night, O Partha (Arjuna).
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand the transient nature of life and material possessions, encouraging detachment and acceptance of change. It can be applied to overcome fear of death, reduce attachment to worldly things, and develop a broader perspective on personal struggles. The teaching can also inspire people to make the most of their current existence while understanding that all things are part of a greater cosmic cycle.

shlokas.name: Shloka 20
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
परस्तस्मात्तु भावोऽन्योऽव्यक्तोऽव्यक्तात्सनातनः।
यः स सर्वेषु भूतेषु नश्यत्सु न विनश्यति॥
shlokas.transliteration: paras tasmāt tu bhāvo 'nyo 'vyakto 'vyaktāt sanātanaḥ | yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu naśyatsu na vinaśyati ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of the Supreme Eternal Reality that exists beyond the manifest and unmanifest states of material nature. It emphasizes the indestructible and eternal nature of the Supreme Being, which remains unaffected even when all other beings and forms in the universe are destroyed. This shloka points to the transcendental nature of the Ultimate Reality, which is beyond the cycle of creation and destruction that governs the material world.
shlokas.meaning: There is, however, another unmanifest reality, which is eternal and is transcendental to this manifested and unmanifested matter. It is supreme and is never annihilated. When all in this world is annihilated, that part remains as it is.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals develop a broader perspective on life and death. It encourages seeking a connection with the eternal, unchanging reality beyond the temporary material world. This knowledge can provide solace during times of loss or change, fostering resilience and inner peace. It also motivates spiritual seekers to look beyond the apparent reality and explore their true, eternal nature, potentially leading to reduced attachment to material possessions and increased focus on spiritual growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 21
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अव्यक्तोऽक्षर इत्युक्तस्तमाहुः परमां गतिम् ।
यं प्राप्य न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम ॥
shlokas.transliteration: avyakto 'kshara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṁ gatim yam prāpya na nivartante taddhāma paramaṁ mama
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the ultimate destination of the soul, which is the Supreme Abode of the Divine. It emphasizes the eternal and imperishable nature of this realm, which is beyond human perception and understanding. The verse suggests that once a soul reaches this state, it achieves liberation from the cycle of birth and death, attaining eternal union with the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: That which is described as the Unmanifest and Imperishable is said to be the supreme destination. Those who reach it do not return. That is My supreme abode.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to focus on spiritual growth and self-realization, reminding them of the ultimate goal of human existence. It can motivate people to look beyond material pursuits and temporary pleasures, inspiring them to cultivate virtues and practices that lead to spiritual evolution. In daily life, it can help in developing detachment from worldly outcomes and fostering a sense of inner peace and purpose.

shlokas.name: Shloka 22
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पुरुषः स परः पार्थ भक्त्या लभ्यस्त्वनन्यया |
यस्यान्तःस्थानि भूतानि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyastvananyayā | yasyāntaḥsthāni bhūtāni yena sarvamidaṁ tatam ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the supreme importance of devotion (bhakti) in realizing the Supreme Being. It suggests that the Ultimate Reality, which pervades all existence, can only be attained through unwavering and exclusive devotion. The shloka presents a holistic view of the Divine, describing it as both immanent (present within all beings) and transcendent (pervading everything).
shlokas.meaning: That Supreme Being, O Arjuna, is attainable by unswerving devotion. All beings exist within Him, and He pervades the entire universe.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to cultivate single-minded devotion to achieve spiritual realization. It teaches that by recognizing the divine presence in all things, one can develop a more compassionate and unified worldview. This understanding can help in overcoming ego, reducing conflicts, and fostering a sense of interconnectedness with all beings, leading to a more harmonious and purposeful life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 23
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यत्र काले त्वनावृत्तिमावृत्तिं चैव योगिन: ।
प्रयाता यान्ति तं कालं वक्ष्यामि भरतर्षभ ॥
shlokas.transliteration: yatra kāle tvanāvṛttim āvṛttiṁ caiva yoginaḥ prayātā yānti taṁ kālaṁ vakṣyāmi bharatarṣabha
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of different paths that yogis take after death, specifically referring to the timing of departure and its consequences. It emphasizes the importance of the moment of death in determining one's spiritual journey and suggests that there are specific times that lead to either liberation or rebirth. The verse also highlights Krishna's role as a teacher, preparing to impart crucial knowledge about these paths to Arjuna.
shlokas.meaning: O best of the Bharatas, I shall now explain to you the different times at which, passing away from this world, the yogi does or does not come back.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to live mindfully and spiritually at all times, as the moment of death is unpredictable. It teaches the importance of constant spiritual practice and maintaining awareness of the divine, so that one is prepared for the final moment. In daily life, this can translate to making conscious choices, living ethically, and cultivating a spiritual mindset to ensure that one's actions align with higher spiritual goals, regardless of when death may occur.

shlokas.name: Shloka 24
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अग्निर्ज्योतिरहः शुक्लः षण्मासा उत्तरायणम् |
तत्र प्रयाता गच्छन्ति ब्रह्म ब्रह्मविदो जनाः ||
shlokas.transliteration: agnirjyotirahah shuklah shanmasa uttarayanam | tatra prayata gacchanti brahma brahmavido janah ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the path of light, also known as the Devayana or the path of the gods. It outlines the auspicious time and conditions under which enlightened souls depart from this world to attain Brahman, the Ultimate Reality. The verse emphasizes the importance of the timing of death in relation to cosmic cycles and suggests that those who have realized Brahman follow this path to ultimate liberation.
shlokas.meaning: Those who know Brahman and depart in the light of fire, during the day, in the bright fortnight of the moon, and in the six months of the northern path of the sun, attain the Supreme.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to pursue spiritual knowledge and self-realization throughout their lives, rather than waiting for a specific time. It emphasizes the importance of constant spiritual practice and awareness, as one cannot predict the time of death. The teaching can motivate people to live righteously, cultivate wisdom, and maintain a positive mindset, preparing themselves for the ultimate journey at any moment.

shlokas.name: Shloka 25
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
धूमो रात्रिस्तथा कृष्णः षण्मासा दक्षिणायनम् |
तत्र चान्द्रमसं ज्योतिर्योगी प्राप्य निवर्तते ||
shlokas.transliteration: dhūmo rātristathā kṛṣṇaḥ ṣaṇmāsā dakṣiṇāyanam | tatra cāndramasaṁ jyotiryogī prāpya nivartate ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the path of gradual liberation known as the 'path of smoke' or 'path of darkness'. It represents a less direct route to spiritual realization, associated with worldly achievements and temporary heavenly pleasures. The verse suggests that yogis who depart during these less auspicious times return to the cycle of rebirth, implying the importance of timing and consciousness at the moment of death in determining one's spiritual journey.
shlokas.meaning: The path of smoke, night, the dark fortnight, and the six months of the southern solstice of the sun - the yogi who passes away by this path attains the lunar light and returns to earth.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to remain spiritually vigilant at all times, as the moment of death is uncertain. It teaches the importance of continuous spiritual practice and maintaining a higher state of consciousness. In daily life, it reminds us to make the most of our time, focusing on spiritual growth alongside worldly duties, and to approach our actions with awareness of their long-term spiritual consequences.

shlokas.name: Shloka 26
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
शुक्लकृष्णे गती ह्येते जगत: शाश्वते मते।
एकया यात्यनावृत्तिमन्ययावर्तते पुन:॥
shlokas.transliteration: śuklakṛṣṇe gatī hyete jagataḥ śāśvate mate | ekayā yātyanāvṛttim anyayāvartate punaḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the two paths of departure from the material world: the bright path (śukla gati) and the dark path (kṛṣṇa gati). The bright path leads to liberation and non-return, while the dark path results in rebirth. It emphasizes the importance of one's state of consciousness and actions at the time of death, as they determine the soul's journey after leaving the body.
shlokas.meaning: These two paths of the world, the bright and the dark, are considered eternal. By one, a person goes to non-return (liberation), and by the other, one returns again (to the material world).
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to live a life of spiritual awareness and righteous action. It teaches us to make conscious choices that align with higher spiritual goals, as these decisions impact our future beyond this lifetime. In daily life, it reminds us to cultivate positive thoughts, perform selfless actions, and maintain spiritual practices, as these lead to higher consciousness and ultimately to liberation from the cycle of birth and death.

shlokas.name: Shloka 27
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
नैते सृती पार्थ जानन्योगी मुह्यति कश्चन।
तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु योगयुक्तो भवार्जुन॥
shlokas.transliteration: naite sṛtī pārtha jānan yogī muhyati kaścana | tasmāt sarveṣu kāleṣu yogayukto bhavārjuna ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of spiritual knowledge and yoga practice. It suggests that a true yogi, armed with the understanding of the two paths (light and darkness), is never deluded. The verse encourages constant engagement in yoga, implying that spiritual awareness and practice lead to clarity and liberation from confusion in all circumstances.
shlokas.meaning: O Partha (Arjuna), the yogi who knows these two paths (of light and darkness) is never deluded. Therefore, O Arjuna, be steadfast in yoga at all times.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in daily life by encouraging individuals to cultivate spiritual awareness and maintain a consistent practice of self-reflection or meditation. It teaches that by developing a deep understanding of life's dualities and maintaining spiritual equilibrium, one can navigate through life's challenges with clarity and purpose, avoiding confusion and making wise decisions in all situations.

shlokas.name: Shloka 28
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
वेदेषु यज्ञेषु तपःसु चैव
दानेषु यत्पुण्यफलं प्रदिष्टम् ।
अत्येति तत्सर्वमिदं विदित्वा
योगी परं स्थानमुपैति चाद्यम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: vedeṣu yajñeṣu tapaḥsu caiva dāneṣu yat puṇyaphalaṁ pradiṣṭam atyeti tat sarvam idaṁ viditvā yogī paraṁ sthānam upaiti cādyam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the superiority of yoga and spiritual knowledge over ritualistic practices. It suggests that while Vedic rituals, sacrifices, austerities, and charitable acts yield merit, a yogi who understands the supreme truth transcends all these. The verse highlights the importance of direct spiritual realization over mere religious observances, indicating that true spiritual knowledge leads to the highest state of consciousness.
shlokas.meaning: The yogi who knows this truth goes beyond all the fruits of merit assigned to the study of the Vedas, performance of sacrifices, practice of austerities, and giving of charity. Such a yogi attains the supreme, primordial abode.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to look beyond external religious practices and focus on inner spiritual growth. It can be applied in daily life by prioritizing self-reflection, meditation, and the pursuit of higher knowledge over mere ritualistic observances. It teaches that true spiritual progress comes from understanding the essence of existence rather than following religious customs blindly. This approach can lead to a more meaningful and purposeful life, helping individuals to overcome stress, find inner peace, and achieve a higher state of consciousness in their everyday experiences.
