shlokas.name: Shloka 1
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
इदं तु ते गुह्यतमं प्रवक्ष्याम्यनसूयवे ।
ज्ञानं विज्ञानसहितं यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca idaṁ tu te guhyatamaṁ pravakṣyāmy anasūyave jñānaṁ vijñāna-sahitaṁ yaj jñātvā mokṣyase 'śubhāt
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks the beginning of Chapter 9, where Krishna introduces the most confidential knowledge to Arjuna. It emphasizes the importance of receiving wisdom with a non-envious attitude. Krishna promises to reveal both theoretical knowledge (jnana) and realized knowledge (vijnana), indicating a comprehensive understanding that goes beyond mere intellectual grasp. The verse also highlights the transformative power of this knowledge, capable of liberating one from all inauspiciousness.
shlokas.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: Because you are not envious, I shall impart to you this most confidential knowledge and wisdom, knowing which you shall be released from the miseries of material existence.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of approaching knowledge with humility and without envy. In daily life, we can apply this by being open-minded and receptive to new ideas and perspectives, especially from those more experienced or knowledgeable than us. It also emphasizes the value of both theoretical and practical knowledge in solving life's problems. By cultivating a non-envious attitude and seeking comprehensive understanding, we can gain insights that help us overcome personal struggles and achieve spiritual growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 2
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम् |
प्रत्यक्षावगमं धर्म्यं सुसुखं कर्तुमव्ययम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: rājavidyā rājaguhyaṁ pavitram idam uttamam pratyakṣāvagamaṁ dharmyaṁ susukhaṁ kartum avyayam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the supreme nature of spiritual knowledge, describing it as the king of all sciences and the most confidential of all secrets. It suggests that this knowledge is directly perceivable, in alignment with dharma (righteousness), and leads to eternal happiness. The verse implies that this spiritual wisdom is not just theoretical but can be practically experienced and applied in one's life, leading to lasting fulfillment.
shlokas.meaning: This knowledge is the king of education, the most secret of all secrets. It is the purest knowledge, and because it gives direct perception of the self by realization, it is the perfection of religion. It is everlasting, and it is joyfully performed.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to pursue spiritual knowledge as the highest form of education. It can be applied in daily life by prioritizing self-reflection and spiritual practices over mundane pursuits. By focusing on this supreme knowledge, one can find lasting happiness and purpose, overcome life's challenges with a broader perspective, and align one's actions with dharma or righteous living. This approach can lead to better decision-making, reduced stress, and a more fulfilling life overall.

shlokas.name: Shloka 3
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अश्रद्दधानाः पुरुषा धर्मस्यास्य परन्तप |
अप्राप्य मां निवर्तन्ते मृत्युसंसारवर्त्मनि ||
shlokas.transliteration: ashraddadhānāḥ puruṣā dharmasyāsya parantapa aprāpya māṁ nivartante mṛityu-saṁsāra-vartmani
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of faith (shraddha) in spiritual practice. It warns that those who lack faith in the teachings of Krishna (dharma) fail to attain the ultimate goal of self-realization. The cycle of birth and death (samsara) is described as a path of death, highlighting the urgency of spiritual awakening. The verse implies that faith is crucial for transcending material existence and reaching the divine.
shlokas.meaning: Those who lack faith in this dharma, O Arjuna, fail to attain Me and return to the path of rebirth and death in the material world.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied to cultivate perseverance and commitment in one's spiritual journey or personal growth. It encourages individuals to develop faith in their chosen path, whether spiritual or secular, to achieve their goals. In practical terms, it suggests that doubt and skepticism can hinder progress and keep one trapped in unproductive cycles. By fostering faith and dedication, one can overcome obstacles and achieve transformative results in various aspects of life, such as career, relationships, or personal development.

shlokas.name: Shloka 4
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मया ततमिदं सर्वं जगदव्यक्तमूर्तिना |
मत्स्थानि सर्वभूतानि न चाहं तेष्ववस्थितः ||
shlokas.transliteration: mayā tatam idaṁ sarvaṁ jagad avyakta-mūrtinā mat-sthāni sarva-bhūtāni na cāhaṁ teṣv avasthitaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse encapsulates the concept of God's omnipresence and transcendence. Krishna explains His relationship with the universe, emphasizing that He pervades all of creation while remaining distinct from it. This paradoxical nature of the Divine is a fundamental concept in Vedantic philosophy, illustrating the simultaneous immanence and transcendence of the Supreme Being.
shlokas.meaning: This entire universe is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest form. All beings exist within Me, but I am not contained within them.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals develop a broader perspective on life and their place in the universe. It encourages seeing the divine in all things while recognizing that the ultimate reality transcends physical manifestations. This can lead to greater respect for all forms of life, reduced ego, and a sense of interconnectedness, which can be applied in daily interactions, environmental consciousness, and personal spiritual practices.

shlokas.name: Shloka 5
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
न च मत्स्थानि भूतानि पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम् |
भूतभृन्न च भूतस्थो ममात्मा भूतभावनः ||
shlokas.transliteration: na ca mat-sthāni bhūtāni paśya me yogam aiśvaram | bhūta-bhṛn na ca bhūta-stho mamātmā bhūta-bhāvanaḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse reveals the paradoxical nature of Krishna's relationship with the universe. It emphasizes the concept of divine omnipresence while maintaining a distinct identity. Krishna explains His supreme yogic power, which allows Him to sustain all beings without being limited by them. This verse highlights the transcendental nature of the Supreme Being, who is simultaneously immanent and transcendent.
shlokas.meaning: All beings do not reside in Me, behold My divine yoga. I am the sustainer of all beings, yet I am not contained within them. My Self is the very source of all beings.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand the complex nature of reality and their relationship with the divine. It encourages a broader perspective on life, reminding us that we are supported by a higher power while maintaining our individuality. This understanding can lead to a sense of security and purpose, reducing anxiety about existence. It also inspires us to recognize the divine in all things while understanding that the divine transcends all manifestations, promoting respect for all life forms and the environment.

shlokas.name: Shloka 6
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यथाकाशस्थितो नित्यं वायुः सर्वत्रगो महान् |
तथा सर्वाणि भूतानि मत्स्थानीत्युपधारय ||
shlokas.transliteration: yathākāśasthito nityaṁ vāyuḥ sarvatrago mahān tathā sarvāṇi bhūtāni matsthānītyupadhāraya
shlokas.interpretation: This verse presents a profound analogy between the omnipresence of air within space and the existence of all beings within the Supreme. It illustrates the concept of divine immanence, suggesting that just as air pervades all of space without being bound by it, the Supreme Being permeates and sustains all of creation without being limited by it. This metaphor helps to explain the simultaneous transcendence and immanence of the Divine, a fundamental concept in Vedantic philosophy.
shlokas.meaning: As the mighty wind, blowing everywhere, rests always in the sky, know that in the same manner all beings rest in Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a sense of interconnectedness with all of existence, fostering compassion and respect for all life forms. It encourages a broader perspective on personal challenges, reminding us that we are part of a larger cosmic order. This understanding can reduce ego-centric thinking and promote a more harmonious approach to relationships and environmental stewardship. It also offers comfort in difficult times by emphasizing our constant connection to the divine, potentially alleviating feelings of isolation or meaninglessness.

shlokas.name: Shloka 7
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सर्वभूतानि कौन्तेय प्रकृतिं यान्ति मामिकाम् |
कल्पक्षये पुनस्तानि कल्पादौ विसृजाम्यहम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: sarvabhūtāni kaunteya prakṛtiṁ yānti māmikām kalpa-kṣaye punas tāni kalpādau visṛjāmy aham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse reveals the cyclical nature of creation and dissolution in the universe. It emphasizes Lord Krishna's role as the supreme controller who oversees these cosmic cycles. The shloka highlights the concept of prakriti (material nature) and its relationship with the Divine, suggesting that all beings are ultimately part of the Lord's nature and return to it at the end of each cosmic cycle, only to be manifested again at the beginning of the next.
shlokas.meaning: O son of Kunti, at the end of a cosmic cycle, all beings enter into My material nature, and at the beginning of the next cycle, I create them again.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand the impermanence of material existence and the eternal nature of the soul. It encourages detachment from worldly possessions and outcomes, as everything is part of a larger cosmic cycle. This perspective can aid in reducing stress and anxiety about temporary situations, promoting a more balanced and spiritual approach to life's challenges. It also instills a sense of humility and reverence for the divine order, encouraging individuals to align their actions with universal principles.

shlokas.name: Shloka 8
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
प्रकृतिं स्वामवष्टभ्य विसृजामि पुनः पुनः |
भूतग्राममिमं कृत्स्नमवशं प्रकृतेर्वशात् ||
shlokas.transliteration: prakṛtiṁ svām avaṣṭabhya visṛjāmi punaḥ punaḥ bhūtagrāmam imaṁ kṛtsnam avaśaṁ prakṛter vaśāt
shlokas.interpretation: This verse reveals the cyclical nature of creation and the divine role of Krishna in this process. It emphasizes the concept of prakriti (material nature) and how all beings are subject to its influence. Krishna, as the Supreme Being, oversees this process but remains detached from it, highlighting the interplay between the divine and the material world.
shlokas.meaning: Presiding over My material nature (prakriti), I create again and again the entire multitude of beings, which are helpless, being under the control of material nature.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand the impermanence of material existence and the power of natural laws. It encourages acceptance of life's cycles and challenges while promoting detachment from outcomes. In practical terms, it can guide people to focus on their actions (karma) rather than results, fostering resilience and equanimity in the face of life's ups and downs. It also prompts reflection on the balance between free will and the influence of external factors in shaping one's life journey.

shlokas.name: Shloka 9
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
न च मां तानि कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनंजय।
उदासीनवदासीनमसक्तं तेषु कर्मसु॥
shlokas.transliteration: na ca mām tāni karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanaṁjaya udāsīnavad āsīnam asaktaṁ teṣu karmasu
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of non-attachment and the transcendental nature of the Divine. It illustrates that the Supreme Being, while being the source of all actions, remains unaffected by them. This paradox of being involved yet detached is a key aspect of Krishna's divinity and serves as a model for human behavior in the material world.
shlokas.meaning: O Dhananjaya (Arjuna), I am not bound by any actions. I remain neutral and unattached to these actions, as if indifferent to them.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to perform our duties without being overly attached to the results. By adopting a mindset of detachment, we can reduce stress, anxiety, and disappointment in our daily lives. It encourages us to act with dedication and skill, but to remain emotionally unaffected by success or failure, thus maintaining inner peace and equanimity in all situations.

shlokas.name: Shloka 10
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मयाध्यक्षेण प्रकृति: सूयते सचराचरम् |
हेतुनानेन कौन्तेय जगद्विपरिवर्तते ||
shlokas.transliteration: mayādhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ sūyate sacarācaram | hetunānena kaunteya jagadviparivartate ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse reveals the cosmic order and the supreme control of the Divine. It emphasizes that while nature (Prakriti) operates, it does so under the supervision of the Supreme Being. This highlights the concept of divine governance in the universe, where even the most fundamental processes of creation and dissolution are overseen by a higher power. The verse also touches upon the cyclical nature of the universe, implying that the world goes through continuous cycles of creation and destruction under this divine supervision.
shlokas.meaning: Under My supervision, Nature (Prakriti) produces all things, animate and inanimate. Because of this, O son of Kunti, the universe revolves.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand their place in the grand scheme of things, fostering humility and a sense of purpose. It encourages one to recognize the divine order in all aspects of life, promoting acceptance of both favorable and unfavorable circumstances. In practical terms, it can inspire people to perform their duties diligently while acknowledging a higher power, leading to reduced stress and anxiety about outcomes. It also promotes environmental consciousness by emphasizing the divine nature of the world around us.

shlokas.name: Shloka 11
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अवजानन्ति मां मूढा मानुषीं तनुमाश्रितम् |
परं भावमजानन्तो मम भूतमहेश्वरम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: avajānanti māṁ mūḍhā mānuṣīṁ tanum āśritam paraṁ bhāvam ajānanto mama bhūta-maheśvaram
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the divine nature of Krishna and the ignorance of those who fail to recognize it. It emphasizes the concept of God incarnating in human form and the spiritual blindness that prevents people from perceiving the supreme reality behind the apparent physical manifestation. The shloka underscores the importance of spiritual wisdom and the ability to see beyond material appearances.
shlokas.meaning: Fools disregard Me when I descend in human form. They do not know My transcendental nature as the Supreme Lord of all beings.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to look beyond superficial appearances and seek deeper spiritual truths. In daily life, it encourages us to approach people and situations with an open mind, recognizing that there may be more than what meets the eye. It also reminds us to cultivate spiritual wisdom and discernment to recognize the divine in various forms around us, promoting respect and understanding in our interactions with others.

shlokas.name: Shloka 12
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मोघाशा मोघकर्माणो मोघज्ञाना विचेतसः।
राक्षसीमासुरीं चैव प्रकृतिं मोहिनीं श्रिताः॥
shlokas.transliteration: moghāśā moghakarmāṇo moghajñānā vicetasaḥ rākṣasīmāsurīṁ caiva prakṛtiṁ mohinīṁ śritāḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the nature of those who are deluded and have turned away from the divine. It emphasizes the futility of their aspirations, actions, and knowledge when they are not aligned with spiritual truth. The shloka suggests that such individuals, by embracing demonic qualities, are trapped in a cycle of delusion and ignorance, unable to perceive the higher reality of existence.
shlokas.meaning: Those of vain hopes, vain actions, vain knowledge, and devoid of discrimination, partake of the deluding nature of rakshasas and asuras.
shlokas.life_application: This verse serves as a warning against pursuing materialistic goals without spiritual awareness. It encourages self-reflection to identify and overcome deluding tendencies in one's life. By recognizing the futility of actions driven by ego and ignorance, individuals can redirect their efforts towards meaningful spiritual growth, cultivate true knowledge, and develop discernment in their choices and actions.

shlokas.name: Shloka 13
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
महात्मानस्तु मां पार्थ दैवीं प्रकृतिमाश्रिताः।
भजन्त्यनन्यमनसो ज्ञात्वा भूतादिमव्ययम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: mahātmānastu māṁ pārtha daivīṁ prakṛtimāśritāḥ bhajantyananyamanaso jñātvā bhūtādimavyayam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the characteristics of great souls (mahātmās) who have realized the divine nature of the Supreme. It emphasizes their unwavering devotion and complete surrender to the Divine, recognizing the Lord as the eternal source of all existence. The verse also implies the contrast between these enlightened beings and those still bound by material nature.
shlokas.meaning: O Partha (Arjuna), the great souls, taking shelter of My divine nature, worship Me with undivided minds, knowing Me as the imperishable source of all beings.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of cultivating a higher consciousness and aligning ourselves with divine qualities. It encourages us to develop unwavering focus in our spiritual practices, reminding us that true fulfillment comes from connecting with the eternal source. In daily life, we can apply this by striving to maintain a broader perspective, remaining steadfast in our principles, and dedicating our actions to a higher purpose, which can lead to greater inner peace and resilience in facing life's challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 14
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सततं कीर्तयन्तो मां यतन्तश्च दृढव्रताः |
नमस्यन्तश्च मां भक्त्या नित्ययुक्ता उपासते ||
shlokas.transliteration: satatam kirtayanto mam yatantas ca drdha-vratah namasyantas ca mam bhaktya nitya-yukta upasate
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the characteristics of true devotees who are constantly engaged in devotional service to Krishna. It emphasizes the importance of continuous practice, firm determination, and unwavering devotion in spiritual life. The verse highlights four key aspects of devotion: glorification, endeavor, reverence, and worship, all performed with steadfast dedication and love.
shlokas.meaning: Always chanting My glories, endeavoring with great determination, bowing down to Me, these great souls perpetually worship Me with devotion.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of consistency and dedication in our spiritual practices and personal growth. It encourages us to cultivate a habit of gratitude, perseverance in our goals, humility in our approach, and devotion in our actions. By applying these principles in daily life, one can develop resilience, maintain focus on important objectives, build stronger relationships, and find greater purpose and fulfillment.

shlokas.name: Shloka 15
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ज्ञानयज्ञेन चाप्यन्ये यजन्तो मामुपासते।
एकत्वेन पृथक्त्वेन बहुधा विश्वतोमुखम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: jñāna-yajñena cāpy anye yajanto mām upāsate ekatvena pṛthaktvena bahudhā viśvato-mukham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the diverse ways in which devotees approach and worship the Divine. It emphasizes that some seekers worship through the sacrifice of knowledge (jnana yajna), recognizing the Supreme in various forms - as one (non-dual), as separate (dualistic), or as manifested in multiple forms throughout the universe. This verse underscores the inclusivity and flexibility of spiritual paths in Hinduism, acknowledging that different individuals may have different approaches to understanding and connecting with the Divine, all of which are valid.
shlokas.meaning: Some worship Me through the sacrifice of knowledge, seeing Me as one, as separate, or as manifested in many forms throughout the universe.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages respect for diverse spiritual practices and beliefs. It teaches us to be open-minded and accepting of different philosophical viewpoints, fostering harmony in a pluralistic society. In personal spiritual growth, it inspires us to explore various approaches to understanding the Divine, allowing for a more comprehensive and nuanced spiritual journey. In conflict resolution, this verse reminds us that seemingly contradictory views can be different perspectives of the same truth, promoting tolerance and understanding.

shlokas.name: Shloka 16
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अहं क्रतुरहं यज्ञः स्वधाहमहमौषधम् ।
मन्त्रोऽहमहमेवाज्यमहमग्निरहं हुतम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: ahaṁ kratur ahaṁ yajñaḥ svadhāham aham auṣadham mantro 'ham aham evājyam aham agnir ahaṁ hutam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the all-pervasive nature of the Divine. Krishna declares Himself as the essence of all aspects of Vedic rituals and sacrifices, highlighting the omnipresence of the Supreme Being in every element of spiritual practice. It underscores the unity of all forms of worship and the ultimate reality behind diverse religious expressions.
shlokas.meaning: I am the ritual, I am the sacrifice, I am the offering, I am the medicinal herb, I am the sacred chant, I am the clarified butter, I am the fire, and I am the oblation.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to see the divine in all aspects of life, not just in formal religious practices. It encourages a holistic spiritual outlook, where every action can be seen as an offering to the Divine. This perspective can help in cultivating mindfulness, respect for all things, and a sense of unity with the universe, leading to a more harmonious and purposeful life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 17
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पिता'हमस्य जगतो माता धाता पितामहः ।
वेद्यं पवित्रमोंकार ऋक्साम यजुरेव च ॥
shlokas.transliteration: pitā'hamasya jagato mātā dhātā pitāmahaḥ | vedyaṁ pavitram oṁkāra ṛk sāma yajur eva ca ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of the Divine. Krishna declares Himself as the ultimate source and sustainer of the entire creation, embodying both masculine and feminine aspects. He is not only the immediate parent but also the grand-parent, highlighting His eternal nature. The verse also connects the Divine to sacred knowledge and purification, showing that spiritual wisdom and purity are inherent in the Supreme Being.
shlokas.meaning: I am the father of this universe, the mother, the support, and the grandsire. I am the object of knowledge, the purifier and the syllable Om. I am also the Rig, the Sama, and the Yajur Vedas.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a holistic perspective on life, recognizing the divine presence in all aspects of existence. It encourages respect for knowledge and purity, which can guide ethical decision-making. Understanding the interconnectedness of all things can foster a sense of responsibility towards the world and its inhabitants. The concept of divine parenthood can provide comfort during difficult times, reminding one of the ever-present support of the Supreme.

shlokas.name: Shloka 18
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
गतिर्भर्ता प्रभुः साक्षी निवासः शरणं सुहृत् ।
प्रभवः प्रलयः स्थानं निधानं बीजमव्ययम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: gatir bhartā prabhuḥ sākṣī nivāsaḥ śaraṇaṁ suhṛt prabhavaḥ pralayaḥ sthānaṁ nidhānaṁ bījam avyayam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of the Divine. It portrays the Supreme Being as the ultimate source and destination of all existence, highlighting the intimate relationship between the Divine and creation. The verse underscores the omnipresence and omnipotence of the Divine, suggesting that every aspect of existence is permeated by and dependent on the Supreme.
shlokas.meaning: I am the goal, the sustainer, the master, the witness, the abode, the refuge and the most dear friend. I am the creation and the annihilation, the basis of everything, the resting place and the eternal seed.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a sense of security and trust in the Divine, knowing that the Supreme is present in all aspects of life. It encourages seeking guidance and support from the Divine in times of difficulty, viewing challenges as part of a larger cosmic process. The teaching can also inspire people to cultivate a friendship with the Divine, fostering a sense of companionship and reducing feelings of loneliness or isolation. Moreover, it can motivate individuals to recognize the divine presence in all beings, promoting compassion and unity in their interactions with others.

shlokas.name: Shloka 19
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तपाम्यहमहं वर्षं निगृह्णाम्युत्सृजामि च |
अमृतं चैव मृत्युश्च सदसच्चाहमर्जुन ||
shlokas.transliteration: tapāmyahamahaṁ varṣaṁ nigṛhṇāmyutsṛjāmi ca | amṛtaṁ caiva mṛtyuśca sadasaccāhamarjuna ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of the Divine. Krishna reveals himself as the source of all natural phenomena and the ultimate controller of life and death. It illustrates the concept of God's immanence in every aspect of existence, from the most mundane to the most profound. The verse also touches on the philosophical idea of duality and non-duality, suggesting that the Divine transcends these apparent opposites.
shlokas.meaning: I give heat, I withhold and send forth the rain. I am immortality and death personified. I am the eternal and the temporal, O Arjuna.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a broader perspective on life's experiences. By recognizing the divine presence in all aspects of existence, one can cultivate acceptance and equanimity in the face of both positive and negative circumstances. It encourages us to see beyond surface-level dualities and find unity in diversity, which can lead to greater tolerance and understanding in personal relationships and society at large. Moreover, it reminds us of the impermanence of worldly phenomena, inspiring detachment and a focus on spiritual growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 20
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
त्रैविद्या मां सोमपा: पूतपापा
यज्ञैरिष्ट्वा स्वर्गतिं प्रार्थयन्ते |
ते पुण्यमासाद्य सुरेन्द्रलोक-
मश्नन्ति दिव्यान्दिवि देवभोगान् ||
shlokas.transliteration: traividyā māṁ somapāḥ pūtapāpā yajñairiṣṭvā svargatiṁ prārthayante | te puṇyamāsādya surendralokam aśnanti divyāndivi devabhogān ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the limitations of ritualistic worship and the pursuit of temporary heavenly pleasures. It suggests that those who perform Vedic rituals with the aim of gaining celestial rewards are still bound by the cycle of karma and rebirth. Krishna implies that such actions, while not inherently wrong, fall short of the ultimate goal of spiritual realization and union with the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: Those who study the three Vedas, drink the soma juice, and are purified of sin, worship Me through sacrifices and pray for passage to heaven. As a result of their pious activities, they attain the realm of Indra and enjoy celestial pleasures in heaven.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to examine our motivations in spiritual practices. It encourages us to look beyond short-term gains and material rewards in our spiritual journey. Instead of focusing on temporary pleasures or status, we should aim for lasting spiritual growth and self-realization. In daily life, this principle can be applied by prioritizing long-term personal development over quick fixes or temporary solutions, and by cultivating a deeper understanding of our actions and their consequences.

shlokas.name: Shloka 21
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ते तं भुक्त्वा स्वर्गलोकं विशालं
क्षीणे पुण्ये मर्त्यलोकं विशन्ति।
एवं त्रयीधर्ममनुप्रपन्ना
गतागतं कामकामा लभन्ते॥
shlokas.transliteration: te taṁ bhuktvā svarga-lokaṁ viśālaṁ kṣīṇe puṇye martya-lokaṁ viśanti evaṁ trayī-dharmam anuprapannā gatāgataṁ kāma-kāmā labhante
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the cyclical nature of karma and the temporary nature of heavenly pleasures. It emphasizes that actions performed with desire for rewards lead to a continuous cycle of birth and death. The verse indirectly encourages seekers to aim for liberation (moksha) rather than temporary celestial enjoyments.
shlokas.meaning: Having enjoyed the vast heavenly realm, they return to the mortal world when their merit is exhausted. Thus, those who follow the rituals of the three Vedas, seeking desires, repeatedly come and go.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to focus on long-term spiritual growth rather than short-term pleasures. In daily life, it encourages us to make choices based on lasting values and inner growth, rather than temporary gains or sensory satisfactions. It also reminds us that actions driven by desire for rewards will keep us bound in cycles of temporary happiness and inevitable disappointment, urging us to cultivate detachment and seek higher spiritual goals.

shlokas.name: Shloka 22
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते।
तेषां नित्याभियुक्तानां योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: ananyāścintayanto māṁ ye janāḥ paryupāsate | teṣāṁ nityābhiyuktānāṁ yogakṣemaṁ vahāmyaham ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of unwavering devotion and complete surrender to the Divine. It suggests that those who focus their thoughts entirely on God, without any distractions or divided loyalties, receive special care and protection. The Lord personally takes responsibility for the well-being of such devotees, both in terms of their spiritual progress (yoga) and material needs (kshema). This verse is often seen as a powerful assurance of divine grace and protection for sincere devotees.
shlokas.meaning: For those who worship Me alone, thinking of no other, for those ever-united souls, I secure what they lack and preserve what they already possess.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in daily life to cultivate trust in a higher power and reduce anxiety about worldly concerns. It encourages individuals to focus on their spiritual growth and duties while having faith that their essential needs will be met. This teaching can help in managing stress, overcoming fear of scarcity, and developing a more balanced approach to material pursuits. It also promotes the idea of living in the present moment with complete dedication to one's chosen path or duty, trusting that sincere efforts will be supported by the universe or divine forces.

shlokas.name: Shloka 23
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ये त्वन्यदेवता भक्ता यजन्ते श्रद्धयान्विताः ।
तेऽपि मामेव कौन्तेय यजन्त्यविधिपूर्वकम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: ye tv anya-devatā-bhaktā yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ te 'pi mām eva kaunteya yajanty avidhi-pūrvakam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the inclusive nature of Krishna's teachings, emphasizing that all forms of worship, even those directed towards other deities, ultimately reach Him. It underscores the unity of divine consciousness and the idea that there are many paths to the same ultimate truth. Krishna acknowledges the sincerity of devotees who worship other gods, suggesting that their devotion, though not directly aimed at Him, still reaches Him indirectly.
shlokas.meaning: Those who are devotees of other gods and who worship them with faith actually worship Me alone, O son of Kunti, albeit in an improper way.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to respect and tolerate different religious beliefs and practices. It encourages us to look beyond superficial differences in worship and recognize the underlying unity in all spiritual pursuits. In daily life, this can be applied by fostering interfaith dialogue, practicing religious tolerance, and understanding that different cultural and spiritual practices can lead to the same ultimate goal of self-realization and connection with the divine.

shlokas.name: Shloka 24
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अहं हि सर्वयज्ञानां भोक्ता च प्रभुरेव च।
न तु मामभिजानन्ति तत्त्वेनातश्च्यवन्ति ते॥
shlokas.transliteration: ahaṁ hi sarvayajñānāṁ bhoktā ca prabhureva ca | na tu māmabhijānanti tattvenātaścyavanti te ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the supreme position of Krishna as the ultimate recipient and lord of all sacrifices. It highlights the importance of recognizing the divine nature of Krishna in spiritual practices. The verse also points out the consequence of failing to understand this truth, which leads to the cycle of rebirth and suffering.
shlokas.meaning: I am the enjoyer and the lord of all sacrifices. But those who do not recognize My true nature fall from the path of spiritual progress.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching encourages individuals to perform their duties and rituals with the right understanding and attitude. It emphasizes the importance of dedicating one's actions to the Divine, which can lead to a more purposeful and spiritually fulfilling life. By recognizing the supreme nature of the Divine in all aspects of life, one can overcome ego, reduce attachment to results, and find greater peace and contentment in daily activities.

shlokas.name: Shloka 25
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यान्ति देवव्रता देवान् पितॄन्यान्ति पितृव्रताः ।
भूतानि यान्ति भूतेज्या यान्ति मद्याजिनोऽपि माम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: yānti devavratā devān pitṝnyānti pitṛvratāḥ bhūtāni yānti bhūtejyā yānti madyājino'pi mām
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the principle of spiritual reciprocity and the law of karma. It illustrates that one's devotional focus and worship determine their spiritual destination. The shloka underscores the importance of one's chosen path of devotion and how it aligns with their ultimate spiritual goal. It also subtly hints at the superiority of devotion to Krishna (the speaker) as the path to the highest spiritual attainment.
shlokas.meaning: Those who worship the devas go to the devas; those who worship the ancestors go to the ancestors; those who worship the spirits go to the spirits; and those who worship Me come to Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can guide individuals in choosing their spiritual path wisely, understanding that their focus and devotion shape their spiritual journey and ultimate destination. It encourages self-reflection on one's spiritual practices and goals. In practical terms, it teaches that our thoughts, actions, and devotions should align with our highest aspirations, whether in spiritual pursuits or worldly endeavors. This principle can be applied in career choices, relationship building, and personal development, reminding us that our consistent efforts and focus in any area of life will yield corresponding results.

shlokas.name: Shloka 26
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति |
तदहं भक्त्युपहृतमश्नामि प्रयतात्मन: ||
shlokas.transliteration: patram pushpam phalam toyam yo me bhaktya prayacchati | tadaham bhaktyupahritam ashnami prayatatmanah ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of devotion and sincerity in offering to the Divine. It suggests that the act of offering is more significant than the material value of the offering itself. The verse illustrates the accessibility of the Divine to all, regardless of their material possessions or social status. It also highlights the reciprocal nature of the devotee-Divine relationship, where genuine devotion is met with divine acceptance and grace.
shlokas.meaning: If one offers Me with love and devotion a leaf, a flower, fruit or water, I will accept it. I partake of that offering of love from the pure-hearted devotee.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life by emphasizing the importance of intention and sincerity in our actions, rather than their grandeur or material value. It encourages us to approach our work, relationships, and spiritual practices with genuine love and devotion. This verse also teaches us to value and appreciate even the smallest acts of kindness or offerings from others, focusing on the sentiment behind the act rather than its material worth. It can help in cultivating gratitude, humility, and a non-judgmental attitude towards others' expressions of love or respect.

shlokas.name: Shloka 27
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यत्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत् ।
यत्तपस्यसि कौन्तेय तत्कुरुष्व मदर्पणम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: yat karosi yad asnasi yaj juhosi dadasi yat yat tapasyasi kaunteya tat kurusva mad-arpanam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse encapsulates the essence of Karma Yoga, emphasizing the importance of dedicating all actions to the Divine. It suggests that every aspect of life, from the mundane to the spiritual, can be transformed into an act of worship when performed with the right attitude. This teaching encourages a holistic approach to spirituality, integrating it into daily life rather than separating it as a distinct activity.
shlokas.meaning: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give away, and whatever austerities you perform – do all of that as an offering to Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied to cultivate mindfulness and purpose in daily life. By viewing all actions as offerings to the Divine, one can find deeper meaning in work, relationships, and personal habits. It can help in overcoming stress and dissatisfaction by shifting focus from personal gain to a higher purpose. This approach can lead to greater contentment, reduced ego, and a more harmonious life by aligning one's actions with spiritual values.

shlokas.name: Shloka 28
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
शुभाशुभफलैरेवं मोक्ष्यसे कर्मबन्धनैः ।
संन्यासयोगयुक्तात्मा विमुक्तो मामुपैष्यसि ॥
shlokas.transliteration: śubhāśubhaphalair evaṁ mokṣyase karmabandhanaiḥ | sannyāsayogayuktātmā vimukto mām upaiṣyasi ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of detachment from the fruits of one's actions. It suggests that by performing actions with a spirit of renunciation and dedicating them to the Divine, one can break free from the cycle of karma. The verse also highlights the ultimate goal of spiritual practice: to attain union with the Supreme Being.
shlokas.meaning: Thus, you shall be freed from the bondage of actions that yield good and bad results. With your mind firmly set on the yoga of renunciation, and liberated, you shall come to Me.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life by encouraging individuals to perform their duties without being overly attached to the outcomes. It promotes a mindset of working for the greater good rather than personal gain, which can reduce stress and anxiety related to results. By focusing on the action itself and dedicating it to a higher purpose, one can find more fulfillment in work and relationships, leading to a more balanced and peaceful life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 29
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
समोऽहं सर्वभूतेषु न मे द्वेष्योऽस्ति न प्रियः।
ये भजन्ति तु मां भक्त्या मयि ते तेषु चाप्यहम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: samo'haṁ sarvabhūteṣu na me dveṣyo'sti na priyaḥ ye bhajanti tu māṁ bhaktyā mayi te teṣu cāpyaham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the impartial nature of the Divine and introduces the concept of reciprocal devotion. It highlights that while God treats all beings equally, those who approach with sincere devotion receive special attention. This doesn't contradict God's impartiality but illustrates the power of bhakti (devotion) in forging a deeper connection with the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: I am equally disposed to all beings; I hate none nor have I any favorites. However, those who worship Me with devotion, they are in Me, and I am in them.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to cultivate impartiality and equal respect for all beings in our daily interactions. It encourages developing a loving, devotional attitude towards life and work, which can lead to a deeper sense of connection and fulfillment. In challenging relationships, it reminds us to maintain equanimity while also inspiring us to forge deeper connections through sincere dedication and love.

shlokas.name: Shloka 30
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अपि चेत्सुदुराचारो भजते मामनन्यभाक् |
साधुरेव स मन्तव्यः सम्यग्व्यवसितो हि सः ||
shlokas.transliteration: api cet sudurācāro bhajate mām ananya-bhāk | sādhur eva sa mantavyaḥ samyag vyavasito hi saḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the transformative power of devotion and the importance of one's current actions over past misdeeds. It suggests that even a person with a history of wrongdoing can be considered righteous if they wholeheartedly devote themselves to God. This teaches the concepts of redemption, the power of present choices, and the supremacy of devotion in spiritual life.
shlokas.meaning: Even if a person of very bad conduct worships Me with exclusive devotion, he should be regarded as righteous because he has rightly resolved.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in situations where one needs to overcome past mistakes or judge others fairly. It encourages forgiveness, both of oneself and others, and emphasizes the importance of current choices over past actions. In personal development, it motivates individuals to make positive changes regardless of their history. In leadership and social contexts, it promotes giving second chances and valuing a person's present commitment over their past reputation.

shlokas.name: Shloka 31
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
क्षिप्रं भवति धर्मात्मा शश्वच्छान्तिं निगच्छति |
कौन्तेय प्रतिजानीहि न मे भक्त: प्रणश्यति ||
shlokas.transliteration: kṣipraṁ bhavati dharmātmā śaśvac-chāntiṁ nigacchati | kaunteya pratijānīhi na me bhaktaḥ praṇaśyati ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the transformative power of devotion and the unwavering protection Krishna offers to his devotees. It highlights the swift spiritual progress one can make through sincere devotion, assuring that even those who have committed wrongs can quickly become righteous and find lasting peace. The verse serves as a powerful promise from Krishna, emphasizing the infallible nature of devotional service.
shlokas.meaning: He quickly becomes righteous and attains lasting peace. O son of Kunti, declare it boldly that My devotee never perishes.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied to overcome feelings of guilt, unworthiness, or hopelessness in one's spiritual journey. It encourages perseverance in devotional practices, assuring that sincere efforts lead to positive transformation. It can also be used to cultivate faith and trust in the divine, helping individuals face life's challenges with confidence and inner peace.

shlokas.name: Shloka 32
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मां हि पार्थ व्यपाश्रित्य येऽपि स्युः पापयोनयः ।
स्त्रियो वैश्यास्तथा शूद्रास्तेऽपि यान्ति परां गतिम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: mām hi pārtha vyapāśritya ye'pi syuḥ pāpayonayaḥ | striyo vaiśyās tathā śūdrās te'pi yānti parāṃ gatim ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the universal accessibility of spiritual liberation, regardless of social status, gender, or birth. Krishna assures Arjuna that even those considered 'low-born' or traditionally excluded from spiritual practices can attain the highest spiritual goal through devotion to Him. This teaching challenges the rigid caste system and gender discrimination prevalent in ancient Indian society, promoting a more inclusive and egalitarian approach to spirituality.
shlokas.meaning: O Partha (Arjuna), even those who are born of sinful origins, women, vaishyas (merchants), and shudras (laborers) can attain the supreme destination by taking refuge in Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied to promote social equality and combat discrimination in modern society. It teaches that spiritual growth and self-realization are available to all, regardless of social background, gender, or occupation. This principle can inspire individuals to pursue their spiritual goals without feeling limited by their circumstances, and encourage communities to be more inclusive and supportive of all members in their spiritual journeys.

shlokas.name: Shloka 33
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
किं पुनर्ब्राह्मणाः पुण्या भक्ता राजर्षयस्तथा |
अनित्यमसुखं लोकमिमं प्राप्य भजस्व माम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: kiṁ punar brāhmaṇāḥ puṇyā bhaktā rājarṣayas tathā anityam asukhaṁ lokam imaṁ prāpya bhajasva mām
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of devotion to Krishna, regardless of one's social status or background. It suggests that if even the most revered members of society should worship Krishna, then it is even more imperative for ordinary individuals to do so. The verse also highlights the transient and unsatisfactory nature of the material world, urging seekers to turn towards the divine for true fulfillment.
shlokas.meaning: How much more so then, the righteous Brahmins and devoted royal sages. Having come to this temporary, miserable world, engage in loving service unto Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied to overcome feelings of unworthiness or social barriers in spiritual practice. It encourages individuals to pursue spiritual growth regardless of their background or current life circumstances. It also serves as a reminder to seek lasting happiness through spiritual means rather than temporary material pursuits, helping to prioritize one's life goals and find inner peace amidst worldly challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 34
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु।
मामेवैष्यसि युक्त्वैवमात्मानं मत्परायणः॥
shlokas.transliteration: manmanā bhava madbhakto madyājī māṁ namaskuru | mām evaiṣyasi yuktvaivam ātmānaṁ matparāyaṇaḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse is considered one of the most important in the Bhagavad Gita, as it encapsulates the essence of Krishna's teachings. It emphasizes the importance of complete surrender and devotion to the Divine. Krishna instructs Arjuna to focus his mind on Him, become His devotee, worship Him, and offer obeisance to Him. By doing so, one can unite their consciousness with the Divine and ultimately attain Him. This verse highlights the path of Bhakti Yoga (devotional service) as a means to spiritual realization and liberation.
shlokas.meaning: Fix your mind on Me, be devoted to Me, worship Me, and bow down to Me. Thus uniting yourself with Me and regarding Me as the supreme goal, you shall come to Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in daily life to find focus, purpose, and inner peace. By directing one's thoughts and actions towards a higher ideal or purpose (represented by Krishna), individuals can overcome stress, anxiety, and confusion. Regular meditation, selfless service, and cultivating devotion can help in aligning one's life with higher principles. This practice can lead to improved mental clarity, emotional stability, and a sense of fulfillment. In practical terms, it encourages setting a noble goal and dedicating one's actions towards it, which can be beneficial in personal and professional life.
