shlokas.name: Shloka 1
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
भूय एव महाबाहो शृणु मे परमं वचः।
यत्तेऽहं प्रीयमाणाय वक्ष्यामि हितकाम्यया॥
shlokas.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca bhūya eva mahā-bāho śṛṇu me paramaṁ vacaḥ yat te 'haṁ prīyamāṇāya vakṣyāmi hita-kāmyayā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks the beginning of Chapter 10, where Lord Krishna continues to reveal His divine glories. He emphasizes the importance of what He's about to say, indicating that the following teachings are of paramount significance. The use of 'bhūya eva' (once again) suggests that Krishna is reiterating and expanding upon previously discussed concepts, highlighting their importance. His address to Arjuna as 'mahā-bāho' (mighty-armed one) is both affectionate and acknowledging of Arjuna's strength, preparing him for the profound wisdom to follow.
shlokas.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: Listen again, O mighty-armed Arjuna, to My supreme word, which I shall impart to you for your benefit and which will give you great joy.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of being receptive to wisdom, especially when it comes from a trusted and knowledgeable source. It encourages us to approach learning with enthusiasm and an open mind, recognizing that repeated exposure to profound ideas can lead to deeper understanding. In daily life, this can be applied by actively seeking out knowledge, being willing to listen to advice, and understanding that personal growth often comes through revisiting and deepening our understanding of fundamental truths.

shlokas.name: Shloka 2
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
न मे विदुः सुरगणाः प्रभवं न महर्षयः।
अहमादिर्हि देवानां महर्षीणां च सर्वशः॥
shlokas.transliteration: na me viduḥ suragaṇāḥ prabhavaṁ na maharṣayaḥ aham ādir hi devānāṁ maharṣīṇāṁ ca sarvaśaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes Krishna's supreme position as the source of all existence. It highlights the transcendental nature of the Divine, which surpasses even the understanding of celestial beings and great sages. Krishna asserts His primordial status, indicating that He is the origin of both the cosmic forces (devas) and the embodiments of wisdom (maharishis). This reinforces the concept of God as the ultimate cause and sustainer of all creation, beyond the comprehension of even the most elevated beings.
shlokas.meaning: Neither the hosts of demigods nor the great sages know My origin, for I am the source of all the demigods and sages in every respect.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages humility and continuous spiritual seeking. It reminds us that there are always higher truths beyond our current understanding, promoting a lifelong journey of learning and self-improvement. In practical terms, it can help individuals approach complex life situations with openness and curiosity, recognizing that our knowledge is limited and there's always more to learn. It also inspires reverence for the divine and the mysteries of existence, fostering a sense of wonder and respect for the universe and its workings.

shlokas.name: Shloka 3
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यो मामजमनादिं च वेत्ति लोकमहेश्वरम् |
असम्मूढः स मर्त्येषु सर्वपापैः प्रमुच्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration: yo mām ajam anādiṁ ca vetti loka-maheśvaram | asammūḍhaḥ sa martyeṣu sarva-pāpaiḥ pramucyate ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of understanding Krishna's divine nature. It suggests that true knowledge of God's eternal and supreme status leads to spiritual clarity and liberation from karmic bondage. The verse implies that such understanding is rare among mortals and those who attain it are elevated above ordinary human consciousness.
shlokas.meaning: He who knows Me as unborn and beginningless, as the great Lord of the worlds, he, among mortals, is undeluded and freed from all sins.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life by encouraging individuals to seek deeper spiritual understanding, which can lead to mental clarity and ethical living. By recognizing a higher power or universal principle, one can gain perspective on life's challenges, make more conscious decisions, and strive for moral purity. This understanding can help in overcoming guilt, fear, and confusion, leading to a more purposeful and peaceful existence.

shlokas.name: Shloka 4
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
बुद्धिर्ज्ञानमसंमोहः क्षमा सत्यं दमः शमः |
सुखं दुःखं भवोऽभावो भयं चाभयमेव च ||
shlokas.transliteration: buddhir jñānam asammohaḥ kṣamā satyaṁ damaḥ śamaḥ sukhaṁ duḥkhaṁ bhavo 'bhāvo bhayaṁ cābhayam eva ca
shlokas.interpretation: This verse enumerates various qualities and states of existence, both positive and negative, that originate from the Divine. It emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of the Supreme Being, highlighting that all aspects of human experience and consciousness are rooted in the divine source. The verse suggests that understanding these qualities as manifestations of the Divine can lead to a deeper spiritual awareness and connection with the ultimate reality.
shlokas.meaning: Intelligence, knowledge, freedom from delusion, forgiveness, truthfulness, self-control, calmness, happiness, distress, birth, death, fear, and fearlessness – all these various qualities of living beings originate from Me alone.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to recognize the divine origin of all experiences and qualities, both positive and negative. By understanding this, one can develop a more balanced and accepting approach to life's ups and downs. It teaches us to cultivate positive qualities like intelligence, knowledge, and self-control while also accepting and learning from challenging experiences. This perspective can help in managing stress, overcoming fear, and maintaining equanimity in the face of life's dualities.

shlokas.name: Shloka 5
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अहिंसा समता तुष्टिस्तपो दानं यशोऽयशः ।
भवन्ति भावा भूतानां मत्त एव पृथग्विधाः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: ahiṁsā samatā tuṣṭis tapo dānaṁ yaśo'yaśaḥ bhavanti bhāvā bhūtānāṁ matta eva pṛthagvidhāḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the divine origin of all qualities and states of being in living entities. It suggests that both positive and negative attributes, as well as neutral states, all stem from the Supreme Being. This reinforces the concept of God's omnipresence and the interconnectedness of all existence.
shlokas.meaning: Non-violence, equanimity, contentment, austerity, charity, fame, and infamy - these diverse qualities in living beings arise from Me alone.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding that all qualities, both positive and negative, originate from the divine can help individuals develop a more balanced and accepting view of themselves and others. It encourages non-judgment, as one realizes that everyone's nature is a manifestation of the divine. This perspective can lead to greater compassion, self-acceptance, and a reduction in ego-driven behaviors, ultimately fostering personal growth and harmonious relationships.

shlokas.name: Shloka 6
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
महर्षयः सप्त पूर्वे चत्वारो मनवस्तथा |
मद्भावा मानसा जाता येषां लोक इमाः प्रजाः ||
shlokas.transliteration: maharṣayaḥ sapta pūrve catvāro manavas tathā | madbhāvā mānasā jātā yeṣāṁ loka imāḥ prajāḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the divine origin of great sages and progenitors of humanity. It emphasizes Krishna's role as the ultimate source of creation, wisdom, and spiritual lineage. The mention of seven great sages and four Manus underscores the ancient and revered tradition of spiritual knowledge in Hinduism, all emanating from the Supreme Being.
shlokas.meaning: The seven great sages, the four ancient Manus, and all other beings in this world are born from My mind and possess My divine essence. From them, all the people in the various planets have come into being.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to recognize the divine essence within ourselves and others, promoting respect and unity. It reminds us of our spiritual heritage and the importance of seeking wisdom from enlightened sources. In daily life, it can inspire us to cultivate our innate divine qualities, respect diverse spiritual traditions, and strive for harmony with the cosmic order in our actions and decisions.

shlokas.name: Shloka 7
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
एतां विभूतिं योगं च मम यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः |
सोऽविकम्पेन योगेन युज्यते नात्र संशयः ||
shlokas.transliteration: etāṁ vibhūtiṁ yogaṁ ca mama yo vetti tattvataḥ | so'vikampena yogena yujyate nātra saṁśayaḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of understanding Krishna's divine manifestations and His yoga (divine power) in their true essence. It suggests that such profound knowledge leads to unwavering devotion and union with the Divine. The verse implies that true spiritual knowledge is transformative, leading to a state of unshakeable faith and connection with the Supreme.
shlokas.meaning: One who truly understands My divine manifestations and yoga in essence becomes united with Me through unwavering devotional service. Of this, there is no doubt.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in life to cultivate deeper spiritual understanding and unwavering faith. By studying and contemplating the various manifestations of the Divine in the world around us, we can develop a stronger connection to the Supreme. This understanding can help in facing life's challenges with equanimity, making decisions aligned with higher principles, and finding purpose and direction in life. It encourages us to seek knowledge not just intellectually, but to internalize it in a way that transforms our consciousness and daily actions.

shlokas.name: Shloka 8
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अहं सर्वस्य प्रभवो मत्त: सर्वं प्रवर्तते |
इति मत्वा भजन्ते मां बुधा भावसमन्विता: ||
shlokas.transliteration: ahaṁ sarvasya prabhavo mattaḥ sarvaṁ pravartate | iti matvā bhajante māṁ budhā bhāvasamanvitāḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse encapsulates the essence of Krishna's divine supremacy. It establishes Him as the ultimate source of all existence and the prime mover of all actions in the universe. Krishna emphasizes that those who truly understand this fundamental truth engage in His devotional service with deep emotional connection. This realization leads to a profound shift in perspective, where one sees the divine in everything and recognizes the interconnectedness of all creation.
shlokas.meaning: I am the source of all spiritual and material worlds. Everything emanates from Me. The wise who perfectly know this engage in My devotional service and worship Me with all their hearts.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals develop a sense of reverence for all life and the world around them, recognizing the divine essence in everything. It encourages a holistic approach to problem-solving, considering the interconnectedness of all things. This perspective can lead to more compassionate and mindful decision-making in daily life, fostering a sense of unity and reducing ego-driven conflicts. It also provides a foundation for developing unwavering faith and devotion, which can be a source of strength and resilience in facing life's challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 9
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मच्चित्ता मद्गतप्राणा बोधयन्तः परस्परम् |
कथयन्तश्च मां नित्यं तुष्यन्ति च रमन्ति च ||
shlokas.transliteration: mac-cittā mad-gata-prāṇā bodhayantaḥ parasparam kathayantaś ca māṁ nityaṁ tuṣyanti ca ramanti ca
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the characteristics and behavior of true devotees of Krishna. It emphasizes the importance of constant remembrance, mutual enlightenment, and the joy derived from discussing the divine. The shloka highlights the concept of bhakti yoga, where devotees find ultimate satisfaction in dedicating their thoughts, life force, and actions to the Supreme Being.
shlokas.meaning: With their minds fixed on Me, their lives surrendered to Me, enlightening one another and constantly talking about Me, My devotees derive great satisfaction and delight.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of surrounding ourselves with like-minded individuals who share our spiritual goals. It encourages us to engage in regular spiritual discussions and practices, which can lead to greater understanding, joy, and fulfillment in life. By focusing our thoughts and actions on higher principles, we can find deeper meaning and satisfaction in our daily lives, overcoming stress, anxiety, and feelings of emptiness.

shlokas.name: Shloka 10
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तेषां सततयुक्तानां भजतां प्रीतिपूर्वकम् ।
ददामि बुद्धियोगं तं येन मामुपयान्ति ते ॥
shlokas.transliteration: teṣāṁ satata-yuktānāṁ bhajatāṁ prīti-pūrvakam dadāmi buddhi-yogaṁ taṁ yena mām upayānti te
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the reciprocal nature of devotion and divine grace. It suggests that consistent, loving devotion to the Divine is rewarded with spiritual wisdom. The Lord promises to bestow 'buddhi-yoga' or the yoga of intellect, which is the discriminative faculty that leads to spiritual realization. This highlights the importance of both devotion and knowledge in spiritual progress.
shlokas.meaning: To those who are constantly devoted and worship Me with love, I give the understanding by which they can come to Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in daily life by cultivating a consistent practice of devotion or mindfulness. It encourages maintaining a positive, loving attitude in one's spiritual practices. It also suggests that persistent effort in any field, coupled with the right attitude, can lead to deeper understanding and success. In problem-solving, it implies that approaching challenges with dedication and a positive mindset can lead to innovative solutions and personal growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 11
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तेषामेवानुकम्पार्थमहमज्ञानजं तम: |
नाशयाम्यात्मभावस्थो ज्ञानदीपेन भास्वता ||
shlokas.transliteration: teṣām evānukampārtham aham ajñānajaṁ tamaḥ nāśayāmy ātmabhāvastho jñānadīpena bhāsvatā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse illustrates the compassionate nature of the Divine and the transformative power of spiritual knowledge. It suggests that the Supreme Being, out of pure compassion, actively helps sincere devotees overcome their ignorance. The imagery of a radiant lamp dispelling darkness symbolizes how divine wisdom illuminates the mind, removing doubts and misconceptions. This verse also emphasizes the intimate relationship between the devotee and the Divine, as the latter resides within the heart of the seeker.
shlokas.meaning: Out of compassion for them, I, dwelling in their hearts, destroy the darkness born of ignorance with the radiant lamp of knowledge.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in various life situations where one feels stuck or confused. It encourages seeking knowledge and wisdom to overcome personal limitations and ignorance. In times of doubt or difficulty, one can turn inward, cultivating self-awareness and seeking higher understanding. This verse also inspires compassion towards others who may be struggling with ignorance, encouraging us to share knowledge and help others grow. In leadership roles, it reminds us to lead with wisdom and compassion, helping team members overcome their limitations through guidance and support.

shlokas.name: Shloka 12
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
परं ब्रह्म परं धाम पवित्रं परमं भवान् |
पुरुषं शाश्वतं दिव्यमादिदेवमजं विभुम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: paraṁ brahma paraṁ dhāma pavitraṁ paramaṁ bhavān puruṣaṁ śāśvataṁ divyam ādidevam ajaṁ vibhum
shlokas.interpretation: This verse is a profound declaration of Krishna's supreme nature. Arjuna acknowledges Krishna as the ultimate reality, the highest abode, and the purest being. It emphasizes the transcendental, eternal, and all-pervading nature of the Divine. The verse establishes Krishna's position as the source of all creation, beyond birth and death, and the primordial God. It serves as a pivotal moment in the Gita where Krishna's true identity is recognized and revered.
shlokas.meaning: You are the Supreme Brahman, the ultimate abode, the purest, the Absolute Truth. You are the eternal, transcendental, original person, the unborn, and the greatest. All the great sages proclaim this, and now You Yourself are declaring it to me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to recognize the divine in all aspects of life, fostering a sense of reverence and interconnectedness. It can help in developing humility by acknowledging a higher power, reducing ego-driven conflicts. The concept of an all-pervading divinity can inspire people to treat others and the environment with respect. It also provides a foundation for seeking deeper meaning and purpose in life, beyond material pursuits, potentially leading to greater contentment and spiritual growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 13
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
आहुस्त्वामृषयः सर्वे देवर्षिर्नारदस्तथा |
असितो देवलो व्यासः स्वयं चैव ब्रवीषि मे ||
shlokas.transliteration: āhus tvām ṛṣayaḥ sarve devarṣir nāradas tathā asito devalo vyāsaḥ svayaṁ caiva bravīṣi me
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the universal recognition of Krishna's divine nature by great sages and seers. It shows that Krishna's supremacy is not just a personal claim but is acknowledged by respected spiritual authorities. The mention of specific sages like Narada, Asita, Devala, and Vyasa adds credibility to this recognition, as these are highly revered figures in Hindu tradition. The verse also highlights the consistency between what these sages proclaim and what Krishna himself is saying, reinforcing the truth of his divine nature.
shlokas.meaning: All the great sages such as Narada, Asita, Devala, and Vyasa proclaim You as the Supreme Divine Being, and now You Yourself are declaring the same to me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of seeking wisdom from multiple respected sources when trying to understand profound truths. It encourages us to validate our beliefs and experiences through the lens of established wisdom traditions. In practical life, this principle can be applied when making important decisions by consulting experts, mentors, and trusted advisors, while also trusting our own intuition and understanding. It also reminds us to be humble and open to learning, recognizing that truth can be affirmed through various channels.

shlokas.name: Shloka 14
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सर्वमेतदृतं मन्ये यन्मां वदसि केशव |
न हि ते भगवन्व्यक्तिं विदुर्देवा न दानवा: ||
shlokas.transliteration: sarvam etad rtam manye yan mam vadasi kesava | na hi te bhagavan vyaktim vidur deva na danavah ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse represents Arjuna's acknowledgment of Krishna's divine nature and omniscience. It highlights the transcendental position of Krishna, emphasizing that even celestial beings and demons cannot fully comprehend His true nature. This underscores the supreme position of the Divine and the limitations of mortal and even supernatural understanding.
shlokas.meaning: O Krishna, I believe everything You have told me to be true. Neither the gods nor the demons can understand Your true personality and manifestation.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages humility and faith in the face of the incomprehensible. It teaches us to trust in higher wisdom, especially when facing complex life situations. It also reminds us to be open to knowledge from authentic sources, even if it challenges our preconceptions. In practical terms, this can help in decision-making by encouraging us to seek guidance from wise mentors or spiritual teachings when confronted with difficult choices or ethical dilemmas.

shlokas.name: Shloka 15
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
स्वयमेवात्मनात्मानं वेत्थ त्वं पुरुषोत्तम |
भूतभावन भूतेश देवदेव जगत्पते ||
shlokas.transliteration: svayamevātmanātmānaṁ vettha tvaṁ puruṣottama | bhūtabhāvana bhūteśa devadeva jagatpate ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the supreme nature of Krishna as the ultimate knower of himself. It acknowledges that only Krishna, as the Supreme Being, has complete self-knowledge and understanding of his own divine nature. The verse uses several epithets to address Krishna, highlighting his role as the creator, sustainer, and lord of all beings, as well as the supreme god and master of the universe. This shloka underscores the limitations of human understanding and the vastness of divine knowledge.
shlokas.meaning: O Supreme Person, You alone know Yourself by Your own internal potency. You are the creator of all beings, the Lord of all creatures, the God of gods, and the Lord of the universe.
shlokas.life_application: This verse reminds us of the importance of humility in our pursuit of knowledge and understanding. It teaches us to recognize our limitations and to approach life's challenges with an open mind, understanding that there may be aspects of reality beyond our comprehension. In practical terms, this can help us in decision-making processes by encouraging us to seek diverse perspectives and expert opinions, rather than relying solely on our own understanding. It also inspires us to continually strive for self-improvement and deeper self-awareness, while maintaining reverence for the mysteries of existence.

shlokas.name: Shloka 16
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
वंशः पाण्डवानां च मुनीनामप्यहं व्यासः।
कवीनामुशना कविः प्रहलादश्चास्मि दैत्यानाम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: vaṁśaḥ pāṇḍavānāṁ ca munīnāmapyahaṁ vyāsaḥ kavīnāmuśanā kaviḥ prahalādaścāsmi daityānām
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations in various forms of excellence. He identifies himself with the most prominent figures in different categories, emphasizing his omnipresence and supremacy. By mentioning Vyasa, Ushana, and Prahlada, Krishna illustrates that he embodies wisdom, poetic genius, and devotion respectively, showcasing the diverse aspects of his divine nature.
shlokas.meaning: Among the Pandavas, I am Arjuna. Among the sages, I am Vyasa. Among poets, I am Ushana (Shukracharya). And among the Daityas, I am Prahlada.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize and appreciate excellence in various fields and individuals. It encourages us to strive for greatness in our chosen paths, understanding that the divine manifests through human excellence. It also reminds us to see the divine in others, promoting respect and unity despite apparent differences in roles or backgrounds.

shlokas.name: Shloka 17
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
कथं विद्यामहं योगिंस्त्वां सदा परिचिन्तयन् ।
केषु केषु च भावेषु चिन्त्योऽसि भगवन्मया ॥
shlokas.transliteration: kathaṁ vidyām ahaṁ yogiṁs tvāṁ sadā paricintayan keṣu keṣu ca bhāveṣu cintyo 'si bhagavan mayā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse represents Arjuna's eagerness to understand the divine nature of Krishna more deeply. It shows the devotee's desire for a more intimate connection with the Supreme Being. Arjuna's question reflects the human quest for understanding the omnipresent nature of the Divine and how to constantly meditate on it.
shlokas.meaning: O Yogi, how can I know You by constantly thinking of You? In what various forms are You to be contemplated, O Blessed Lord?
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to seek a deeper understanding of the divine in our daily lives. It teaches us to be curious about spiritual matters and to constantly contemplate on higher truths. In practical terms, it can inspire us to maintain a regular spiritual practice, be it meditation, prayer, or self-reflection, to connect with our inner divinity and find purpose and peace in our lives.

shlokas.name: Shloka 18
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
विस्तरेणात्मनो योगं विभूतिं च जनार्दन |
भूयः कथय तृप्तिर्हि श्रृण्वतो नास्ति मेऽमृतम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: vistareṇātmano yogaṁ vibhūtiṁ ca janārdana bhūyaḥ kathaya tṛptir hi śṛṇvato nāsti me'mṛtam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse reflects Arjuna's deep desire for spiritual knowledge and his reverence for Krishna's teachings. It shows the importance of continuous learning and the insatiable thirst for divine wisdom. The use of 'amritam' (nectar) metaphorically represents the eternal and life-giving nature of Krishna's words.
shlokas.meaning: O Janardana, please describe in detail once again Your divine opulences and Your Yoga power. I never tire of hearing Your ambrosial words.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to cultivate a lifelong passion for learning and self-improvement. It teaches us to seek wisdom from those more knowledgeable than ourselves and to never be satisfied with our current level of understanding. In practical life, this attitude can lead to personal growth, professional development, and a deeper appreciation of the world around us.

shlokas.name: Shloka 19
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थितः।
अहमादिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च॥
shlokas.transliteration: aham ātmā guḍākeśa sarva-bhūtāśaya-sthitaḥ aham ādiś ca madhyaṁ ca bhūtānām anta eva ca
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes Krishna's omnipresence and His role as the ultimate essence of all existence. It highlights the concept of divine immanence, suggesting that the Supreme Being resides within the heart of every living entity. The verse also underscores the eternal nature of the Divine, encompassing the beginning, middle, and end of all beings, thus reinforcing the idea of God as the source, sustainer, and ultimate destination of all creation.
shlokas.meaning: O Arjuna, I am the Self seated in the hearts of all creatures. I am the beginning, the middle and the end of all beings.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a sense of unity and interconnectedness with all beings, fostering compassion and empathy. It encourages self-reflection and the search for the divine within oneself and others. Understanding the omnipresence of the Divine can lead to a more holistic and balanced approach to life, helping one navigate challenges with equanimity and find purpose in all stages of existence.

shlokas.name: Shloka 20
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थितः।
अहमादिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च॥
shlokas.transliteration: aham ātmā guḍākeśa sarva-bhūtāśaya-sthitaḥ aham ādiś ca madhyaṁ ca bhūtānām anta eva ca
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes Krishna's omnipresence and His role as the ultimate essence of existence. By declaring Himself as the Atma (soul) residing in all beings, Krishna highlights the interconnectedness of all life and the divine presence within every entity. The statement about being the beginning, middle, and end of all beings underscores the eternal and all-encompassing nature of the Supreme Being, suggesting that all of creation is a manifestation of the divine.
shlokas.meaning: I am the Self, O Gudakesha, seated in the hearts of all creatures. I am the beginning, the middle and the end of all beings.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals develop a sense of unity and respect for all life forms, recognizing the divine essence in everyone. It encourages self-reflection and the pursuit of self-realization, as one begins to see the connection between their inner self and the universal consciousness. This perspective can lead to greater compassion, reduced ego, and a more harmonious approach to relationships and conflicts, as we recognize the same divine spark in others that exists within ourselves.

shlokas.name: Shloka 21
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
आदित्यानां अहं विष्णुर्ज्योतिषां रविरंशुमान् |
मरीचिर्मरुतामस्मि नक्षत्राणामहं शशी ||
shlokas.transliteration: ādityānāṁ ahaṁ viṣṇur jyotiṣāṁ ravir aṁśumān marīcir marutām asmi nakṣatrāṇām ahaṁ śaśī
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations in celestial bodies and natural phenomena. It emphasizes His omnipresence and supremacy in the cosmos, showcasing how He pervades every aspect of existence, from the brightest sun to the gentle moon. This revelation serves to deepen Arjuna's understanding of Krishna's universal form and divine nature.
shlokas.meaning: Among the Adityas, I am Vishnu; among luminaries, I am the radiant sun; among the Maruts, I am Marichi; and among the stars, I am the moon.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to see the divine in all aspects of nature and the universe. It teaches us to approach life with reverence and awe, recognizing the interconnectedness of all things. In practical terms, it can inspire us to be more mindful of our environment, to seek harmony in our relationships, and to strive for excellence in our chosen fields, knowing that divinity manifests in various forms of greatness.

shlokas.name: Shloka 22
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
वेदानां सामवेदोऽस्मि देवानामस्मि वासवः।
इन्द्रियाणां मनश्चास्मि भूतानामस्मि चेतना॥
shlokas.transliteration: vedānāṁ sāma-vedo'smi devānām asmi vāsavaḥ indriyāṇāṁ manaś cāsmi bhūtānām asmi cetanā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations in various aspects of creation. By equating himself with the most prominent or essential elements in different categories, Krishna emphasizes his all-pervasive nature and supreme position in the universe. This reinforces the concept of God's omnipresence and the interconnectedness of all existence.
shlokas.meaning: Among the Vedas, I am the Sama Veda; among the gods, I am Indra; among the senses, I am the mind; and among living beings, I am consciousness.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to recognize the divine presence in all aspects of life. It teaches us to approach our studies, relationships, and self-awareness with reverence, understanding that the supreme consciousness permeates everything. In daily life, we can apply this by cultivating mindfulness, treating our body and mind as sacred vessels, and seeking to connect with the higher consciousness in our interactions with others and our environment.

shlokas.name: Shloka 23
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
रुद्राणां शङ्करश्चास्मि वित्तेशो यक्षरक्षसाम् ।
वसूनां पावकश्चास्मि मेरुः शिखरिणामहम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: rudrāṇāṁ śaṅkaraś cāsmi vitteśo yakṣarakṣasām vasūnāṁ pāvakaś cāsmi meruḥ śikhariṇām aham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations among various celestial beings and natural phenomena. By identifying himself with prominent figures in different categories, Krishna emphasizes his all-pervasive nature and supreme position in the cosmic hierarchy. This reinforces the concept of God's omnipresence and his role as the source of all existence.
shlokas.meaning: Among the Rudras, I am Shankara; among the Yakshas and Rakshasas, I am Kubera (the lord of wealth); among the Vasus, I am Agni (the fire god); and among the mountains, I am Meru.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to recognize the divine presence in various aspects of life, from powerful forces to everyday elements. It teaches us to approach life with reverence and humility, understanding that the supreme consciousness permeates all things. This perspective can help in developing a more holistic and respectful attitude towards nature, other beings, and the world around us, leading to a more harmonious and balanced life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 24
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पुरोधसां च मुख्यं मां विद्धि पार्थ बृहस्पतिम् |
सेनानीनामहं स्कन्दः सरसामस्मि सागरः ||
shlokas.transliteration: purodhasāṁ ca mukhyaṁ māṁ viddhi pārtha bṛhaspatim | senānīnāmahaṁ skandaḥ sarasāmasmi sāgaraḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations in various roles and natural phenomena. It emphasizes His supremacy as the foremost among priests, military leaders, and bodies of water. By identifying Himself with these prominent figures and elements, Krishna illustrates His all-pervasive nature and encourages Arjuna to recognize the divine presence in all aspects of creation.
shlokas.meaning: Among priests, know Me to be the chief, Brihaspati. Among generals, I am Kartikeya, and among bodies of water, I am the ocean.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize and respect excellence in various fields, understanding that the highest manifestation of skill or power in any domain is a reflection of the divine. It encourages us to strive for excellence in our chosen paths, seeing our work as a form of spiritual practice. Additionally, it reminds us to seek wisdom from those who are most knowledgeable and experienced in their fields, just as Brihaspati is the wisest among priests.

shlokas.name: Shloka 25
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
महर्षीणां भृगुरहं गिरामस्म्येकमक्षरम् |
यज्ञानां जपयज्ञोऽस्मि स्थावराणां हिमालय: ||
shlokas.transliteration: maharṣīṇāṁ bhṛgurahaṁ girāmasmyekamakṣaram yajñānāṁ japayajño'smi sthāvarāṇāṁ himālayaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations in various forms of excellence. It emphasizes the importance of recognizing divinity in the highest expressions of nature, knowledge, and spiritual practices. By identifying himself with these supreme elements, Krishna illustrates the omnipresence of the divine in all aspects of existence, encouraging devotees to see the extraordinary in the ordinary and to strive for excellence in their own pursuits.
shlokas.meaning: Among the great sages, I am Bhrigu; of words, I am the single syllable Om; of sacrifices, I am the sacrifice of silent repetition; and of immovable things, I am the Himalayas.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize and appreciate excellence in various fields of life. It encourages us to strive for the highest quality in our work, speech, and spiritual practices. By understanding the divine presence in all things, we can develop a more respectful and mindful approach to our environment and relationships. The mention of 'Om' and silent repetition reminds us of the power of meditation and mindfulness in our daily lives, which can help reduce stress and increase focus. The reference to the Himalayas symbolizes stability and grandeur, inspiring us to remain steadfast in our principles and aspirations despite life's challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 26
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अश्वत्थः सर्ववृक्षाणां देवर्षीणां च नारदः।
गन्धर्वाणां चित्ररथः सिद्धानां कपिलो मुनिः॥
shlokas.transliteration: ashvatthah sarvavrikshanam devarsheenam cha naradah gandharvaanam chitrarathah siddhaanaam kapilo munih
shlokas.interpretation: This verse is part of Krishna's vibhuti yoga, where He describes His divine manifestations in various forms. By equating Himself with the most prominent or excellent entities in different categories, Krishna emphasizes His omnipresence and supremacy in all aspects of creation. This verse specifically highlights the importance of wisdom, devotion, and spiritual attainment by mentioning revered figures and symbols.
shlokas.meaning: Among all trees, I am the sacred fig tree; among divine sages, I am Narada; among Gandharvas, I am Chitraratha; and among perfected beings, I am the sage Kapila.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to see the divine in all aspects of life, from nature to accomplished individuals. It teaches us to respect and learn from those who have attained wisdom and spiritual perfection. By recognizing excellence in various fields, we can strive for personal growth and seek inspiration from the best examples around us. This approach can help in developing a more holistic and spiritually aware perspective in our daily lives.

shlokas.name: Shloka 27
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
उच्चैःश्रवसमश्वानां विद्धि माममृतोद्भवम् ।
ऐरावतं गजेन्द्राणां नराणां च नराधिपम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: uccaiḥśravasam aśvānāṁ viddhi mām amṛtodbhavam airāvataṁ gajendrāṇāṁ narāṇāṁ ca narādhipam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations in various forms of excellence. It emphasizes the concept of vibhuti yoga, where the Supreme Being manifests as the most extraordinary or supreme aspects of different categories in creation. This reinforces the idea that divinity permeates all aspects of existence, from mythical beings to earthly rulers.
shlokas.meaning: Among horses, know Me to be Ucchaihshrava, born of the churning of the ocean for nectar. Among lordly elephants, I am Airavata, and among humans, I am the monarch.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize and appreciate excellence in various fields of life. It encourages us to strive for the highest quality in our endeavors, understanding that the divine manifests through supreme achievements. In practical terms, it can inspire us to seek out and learn from the best in any field we pursue, whether in our careers, hobbies, or personal development. It also reminds us to see the divine in positions of leadership and responsibility, encouraging ethical and excellent leadership in our own roles.

shlokas.name: Shloka 28
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
आयुधानामहं वज्रं धेनूनामस्मि कामधुक् |
प्रजनश्चास्मि कन्दर्पः सर्पाणामस्मि वासुकिः ||
shlokas.transliteration: āyudhānāmahaṁ vajraṁ dhenūnāmasmi kāmadhuk prajanaścāsmi kandarpaḥ sarpāṇāmasmi vāsukiḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse is part of Krishna's vibhuti yoga, where He describes His divine manifestations in various forms. Here, Krishna identifies Himself with the most powerful or significant entities in different categories. This emphasizes His omnipresence and supremacy in all aspects of creation, showcasing the divine's pervasiveness in both celestial and earthly realms.
shlokas.meaning: Among weapons, I am the thunderbolt; among cows, I am the wish-fulfilling cow Kamadhenu. I am Kandarpa, the god of love, for procreation; and among serpents, I am Vasuki, the king of snakes.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine in all aspects of life, from the powerful to the nurturing. It encourages us to approach life with reverence, seeing the extraordinary in the ordinary. In practical terms, it can inspire us to excel in our chosen fields, understanding that mastery and divinity are interconnected. It also reminds us of the importance of balance – recognizing both the forceful (vajra) and the nurturing (kamadhuk) aspects within ourselves and in our interactions with others.

shlokas.name: Shloka 29
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अनन्तश्चास्मि नागानां वरुणो यादसामहम् ।
पितॄणामर्यमा चास्मि यमः संयमतामहम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: anantaścāsmi nāgānāṁ varuṇo yādasāmaham pitṝṇāmaryamā cāsmi yamaḥ saṁyamatāmaham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations in various forms of cosmic power and authority. By equating himself with these powerful entities, Krishna emphasizes his omnipresence and supremacy in all aspects of creation. The verse also underscores the interconnectedness of different realms - celestial, terrestrial, and netherworld - all unified under Krishna's divine presence.
shlokas.meaning: Among the Nagas, I am Ananta; among the water deities, I am Varuna. Among the ancestors, I am Aryama, and among the maintainers of law and order, I am Yama.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine presence in various aspects of life and nature. It encourages us to approach life with reverence and respect for all beings and forces around us. In practical terms, it can inspire us to seek balance and harmony in our actions, to respect authority and natural laws, and to cultivate a sense of interconnectedness with all aspects of existence. This understanding can lead to more mindful decision-making and a greater sense of responsibility towards our environment and society.

shlokas.name: Shloka 30
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
प्रह्लादश्चास्मि दैत्यानां कालः कलयतामहम् ।
मृगाणां च मृगेन्द्रोऽहं वैनतेयश्च पक्षिणाम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: prahlādaścāsmi daityānāṁ kālaḥ kalayatāmaham mṛgāṇāṁ ca mṛgendro'haṁ vainateyaśca pakṣiṇām
shlokas.interpretation: This verse showcases Krishna's divine manifestations in various forms of power and supremacy. By mentioning Prahlada, Time, the lion, and Garuda, Krishna illustrates His presence in devotion, cosmic force, animal kingdom, and avian realm respectively. This demonstrates the all-pervasive nature of the Divine and emphasizes that God exists in the most prominent aspects of every category of existence.
shlokas.meaning: Among the Daityas, I am Prahlada; among subduers, I am time; among beasts, I am the lion; and among birds, I am Garuda.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize divinity in various aspects of life. It encourages developing devotion like Prahlada, understanding the power of time in personal growth, cultivating courage and leadership like a lion, and aspiring for spiritual elevation like Garuda. In practical terms, it can inspire us to seek the extraordinary in ordinary life, respect natural hierarchies, manage time effectively, and strive for excellence in our respective fields.

shlokas.name: Shloka 31
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पवनः पवतामस्मि रामः शस्त्रभृतामहम् ।
झषाणां मकरश्चास्मि स्रोतसामस्मि जाह्नवी ॥
shlokas.transliteration: pavanaḥ pavatāmasmi rāmaḥ śastrabhṛtāmaham | jhaṣāṇāṁ makaraścāsmi srotasāmasmi jāhnavī ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse is part of Krishna's vibhuti yoga, where He describes His divine manifestations in various forms of excellence. By equating Himself with the purest or most powerful elements of nature and mythological figures, Krishna emphasizes His omnipresence and supremacy in all aspects of existence. This reinforces the idea that the Divine permeates everything, from natural phenomena to human achievements.
shlokas.meaning: Among purifiers, I am the wind; among wielders of weapons, I am Rama; among fishes, I am the shark; and among rivers, I am the Ganges.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to see the divine in all aspects of life, from the mundane to the extraordinary. It teaches us to approach life with reverence and to strive for excellence in our chosen fields, as excellence itself is a manifestation of the divine. It also reminds us of the purifying power of nature and the importance of cleansing our minds and actions. By recognizing the divine in powerful natural forces and heroic figures, we can draw inspiration to overcome challenges and embody noble qualities in our daily lives.

shlokas.name: Shloka 32
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सर्गाणामादिरन्तश्च मध्यं चैवाहमर्जुन।
अध्यात्मविद्या विद्यानां वादः प्रवदतामहम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: sargāṇām ādir antaś ca madhyaṁ caivāham arjuna adhyātma-vidyā vidyānāṁ vādaḥ pravadatām aham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes Krishna's omnipresence and all-pervasiveness. He declares Himself to be the beginning, middle, and end of all creation, highlighting His role as the supreme cause and sustainer of the universe. By stating He is the spiritual science among all sciences, Krishna underscores the paramount importance of self-realization. His claim to be the logic of debaters suggests that He is the ultimate truth that all logical arguments aim to discover.
shlokas.meaning: I am the beginning, middle, and end of all creation, O Arjuna. Among all sciences, I am the spiritual science of the self, and among logicians, I am the conclusive truth.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to seek spiritual knowledge and self-realization as the highest form of education. It reminds us to look for the divine presence in all aspects of life, from beginning to end. In debates and discussions, it advises us to aim for the ultimate truth rather than getting lost in rhetorical arguments. This teaching can help in problem-solving by encouraging a holistic perspective and focusing on core spiritual principles in decision-making.

shlokas.name: Shloka 33
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अक्षराणामकारोऽस्मि द्वन्द्वः सामासिकस्य च |
अहमेवाक्षयः कालो धाताहं विश्वतोमुखः ||
shlokas.transliteration: aksharanam akaro 'smi dvandvah samasikasya cha aham evakshayah kalo dhataham vishvatomukhah
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's omnipresence and all-pervasiveness. By identifying himself with fundamental elements of language, time, and creation, Krishna emphasizes his role as the underlying essence of all existence. The verse showcases the concept of divine immanence, where the Supreme Being is present in even the most basic components of the universe.
shlokas.meaning: Among letters, I am the letter A; among compound words, I am the dual compound. I am the inexhaustible time, and I am the all-pervading Creator.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to see the divine in every aspect of our lives, from the words we speak to the passage of time. It teaches us to approach life with reverence and mindfulness, recognizing the sacred in the ordinary. By understanding the interconnectedness of all things, we can cultivate a sense of unity and purpose in our daily actions and relationships.

shlokas.name: Shloka 34
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मृत्युः सर्वहरश्चाहमुद्भवश्च भविष्यताम् |
कीर्तिः श्रीर्वाक्च नारीणां स्मृतिर्मेधा धृतिः क्षमा ||
shlokas.transliteration: mṛtyuḥ sarvaharaścāhamudbhavaśca bhaviṣyatām | kīrtiḥ śrīrvākca nārīṇāṁ smṛtirmedhā dhṛtiḥ kṣamā ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes Krishna's all-encompassing nature, portraying him as both the destroyer and the creator. It highlights the cyclical nature of existence and Krishna's role in it. The verse also associates Krishna with positive qualities and virtues, particularly those traditionally associated with women, suggesting the importance of these attributes in spiritual growth and the divine nature of such qualities.
shlokas.meaning: I am all-devouring death, and I am the generator of all things yet to be. Among women, I am fame, fortune, fine speech, memory, intelligence, steadfastness and patience.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine in all aspects of life, including death and new beginnings. It encourages cultivating positive qualities like patience, intelligence, and steadfastness, regardless of gender. In facing life's challenges, we can draw strength from understanding that both creation and destruction are part of a larger divine plan, helping us maintain equanimity in success and failure.

shlokas.name: Shloka 35
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
बृहत्साम तथा साम्नां गायत्री छन्दसामहम् |
मासानां मार्गशीर्षोऽहमृतूनां कुसुमाकर: ||
shlokas.transliteration: bṛhatsāma tathā sāmnāṁ gāyatrī chandasāmaham māsānāṁ mārgaśīrṣo'hamṛtūnāṁ kusumākaraḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations in various aspects of nature and sacred texts. By equating himself with the most revered elements in each category, Krishna emphasizes his omnipresence and the interconnectedness of all creation. This verse encourages devotees to see the divine in everyday aspects of life and nature, fostering a deeper spiritual awareness.
shlokas.meaning: Among the Sama Vedic hymns, I am the Brihat-sama; among poetic meters, I am the Gayatri. Of the months, I am Margashirsha (November-December), and of seasons, I am spring, the season of flowering.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize divinity in various aspects of life, encouraging mindfulness and appreciation for the world around us. It can be applied to develop a more holistic and spiritual perspective on daily experiences, helping individuals find meaning and connection in seemingly ordinary things. This approach can lead to greater contentment, reduced stress, and a deeper sense of purpose in life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 36
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
द्यूतं छलयतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम् ।
जयोऽस्मि व्यवसायोऽस्मि सत्त्वं सत्त्ववतामहम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: dyūtaṁ chalayatām asmi tejas tejasvinām aham | jayo 'smi vyavasāyo 'smi sattvaṁ sattvavatām aham ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's omnipresence in various aspects of life, both positive and potentially negative. It emphasizes that the divine exists in all forms of excellence and strength, whether in gambling, radiance, victory, or determination. The verse also underscores the importance of discernment in recognizing the divine in different manifestations, reminding us that even in activities that may seem morally ambiguous, there is an aspect of the supreme being.
shlokas.meaning: Among deceitful gambling, I am the dice. Of the splendid, I am the splendor. I am victory, I am determination, and of the virtuous, I am their virtue.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine in all aspects of life, even those we might consider negative. It encourages us to approach life with discernment, understanding that excellence and virtue can be found in unexpected places. In practical terms, this can help us maintain a balanced perspective, avoid hasty judgments, and seek the positive aspects in challenging situations. It also emphasizes the importance of determination and virtue in our personal growth and success.

shlokas.name: Shloka 37
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
वृष्णीनां वासुदेवोऽस्मि पाण्डवानां धनंजयः।
मुनीनामप्यहं व्यासः कवीनामुशना कविः॥
shlokas.transliteration: vṛṣṇīnāṁ vāsudevosmi pāṇḍavānāṁ dhanaṁjayaḥ munīnām apy ahaṁ vyāsaḥ kavīnām uśanā kaviḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's divine manifestations among various groups, emphasizing His supreme position in different fields. It showcases the concept of vibhuti yoga, where the Lord reveals His divine glories in the most excellent of beings or things in various categories. This reinforces the idea that divinity permeates all aspects of existence, and the most exceptional qualities in any domain are direct manifestations of the Supreme.
shlokas.meaning: Among the Vrishnis, I am Vasudeva; among the Pandavas, I am Arjuna; among the sages, I am Vyasa; and among the poets, I am Ushana (Shukracharya).
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize and appreciate excellence in various fields as manifestations of the divine. It encourages us to strive for excellence in our chosen paths, understanding that by doing so, we are aligning ourselves with the divine. It also promotes respect for accomplished individuals in different domains, seeing them as channels of divine energy. In practical terms, this can inspire us to cultivate our talents, respect expertise, and seek wisdom from various sources, recognizing that the divine manifests in diverse forms of human achievement.

shlokas.name: Shloka 38
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
दण्डो दमयतामस्मि नीतिरस्मि जिगीषताम् |
मौनं चैवास्मि गुह्यानां ज्ञानं ज्ञानवतामहम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: daṇḍo damayatāmasmi nītirasmī jigīṣatām | maunaṁ caivāsmi guhyānāṁ jñānaṁ jñānavatāmaham ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights Krishna's omnipresence in various aspects of governance, strategy, wisdom, and knowledge. It emphasizes the divine presence in righteous punishment, ethical conduct, strategic thinking, and the highest forms of knowledge. The verse also underscores the importance of silence in spiritual practices and the pursuit of self-realization.
shlokas.meaning: Among those who punish, I am the scepter of justice. Among those who seek victory, I am wise policy. Of secrets, I am silence, and of the wise, I am wisdom.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in leadership roles, encouraging fair and just governance. It emphasizes the importance of ethical strategies in achieving goals. The mention of silence as a secret reminds us of the power of discretion and introspection in personal growth. For knowledge seekers, it underscores the significance of cultivating true wisdom beyond mere information gathering, promoting a deeper understanding of life and self.

shlokas.name: Shloka 39
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यच्चापि सर्वभूतानां बीजं तदहमर्जुन |
न तदस्ति विना यत्स्यान्मया भूतं चराचरम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: yac cāpi sarvabhūtānāṁ bījaṁ tad aham arjuna na tad asti vinā yat syān mayā bhūtaṁ carācaram
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the omnipresence and all-pervasiveness of the Divine. Krishna declares that He is the fundamental seed of all existence, implying that He is the source and sustainer of all creation. This concept aligns with the Vedantic philosophy of non-dualism, suggesting that the ultimate reality (Brahman) is the essence of everything in the universe, both animate and inanimate.
shlokas.meaning: I am the seed of all beings, O Arjuna. There is no being, moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals develop a sense of unity with all of creation, fostering compassion and respect for all forms of life. It encourages a holistic worldview, promoting environmental consciousness and ethical behavior. Recognizing the divine essence in everything can lead to reduced ego, increased humility, and a deeper appreciation for the interconnectedness of all things, which can be applied in personal relationships, professional ethics, and spiritual growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 40
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
नान्तोऽस्ति मम दिव्यानां विभूतीनां परंतप।
एष तूद्देशतः प्रोक्तो विभूतेर्विस्तरो मया॥
shlokas.transliteration: nānto'sti mama divyānāṁ vibhūtīnāṁ parantapa | eṣa tūddeśataḥ prokto vibhūtervistaro mayā ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse concludes Krishna's description of His divine manifestations, emphasizing the infinite nature of His glory. It suggests that the manifestations mentioned are just a glimpse of His vast cosmic form, implying that the entire universe is a reflection of the Divine. This reinforces the concept of God's omnipresence and the interconnectedness of all existence.
shlokas.meaning: There is no end to My divine manifestations, O conqueror of enemies. What I have spoken to you is but a mere indication of My infinite opulence.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to see the divine in all aspects of life, fostering a sense of wonder and respect for the world around us. It teaches us to approach life with humility, recognizing that our understanding is limited compared to the vastness of existence. In practical terms, this can help in developing a more inclusive and compassionate worldview, seeing the potential for greatness in every person and situation we encounter.

shlokas.name: Shloka 41
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यद्यद्विभूतिमत्सत्त्वं श्रीमदूर्जितमेव वा ।
तत्तदेवावगच्छ त्वं मम तेजोंऽशसम्भवम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: yad yad vibhūtimat sattvaṁ śrīmad ūrjitam eva vā tad tad evāvagaccha tvaṁ mama tejo-'ṁśa-sambhavam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the omnipresence of the divine in all magnificent and powerful aspects of creation. It suggests that anything possessing extraordinary qualities, beauty, or strength is a manifestation of a fraction of Krishna's divine splendor. This teaching reinforces the concept of God's immanence in the world and encourages devotees to see the divine in all aspects of life, fostering a sense of reverence and wonder for the creation.
shlokas.meaning: Know that all opulent, beautiful and glorious creations spring from but a spark of My splendor.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in daily life to cultivate a sense of wonder and respect for the world around us. By recognizing the divine in all things of beauty and power, one can develop a more positive and appreciative outlook on life. It encourages us to see the extraordinary in the ordinary, fostering gratitude and mindfulness. This perspective can help in overcoming negativity, reducing ego, and promoting a sense of interconnectedness with all of creation.

shlokas.name: Shloka 42
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अथवा बहुनैतेन किं ज्ञातेन तवार्जुन |
विष्टभ्याहमिदं कृत्स्नमेकांशेन स्थितो जगत् ||
shlokas.transliteration: athavā bahunaitena kiṁ jñātena tavārjuna | viṣṭabhyāham idaṁ kṛtsnam ekāṁśena sthito jagat ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse serves as the culmination of Krishna's divine manifestations, emphasizing the omnipresence and all-pervasiveness of the Supreme Being. It underscores the limitless nature of the Divine and suggests that even the extensive list of manifestations previously described is merely a fraction of God's infinite glory. The verse implies that the entire cosmos is sustained by just a fragment of the Divine's power, highlighting the incomprehensible magnitude of the Supreme Being's influence and existence.
shlokas.meaning: But what need is there, Arjuna, for all this detailed knowledge? With a single fragment of Myself, I pervade and support this entire universe.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a sense of humility and wonder about the vastness of the universe and the power that sustains it. It encourages people to see the divine in everything around them, fostering a sense of interconnectedness and respect for all creation. In practical terms, it can inspire individuals to approach their problems with a broader perspective, understanding that their challenges are small in the grand scheme of things, and that there is a greater power they can connect with for strength and guidance.
