shlokas.name: Shloka 1
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मदनुग्रहाय परमं गुह्यमध्यात्मसंज्ञितम् ।
यत्त्वयोक्तं वचस्तेन मोहोऽयं विगतो मम ॥
shlokas.transliteration: madanugrahāya paramaṁ guhyam adhyātma-saṁjñitam yat tvayoktaṁ vacas tena moho 'yaṁ vigato mama
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the dialogue between Arjuna and Krishna. Arjuna acknowledges that Krishna's words have dispelled his confusion and ignorance. It signifies the transformative power of spiritual knowledge and divine grace in overcoming mental delusions. The verse also highlights the importance of a guru-disciple relationship in spiritual growth.
shlokas.meaning: Arjuna says: By Your grace, my delusion is now destroyed. I have gained understanding through Your profound words about the supreme secret of spiritual knowledge.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of seeking guidance from wise mentors or spiritual teachers when facing confusion or moral dilemmas. It encourages us to be open to new perspectives and knowledge that can help overcome our mental limitations and misconceptions. In daily life, we can apply this by actively seeking wisdom, being receptive to constructive feedback, and allowing ourselves to grow beyond our current understanding.

shlokas.name: Shloka 2
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पश्यामि देवांस्तव देव देहे
सर्वांस्तथा भूतविशेषसङ्घान् ।
ब्रह्माणमीशं कमलासनस्थ-
मृषींश्च सर्वानुरगांश्च दिव्यान् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: pashyāmi devāṁs tava deva dehe sarvāṁs tathā bhūta-viśeṣa-saṅghān brahmāṇam īśaṁ kamalāsana-stham ṛṣīṁś ca sarvān uragāṁś ca divyān
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's vision of Krishna's universal form. It signifies the omnipresence and all-encompassing nature of the Divine. Arjuna sees all celestial beings, sages, and divine entities within Krishna's cosmic body, emphasizing the concept that all of creation is contained within the Supreme Being. This revelation challenges Arjuna's previous understanding of Krishna and introduces him to the vast, incomprehensible nature of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: Arjuna says: O Lord, I see within Your body all the gods and hosts of different beings. I see Lord Brahma seated on the lotus flower, as well as Lord Shiva and all the sages and divine serpents.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine presence in all aspects of creation. It encourages a broader perspective on life, helping us overcome narrow-mindedness and prejudices. By understanding the interconnectedness of all beings, we can cultivate respect for diversity, practice inclusivity, and develop a sense of unity with all of existence. This realization can lead to greater compassion, reduced ego, and a more harmonious approach to our relationships and interactions in daily life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 3
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
एवमेतद्यथात्थ त्वं आत्मानं परमेश्वर |
द्रष्टुमिच्छामि ते रूपमैश्वरं पुरुषोत्तम ||
shlokas.transliteration: evam etad yathāttha tvaṁ ātmānaṁ parameśvara draṣṭum icchāmi te rūpam aiśvaraṁ puruṣottama
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita where Arjuna, having heard Krishna's description of His divine nature, expresses his desire to witness Krishna's cosmic form. It signifies the transition from intellectual understanding to direct spiritual experience, highlighting the importance of divine vision (darshan) in spiritual realization.
shlokas.meaning: O Supreme Lord, You have described Yourself as You are. Now, O Supreme Person, I wish to see Your divine cosmic form.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of moving beyond theoretical knowledge to seek direct spiritual experience. In life, we can apply this by not just studying spiritual texts, but also engaging in practices like meditation, prayer, or selfless service to gain a deeper, experiential understanding of spiritual truths. It encourages us to cultivate a sincere desire for spiritual growth and to approach the divine with humility and eagerness to learn.

shlokas.name: Shloka 4
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मन्यसे यदि तच्छक्यं मया द्रष्टुमिति प्रभो।
योगेश्वर ततो मे त्वं दर्शयात्मानमव्ययम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: manyase yadi tacchakyaṁ mayā draṣṭum iti prabho yogeśvara tato me tvaṁ darśayātmānam avyayam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse represents Arjuna's earnest request to Krishna to reveal His divine form. It signifies the human desire to experience the transcendental reality directly. Arjuna's addressing Krishna as 'Yogeshvara' (Lord of Yoga) acknowledges Krishna's supreme power and control over all mystical abilities. The request for the 'avyayam' (imperishable) form indicates Arjuna's readiness to witness the eternal, unchanging aspect of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: O Lord, if You think it is possible for me to see Your universal form, then kindly show me Your imperishable Self, O Master of all mystic power.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us about the importance of spiritual curiosity and the courage to seek higher truths. In life, we often face situations that seem beyond our comprehension. Like Arjuna, we should have the humility to acknowledge our limitations and the courage to seek guidance from those with higher wisdom. It also emphasizes the need for faith and surrender in our spiritual journey, trusting in the divine to reveal deeper truths when we are ready to receive them.

shlokas.name: Shloka 5
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पश्य मे पार्थ रूपाणि शतशोऽथ सहस्रश: ।
नानाविधानि दिव्यानि नानावर्णाकृतीनि च ॥
shlokas.transliteration: pashya me pārtha rūpāṇi shatasho'tha sahasrashah | nānāvidhāni divyāni nānāvarṇākṛtīni cha ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita where Krishna begins to reveal his cosmic form (Vishwaroop) to Arjuna. It emphasizes the infinite and diverse nature of the divine, showcasing that the Supreme Being transcends human comprehension and exists in countless forms. The verse also highlights the concept of unity in diversity, a fundamental principle in Hindu philosophy.
shlokas.meaning: Behold, O Partha (Arjuna), My forms by the hundreds and thousands, of different sorts, divine, and of various colors and shapes.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to broaden our perspective and recognize the divine in all its diverse manifestations. It teaches us to embrace diversity in our daily lives, respecting different cultures, beliefs, and individuals. It also reminds us to look beyond surface-level appearances and seek the underlying unity in all things, promoting tolerance, acceptance, and a more holistic worldview. In problem-solving, it inspires us to consider multiple perspectives and solutions, recognizing that truth and wisdom can come in many forms.

shlokas.name: Shloka 6
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पश्यादित्यान्वसून्रुद्रानश्विनौ मरुतस्तथा |
बहून्यदृष्टपूर्वाणि पश्याश्चर्याणि भारत ||
shlokas.transliteration: pashyādityān vasūn rudrān ashvinau marutastathā bahūnyadṛiṣhṭapūrvāṇi pashyāśhcharyāṇi bhārata
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita where Krishna reveals his cosmic form to Arjuna. It emphasizes the vastness and all-encompassing nature of the divine, showcasing how the Supreme Being contains within itself all celestial entities and wonders of the universe. The verse serves to expand Arjuna's (and the reader's) understanding of divinity beyond limited human perceptions.
shlokas.meaning: Behold the Adityas, Vasus, Rudras, Ashvini-kumaras, and Maruts. Witness the many wonders never seen before, O Bharata (Arjuna).
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to broaden our perspective and see beyond the apparent. In daily life, it teaches us to look for the extraordinary in the ordinary, to recognize the interconnectedness of all things, and to approach challenges with a sense of wonder and openness. It reminds us that there is always more to learn and experience, urging us to remain humble and receptive to new insights and possibilities in our personal and professional lives.

shlokas.name: Shloka 7
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
इहैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं पश्याद्य सचराचरम् ।
मम देहे गुडाकेश यच्चान्यद्द्रष्टुमिच्छसि ॥
shlokas.transliteration: ihaika-sthaṁ jagat kṛtsnaṁ paśyādya sa-carācaram mama dehe guḍākeśa yac cānyad draṣṭum icchasi
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita where Krishna reveals His universal form to Arjuna. It emphasizes the omnipresence of the Divine, showing that all of creation, both animate and inanimate, exists within the cosmic body of the Supreme. This revelation challenges Arjuna's limited perception of reality and introduces him to the vast, all-encompassing nature of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: Behold here in My body the entire universe, including everything moving and non-moving, and whatever else you wish to see, O Arjuna.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to broaden our perspective and see the interconnectedness of all things. In daily life, it can help us overcome narrow-mindedness, promote empathy, and foster a sense of unity with others and nature. It teaches us to look beyond surface differences and recognize the underlying oneness, which can lead to more harmonious relationships and a more holistic approach to problem-solving in personal and professional contexts.

shlokas.name: Shloka 8
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
न तु मां शक्यसे द्रष्टुमनेनैव स्वचक्षुषा।
दिव्यं ददामि ते चक्षुः पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: na tu mām śakyase draṣṭum anenaiva svacakṣuṣā divyaṁ dadāmi te cakṣuḥ paśya me yogam aiśvaram
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita where Krishna prepares Arjuna for the revelation of His divine cosmic form. It emphasizes the limitations of human perception and the necessity of divine grace to comprehend the transcendental nature of God. The verse also highlights the concept of 'divine vision' or spiritual insight, which goes beyond ordinary sensory experiences.
shlokas.meaning: But you cannot see Me with your present eyes. Therefore, I give you divine eyes. Behold My mystic opulence!
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to look beyond surface-level perceptions and seek deeper spiritual understanding. It encourages developing a higher consciousness to comprehend life's profound truths. In practical terms, it suggests cultivating mindfulness, meditation, and spiritual practices to gain clarity and insight in decision-making and problem-solving. It also reminds us to be open to new perspectives and to recognize that our current understanding may be limited, encouraging personal growth and continuous learning.

shlokas.name: Shloka 9
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
एवमुक्त्वा ततो राजन्महायोगेश्वरो हरिः।
दर्शयामास पार्थाय परमं रूपमैश्वरम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: evam uktvā tato rājan mahāyogeśvaro hariḥ | darśayāmāsa pārthāya paramaṁ rūpam aiśvaram ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita, where Krishna, having explained His divine nature, proceeds to reveal His cosmic form to Arjuna. It signifies the transition from verbal description to visual revelation, emphasizing the importance of direct spiritual experience over intellectual understanding. The use of the term 'mahāyogeśvaro' (supreme master of yoga) highlights Krishna's supreme control over all mystical powers, while 'aiśvaram' (divine) underscores the transcendental nature of the vision about to be bestowed upon Arjuna.
shlokas.meaning: Having spoken thus, O King, the Supreme Lord of Yoga, Hari (Krishna), then showed to Partha (Arjuna) His supreme divine form.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us about the importance of direct spiritual experience in our lives. It encourages us to move beyond mere intellectual understanding and seek a deeper, personal connection with the divine. In practical terms, this can be applied through meditation, mindfulness practices, or devotional activities that help us transcend our limited perceptions and experience a broader, more profound reality. It also reminds us that true wisdom often comes through grace and openness to transformative experiences, rather than just accumulation of knowledge.

shlokas.name: Shloka 10
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अनेकवक्त्रनयनमनेकाद्भुतदर्शनम् ।
अनेकदिव्याभरणं दिव्यानेकोद्यतायुधम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: aneka-vaktra-nayanam anekādbhuta-darśanam aneka-divyābharaṇaṁ divyānekodyatāyudham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Krishna's cosmic form (Vishwaroop) as revealed to Arjuna. It emphasizes the infinite and multifaceted nature of the divine, showcasing the Lord's omnipresence and omnipotence. The verse highlights the incomprehensible vastness of the Supreme Being, which transcends human understanding and perception.
shlokas.meaning: With many mouths and eyes, and numerous divine ornaments, the Lord appeared in His universal form, wielding many celestial weapons.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to broaden our perspective and recognize the vastness of the universe and the divine. It teaches us to look beyond our limited perceptions and understand that reality is far more complex and multifaceted than we can comprehend. This realization can help in developing humility, reducing ego, and fostering a sense of wonder and respect for the mysteries of existence. It also inspires us to seek knowledge and understanding beyond our immediate surroundings, promoting personal growth and spiritual development.

shlokas.name: Shloka 11
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
दिव्यमाल्याम्बरधरं दिव्यगन्धानुलेपनम् ।
सर्वाश्चर्यमयं देवमनन्तं विश्वतोमुखम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: divyamālyāmbaradharam divyagandhānulepanam sarvāścaryamayam devamanantam viśvatomukham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the cosmic form of Lord Krishna as revealed to Arjuna. It emphasizes the divine, all-encompassing, and awe-inspiring nature of the Supreme Being. The description portrays a form that transcends human comprehension, adorned with celestial ornaments and fragrances, embodying the entirety of existence. This revelation serves to illustrate the omnipresence and infinitude of the Divine, challenging Arjuna's limited perception of reality and God.
shlokas.meaning: I see the Supreme Lord adorned with celestial garlands and raiments, anointed with divine fragrant oils, full of all wonders, infinite, with faces on all sides.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to broaden their perspective and recognize the divine presence in all aspects of life. It teaches us to look beyond surface appearances and appreciate the interconnectedness of all things. In practical terms, this can help in developing a more inclusive and compassionate worldview, reducing prejudices, and fostering a sense of unity with all beings. It also inspires awe and humility, reminding us of the vastness of the universe and our place within it, which can help in managing ego and cultivating spiritual growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 12
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
दिवि सूर्यसहस्रस्य भवेद्युगपदुत्थिता।
यदि भाः सदृशी सा स्याद्भासस्तस्य महात्मनः॥
shlokas.transliteration: divi sūryasahasrasya bhaved yugapad utthitā yadi bhāḥ sadṛśī sā syād bhāsas tasya mahātmanaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the overwhelming brilliance of Krishna's universal form. It emphasizes the incomprehensible magnitude of the divine manifestation, suggesting that even a thousand suns blazing simultaneously in the sky would not match the radiance of the Supreme Being. This imagery conveys the idea that the divine is beyond human comprehension and ordinary perception, highlighting the transcendent nature of God.
shlokas.meaning: If the radiance of a thousand suns were to burst forth simultaneously in the sky, that would be like the splendor of the mighty one.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to broaden their perspective and recognize the vastness of the universe and the divine. It can be applied in life to cultivate humility, awe, and respect for the greater forces at work in the cosmos. It also inspires one to look beyond the mundane and seek higher truths, fostering spiritual growth and a deeper understanding of one's place in the universe. In challenging times, this verse can remind us of the insignificance of our problems in the grand scheme of things, providing comfort and perspective.

shlokas.name: Shloka 13
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तत्रैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं प्रविभक्तमनेकधा ।
अपश्यद्देवदेवस्य शरीरे पाण्डवस्तदा ॥
shlokas.transliteration: tatraikasthaṁ jagat kṛtsnaṁ pravibhaktam anekadhā apaśyad deva-devasya śarīre pāṇḍavas tadā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's vision of the cosmic form of Lord Krishna. It emphasizes the omnipresence and all-encompassing nature of the Divine, showing how the entire universe, with its infinite diversity, is contained within the Supreme Being. This revelation challenges our limited perception of reality and highlights the interconnectedness of all existence.
shlokas.meaning: Arjuna saw the entire universe, with its countless divisions, unified and present in one place within the body of the God of gods.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to broaden our perspective and see the underlying unity in the apparent diversity of life. It can help in overcoming prejudices, fostering empathy, and developing a more inclusive worldview. In practical terms, it can guide us to approach conflicts and differences with understanding, recognizing that all beings are part of the same cosmic reality. This realization can lead to more harmonious relationships, reduced ego-driven actions, and a deeper sense of connection with the world around us.

shlokas.name: Shloka 14
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ततः स विस्मयाविष्टो हृष्टरोमा धनंजयः ।
प्रणम्य शिरसा देवं कृताञ्जलिरभाषत ॥
shlokas.transliteration: tataḥ sa vismayāviṣṭo hṛṣṭaromā dhanaṁjayaḥ praṇamya śirasā devaṁ kṛtāñjalirabhāṣata
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita where Arjuna, overwhelmed by the cosmic form of Lord Krishna, responds with a mixture of awe, reverence, and humility. It signifies the transformative power of divine revelation and the appropriate human response to such an experience. The verse also illustrates the shift in Arjuna's perception of Krishna from a friend and charioteer to the Supreme Godhead.
shlokas.meaning: Then, filled with wonder and with hair standing on end, Arjuna bowed his head to the Lord with joined palms and began to speak.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of humility and reverence in the face of profound spiritual experiences or realizations. It encourages us to approach life's awe-inspiring moments with a sense of wonder and respect, reminding us to remain open to transformative experiences that can shift our perspective and deepen our understanding of the world and ourselves. In daily life, this can translate to cultivating gratitude, maintaining an attitude of learning, and responding to challenges with a combination of courage and humility.

shlokas.name: Shloka 15
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पश्यामि देवांस्तव देव देहे
सर्वांस्तथा भूतविशेषसङ्घान् ।
ब्रह्माणमीशं कमलासनस्थ-
मृषींश्च सर्वानुरगांश्च दिव्यान् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: pashyāmi devāṁs tava deva dehe sarvāṁs tathā bhūta-viśheṣha-saṅghān brahmāṇam īśhaṁ kamalāsana-stham ṛiṣhīṁśh cha sarvān uragāṁśh cha divyān
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's vision of Krishna's universal form. It emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of the Divine, showing that all beings, from the highest gods to the most humble creatures, are contained within the cosmic body of the Supreme. This revelation highlights the unity of all existence and the omnipresence of the Divine in all forms of life.
shlokas.meaning: O Lord, I see within Your body all the gods and hosts of different beings. I see Lord Brahma seated on the lotus flower, as well as Lord Shiva and all the sages and celestial serpents.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine presence in all beings and things around us. It encourages developing a broader perspective on life, seeing beyond surface differences to the underlying unity. This can foster greater respect, compassion, and harmony in our interactions with others and the environment. It also reminds us of our own divine nature, inspiring us to live up to our highest potential.

shlokas.name: Shloka 16
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अनेकबाहूदरवक्त्रनेत्रं
पश्यामि त्वां सर्वतोऽनन्तरूपम् ।
नान्तं न मध्यं न पुनस्तवादिं
पश्यामि विश्वेश्वर विश्वरूप ॥
shlokas.transliteration: aneka-bāhūdara-vaktra-netraṁ paśyāmi tvāṁ sarvato 'nanta-rūpam nāntaṁ na madhyaṁ na punas tavādiṁ paśyāmi viśveśvara viśva-rūpa
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's vision of Krishna's universal form (Vishwaroop). It emphasizes the infinite, all-encompassing nature of the divine, transcending human comprehension. The verse highlights the concept of God's omnipresence and the limitations of human perception in grasping the totality of the divine.
shlokas.meaning: I see You with countless arms, stomachs, faces, and eyes, extending everywhere without limit. I see no end, middle, or beginning to Your universal form, O Lord of the universe, O universal form.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to broaden our perspective and recognize the interconnectedness of all things. It teaches us to look beyond surface-level appearances and seek a deeper understanding of the world around us. In practical terms, it can inspire us to approach problems with a more holistic view, considering multiple perspectives and recognizing that there may be aspects of a situation that are not immediately apparent to us.

shlokas.name: Shloka 17
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रिणं च
तेजोराशिं सर्वतो दीप्तिमन्तम् |
पश्यामि त्वां दुर्निरीक्ष्यं समन्ताद्
दीप्तानलार्कद्युतिमप्रमेयम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: kirīṭinaṁ gadinaṁ cakriṇaṁ ca tejoraśiṁ sarvato dīptimantam paśyāmi tvāṁ durnirīkṣyaṁ samantād dīptānalārkadyutimaprameyam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's vision of Lord Krishna's cosmic form (Vishwaroop). It emphasizes the overwhelming brilliance and incomprehensible nature of the divine manifestation. The imagery of crown, mace, and discus symbolizes the Lord's supreme authority, power, and all-encompassing nature. The verse highlights the transcendental aspect of divinity that surpasses human perception and understanding.
shlokas.meaning: I see You wearing a crown, carrying a mace and discus, a mass of radiance shining everywhere, difficult to behold, spreading Your immeasurable brilliance all around like the blazing fire or the sun.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the vastness and incomprehensibility of the divine, encouraging humility and awe in our spiritual journey. It reminds us that true understanding often lies beyond our limited perceptions, urging us to expand our consciousness and approach life's challenges with a broader perspective. It also inspires us to seek the divine in all aspects of life, recognizing the extraordinary in the ordinary.

shlokas.name: Shloka 18
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्य-
मनन्तबाहुं शशिसूर्यनेत्रम् ।
पश्यामि त्वां दीप्तहुताशवक्त्रं
स्वतेजसा विश्वमिदं तपन्तम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: anādimadhyāntamanantavīrya-manantabāhuṁ śaśisūryanetram | paśyāmi tvāṁ dīptahutāśavaktraṁ svatejaśā viśvamidaṁ tapantam ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's vision of Lord Krishna's cosmic form (Vishwarupa). It emphasizes the infinite, all-encompassing nature of the Divine, transcending time and space. The imagery of countless arms, sun and moon as eyes, and a blazing mouth symbolizes the omnipresence and omnipotence of the Supreme Being. This revelation challenges human perception of reality and showcases the limitless power of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: I see You without beginning, middle, or end, with infinite power, infinite arms, with the sun and moon as Your eyes, with Your mouth as a blazing fire, scorching the entire universe with Your radiance.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to broaden their perspective and recognize the vastness of the universe and the divine presence within it. It teaches humility in the face of cosmic grandeur and inspires awe for the mysteries of existence. In daily life, it can help people overcome narrow-mindedness, develop a more inclusive worldview, and approach challenges with a sense of cosmic perspective, reducing stress and anxiety about trivial matters.

shlokas.name: Shloka 19
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्यम्
अनन्तबाहुं शशिसूर्यनेत्रम् ।
पश्यामि त्वां दीप्तहुताशवक्त्रं
स्वतेजसा विश्वमिदं तपन्तम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: anādimadhyāntamanantavīryam anantabāhuṁ śaśisūryanetram paśyāmi tvāṁ dīptahutāśavaktraṁ svatejasā viśvamidaṁ tapantam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's vision of Krishna's cosmic form, emphasizing its infinite nature and all-encompassing presence. It highlights the transcendental aspect of the Divine, which is beyond the limitations of time and space. The imagery of countless arms, eyes like the sun and moon, and a face blazing like fire conveys the overwhelming power and omnipresence of the Supreme Being. This vision challenges Arjuna's previous understanding of Krishna and represents a pivotal moment in his spiritual awakening.
shlokas.meaning: I see You without beginning, middle, or end, with infinite power, infinite arms, with the sun and moon as Your eyes, with Your face as a blazing fire, scorching the universe with Your radiance.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to broaden our perspective and recognize the divine presence in all aspects of existence. It teaches us to look beyond the apparent limitations of our physical world and connect with the infinite nature of consciousness. In practical terms, this can help in overcoming fear, developing a sense of unity with all beings, and cultivating humility by recognizing our place within the vast cosmic order. It also inspires awe and reverence, which can lead to a more mindful and respectful approach to life and nature.

shlokas.name: Shloka 20
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
द्यावापृथिव्योरिदमन्तरं हि
व्याप्तं त्वयैकेन दिशश्च सर्वा: |
दृष्ट्वाद्भुतं रूपमुग्रं तवेदं
लोकत्रयं प्रव्यथितं महात्मन् ||
shlokas.transliteration: dyāvāpṛthivyoridamantaraṁ hi vyāptaṁ tvayaikena diśaśca sarvāḥ | dṛṣṭvādbhutaṁ rūpamugraṁ tavedaṁ lokatrayaṁ pravyathitaṁ mahātman ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's awe and fear upon witnessing Krishna's cosmic form (Vishwaroop). It emphasizes the all-pervading nature of the Divine, spanning all directions and dimensions of existence. The shloka highlights the overwhelming power and magnificence of God's universal form, which instills both wonder and terror in the observer. It underscores the limitless nature of the Supreme Being and the insignificance of mortal existence in comparison.
shlokas.meaning: The space between heaven and earth and all directions are pervaded by You alone. Seeing this wonderful and terrible form of Yours, O Great Soul, the three worlds are trembling with fear.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a sense of humility and cosmic perspective. It encourages us to recognize the vastness of the universe and our relatively small place within it, promoting a more balanced and less ego-centric approach to life. It can be applied to overcome personal fears and anxieties by realizing that our individual problems are minuscule in the grand scheme of things. Additionally, it can inspire a deeper respect for nature and the interconnectedness of all existence, promoting environmental consciousness and universal brotherhood.

shlokas.name: Shloka 21
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अमी हि त्वां सुरसङ्घा विशन्ति
केचिद्भीताः प्राञ्जलयो गृणन्ति।
स्वस्तीत्युक्त्वा महर्षिसिद्धसङ्घाः
स्तुवन्ति त्वां स्तुतिभिः पुष्कलाभिः॥
shlokas.transliteration: amī hi tvāṁ surasaṅghā viśanti kecid bhītāḥ prāñjalayo gṛṇanti | svastīty uktvā maharṣisiddhasaṅghāḥ stuvanti tvāṁ stutibhiḥ puṣkalābhiḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the cosmic form of Krishna as witnessed by Arjuna. It portrays the awe-inspiring and fearsome nature of the divine, emphasizing the different reactions of various celestial beings to this manifestation. Some approach with reverence, others with fear, while the great sages offer prayers. This shloka highlights the omnipotence of the Supreme Being and the varying levels of spiritual understanding among different entities.
shlokas.meaning: The hosts of demigods enter into You, and some with folded hands sing Your praises in fear. The great sages and perfected beings exclaim 'Peace be to the universe!' and worship You with elaborate hymns.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to approach the divine with a balance of reverence and love. It reminds us that even in the face of overwhelming power or challenges, maintaining faith and offering our best efforts (like the prayers of the sages) is crucial. In daily life, this can translate to facing difficulties with courage, respecting authority without losing our dignity, and always striving for peace and harmony in our interactions with others and the world around us.

shlokas.name: Shloka 22
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
रुद्रादित्या वसवो ये च साध्या
विश्वेऽश्विनौ मरुतश्चोष्मपाश्च |
गन्धर्वयक्षासुरसिद्धसङ्घा
वीक्षन्ते त्वां विस्मिताश्चैव सर्वे ||
shlokas.transliteration: rudrādityā vasavo ye ca sādhyā viśve'śvinau marutaścoṣmapāśca | gandharvayakṣāsurasiddhasaṅghā vīkṣante tvāṁ vismitāścaiva sarve ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the awe-inspiring cosmic form of Lord Krishna, as witnessed by Arjuna. It emphasizes the universality and all-encompassing nature of the divine, showing how even celestial beings are amazed by this revelation. The verse illustrates the concept of God's omnipresence and the ultimate unity of all existence within the divine.
shlokas.meaning: The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Vishvedevas, the two Ashvins, Maruts, the ancestors, Gandharvas, Yakshas, Asuras, and Siddhas—they are all beholding You in amazement.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine presence in all aspects of existence, encouraging a broader perspective on life. It can help individuals overcome narrow-mindedness and prejudices by realizing the interconnectedness of all beings. In practical terms, this understanding can foster greater respect for diversity, promote environmental consciousness, and inspire a sense of wonder and humility in our daily lives.

shlokas.name: Shloka 23
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
रूपं महत्ते बहुवक्त्रनेत्रं
महाबाहो बहुबाहूरुपादम् ।
बहूदरं बहुदंष्ट्राकरालं
दृष्ट्वा लोकाः प्रव्यथितास्तथाहम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: rūpaṁ mahatte bahuvaktranetraṁ mahābāho bahubāhūrupādam bahūdaraṁ bahudaṁṣṭrākarālaṁ dṛṣṭvā lokāḥ pravyathitāstathāham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's reaction to witnessing Krishna's cosmic form (Vishwaroop). It emphasizes the overwhelming and awe-inspiring nature of the divine manifestation, which is beyond human comprehension. The verse highlights the contrast between the limited human perception and the infinite, all-encompassing nature of the divine, inducing a sense of fear and reverence in the observer.
shlokas.meaning: O mighty-armed one, seeing Your great form with many mouths, eyes, arms, thighs, feet, bellies, and fearsome teeth, the worlds are trembling, and so am I.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the vastness and complexity of the universe and our own limitations in understanding it. It encourages humility in the face of the unknown and respect for forces beyond our control. In daily life, this can be applied by approaching challenges with a sense of reverence, acknowledging that there may be aspects we don't fully comprehend, and remaining open to new perspectives and possibilities beyond our immediate understanding.

shlokas.name: Shloka 24
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
नभःस्पृशं दीप्तमनेकवर्णं
व्यात्ताननं दीप्तविशालनेत्रम् ।
दृष्ट्वा हि त्वां प्रव्यथितान्तरात्मा
धृतिं न विन्दामि शमं च विष्णो ॥
shlokas.transliteration: nabhahsprsam diptam anekavarnam vyattananam diptavisalanetram drstva hi tvam pravyathitantaratma dhrtim na vindami samam ca visno
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's reaction upon witnessing Krishna's cosmic form (Vishwarupa). It emphasizes the overwhelming and awe-inspiring nature of the divine manifestation, which transcends human comprehension. The verse highlights the contrast between mortal limitations and divine infinitude, illustrating the profound impact of direct spiritual experience on the human psyche.
shlokas.meaning: Seeing Your form touching the sky, glowing with many colors, with mouths wide open and large, fiery eyes, I am terrified at heart and can find neither courage nor peace, O Vishnu.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to approach the unknown and the vastness of existence with humility and reverence. It reminds us that there are aspects of reality that may be beyond our current understanding, encouraging open-mindedness and spiritual growth. In facing life's challenges, it suggests that moments of awe and realization can be transformative, pushing us beyond our comfort zones and inspiring personal evolution.

shlokas.name: Shloka 25
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
दंष्ट्राकरालानि च ते मुखानि
दृष्ट्वैव कालानलसन्निभानि।
दिशो न जाने न लभे च शर्म
प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास॥
shlokas.transliteration: daṁṣṭrākarālāni ca te mukhāni dṛṣṭvaiva kālānalasannibhāni | diśo na jāne na labhe ca śarma prasīda deveśa jagannivāsa ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's reaction to witnessing Krishna's cosmic form (Vishwarupa). It emphasizes the overwhelming and terrifying nature of the divine manifestation, highlighting the contrast between human perception and the true nature of the divine. The verse also underscores the importance of divine grace and surrender in the face of the incomprehensible vastness of the universe.
shlokas.meaning: Seeing Your mouths with terrible fangs, blazing like the fires of cosmic dissolution, I lose my sense of direction and find no comfort. O Lord of lords, O abode of the universe, please be gracious to me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to approach life's overwhelming challenges with humility and surrender. When faced with situations beyond our control or understanding, we should seek divine guidance and grace. It reminds us to cultivate a broader perspective on life, acknowledging our limitations and the vastness of the universe. This approach can help in managing stress, anxiety, and feelings of helplessness in difficult times.

shlokas.name: Shloka 26
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अमी च त्वां धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्राः
सर्वे सहैवावनिपालसङ्घैः ।
भीष्मो द्रोणः सूतपुत्रस्तथासौ
सहास्मदीयैरपि योधमुख्यैः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: amī ca tvāṁ dhṛtarāṣṭrasya putrāḥ sarve sahaivāvanipālasaṅghaiḥ bhīṣmo droṇaḥ sūtaputrastathāsau sahāsmadīyairapi yodhamukhyaiḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes Arjuna's vision of the Universal Form of Lord Krishna, where he sees all the warriors of both armies, including the sons of Dhritarashtra, kings, Bhishma, Drona, and Karna, along with the chief warriors of his own side, entering into Krishna's terrifying, all-consuming form. It symbolizes the inevitability of death and the ultimate power of the Divine, transcending human notions of friend and foe.
shlokas.meaning: All the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with the assembled kings, Bhishma, Drona, and Karna, together with the chief warriors on our side, are rushing into Your fearful mouths.
shlokas.life_application: This verse reminds us of the transient nature of life and the ultimate equality of all beings in the face of cosmic reality. It teaches us to transcend petty differences and conflicts, recognizing the divine presence in all. In practical life, this understanding can help us approach conflicts with a broader perspective, reduce ego-driven actions, and cultivate humility and compassion towards others, regardless of perceived differences or enmities.

shlokas.name: Shloka 27
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
वक्त्राणि ते त्वरमाणा विशन्ति
दंष्ट्राकरालानि भयानकानि।
केचिद्विलग्ना दशनान्तरेषु
संदृश्यन्ते चूर्णितैरुत्तमाङ्गैः॥
shlokas.transliteration: vaktrāṇi te tvaramāṇā viśanti daṁṣṭrākarālāni bhayānakāni kecidvilagnā daśanāntareṣu sandṛśyante cūrṇitairuttamāṅgaiḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse vividly describes the cosmic form of Lord Krishna, emphasizing its terrifying and all-consuming nature. It portrays the universal destruction at the end of time, symbolizing the cyclical nature of creation and destruction in Hindu philosophy. The imagery of beings rushing into the Lord's mouths represents the inevitability of death and the ultimate surrender of all existence to the Supreme Being.
shlokas.meaning: All the warriors are rushing and entering swiftly into Your fearful mouths. I see some with crushed heads caught between Your teeth.
shlokas.life_application: This verse reminds us of the transient nature of life and the ultimate power of the divine. It can help individuals face their fears, particularly the fear of death, by understanding that all beings are subject to the same cosmic laws. It encourages humility and surrender to a higher power, promoting a perspective that can reduce ego and attachment to worldly things. In facing life's challenges, one can draw strength from recognizing the larger cosmic order and one's place within it.

shlokas.name: Shloka 28
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यथा नदीनां बहवोऽम्बुवेगाः
समुद्रमेवाभिमुखा द्रवन्ति ।
तथा तवामी नरलोकवीरा
विशन्ति वक्त्राण्यभिविज्वलन्ति ॥
shlokas.transliteration: yathā nadīnāṁ bahavo 'mbuvegāḥ samudram evābhimukhā dravanti | tathā tavāmī naralokavirā viśanti vaktrāṇy abhivijvalanti ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse draws a powerful analogy between rivers flowing into the ocean and warriors entering Krishna's cosmic form. It illustrates the inevitability of fate and the all-consuming nature of the divine. The image of warriors entering the blazing mouths symbolizes the ultimate dissolution of all beings into the supreme reality, emphasizing the transient nature of individual existence and the eternal nature of the divine.
shlokas.meaning: As the many rivers flow rapidly towards the ocean, similarly, these great warriors of the mortal world are entering Your fiery mouths with great speed.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand and accept the inevitability of change and death in life. It encourages embracing the natural flow of existence, letting go of attachments, and recognizing the larger cosmic order. In facing personal challenges or losses, one can find solace in understanding that all things eventually merge with the greater whole, just as rivers merge with the ocean.

shlokas.name: Shloka 29
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यथा प्रदीप्तं ज्वलनं पतङ्गा
विशन्ति नाशाय समृद्धवेगाः ।
तथैव नाशाय विशन्ति लोका-
स्तवापि वक्त्राणि समृद्धवेगाः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: yathā pradīptaṁ jvalanaṁ pataṅgā viśanti nāśāya samṛddhavegāḥ | tathaiva nāśāya viśanti lokās tavāpi vaktrāṇi samṛddhavegāḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse presents a powerful metaphor comparing the fate of all beings to moths drawn to a flame. It illustrates the cosmic form of Krishna as an all-consuming force, emphasizing the inevitability of death and the cyclical nature of existence. The imagery conveys the overwhelming power of the divine and the ultimate insignificance of individual beings in the face of cosmic reality.
shlokas.meaning: As moths rush into a blazing fire to meet their destruction, so do these worlds rush into Your mouths for their annihilation.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand the transient nature of life and the importance of detachment. It encourages acceptance of life's impermanence, prompting us to focus on spiritual growth rather than material pursuits. In facing challenges, one can draw strength from recognizing the larger cosmic order, finding peace in surrendering to the flow of existence rather than resisting inevitable changes.

shlokas.name: Shloka 30
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ग्रसमानः समन्तात्सर्वान्लोकान्वदनैर्ज्वलद्भिः ।
तेजोभिरापूर्य जगत्समग्रं भासस्तवोग्राः प्रतपन्ति विष्णो ॥
shlokas.transliteration: grasamānaḥ samantātsarvānlokānvadanairjvaladbhiḥ | tejobhirāpūrya jagatsamagraṁ bhāsastavogrāḥ pratapanti viṣṇo ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse vividly describes the cosmic form of Lord Krishna, emphasizing His all-encompassing and awe-inspiring nature. It portrays the Lord as consuming all worlds with His flaming mouths, symbolizing the cyclical nature of creation and destruction. The intense radiance emanating from His form represents the divine energy that permeates the entire universe, highlighting the omnipresence and omnipotence of the Supreme Being.
shlokas.meaning: O Vishnu, with Your flaming mouths, You are swallowing all worlds from all directions. Your fierce rays are scorching the entire universe, filling it with Your radiance.
shlokas.life_application: This verse reminds us of the impermanence of worldly existence and the supreme power of the Divine. It encourages individuals to cultivate humility and surrender to a higher power, recognizing our limited role in the grand cosmic scheme. In facing life's challenges, one can draw strength from understanding that everything is part of a larger divine plan, helping to reduce ego and attachment to temporary situations.

shlokas.name: Shloka 31
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
आख्याहि मे को भवानुग्ररूपो
नमोऽस्तु ते देववर प्रसीद।
विज्ञातुमिच्छामि भवन्तमाद्यं
न हि प्रजानामि तव प्रवृत्तिम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: ākhyāhi me ko bhavānugrarūpo namo'stu te devavara prasīda | vijñātum icchāmi bhavantam ādyaṁ na hi prajānāmi tava pravṛttim ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse represents Arjuna's awe and confusion upon witnessing Krishna's cosmic form (Vishwaroop). It highlights the human struggle to comprehend the divine nature and emphasizes the importance of humility and surrender in the face of the supreme reality. The verse also underscores the limitations of human perception and understanding when confronted with the infinite and transcendental aspects of existence.
shlokas.meaning: Arjuna asks Krishna to reveal His identity, bowing in reverence and seeking understanding. He expresses his desire to know the primordial being that Krishna truly is, admitting his inability to comprehend Krishna's actions and manifestations.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to approach life's mysteries and challenges with humility and an open mind. When faced with situations beyond our understanding, we should seek knowledge respectfully, acknowledging our limitations. It encourages us to cultivate curiosity and reverence for the unknown, which can lead to personal growth and spiritual development. In practical terms, this attitude can help in problem-solving, fostering better relationships, and maintaining mental peace in the face of life's complexities.

shlokas.name: Shloka 32
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
कालोऽस्मि लोकक्षयकृत्प्रवृद्धो
लोकान्समाहर्तुमिह प्रवृत्तः।
ऋतेऽपि त्वां न भविष्यन्ति सर्वे
येऽवस्थिताः प्रत्यनीकेषु योधाः॥
shlokas.transliteration: kālo'smi lokakṣayakṛtpravṛddho lokānsamāhartumiha pravṛttaḥ | ṛte'pi tvāṁ na bhaviṣyanti sarve ye'vasthitāḥ pratyanīkeṣu yodhāḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse is a powerful declaration by Krishna, revealing his cosmic form as Time itself, the ultimate destroyer. It emphasizes the inevitability of fate and the supreme power of the Divine. Krishna asserts that he is the force that brings about the end of all worlds, and that the warriors on the battlefield are merely instruments in this grand cosmic plan. This revelation underscores the theme of divine will and the insignificance of individual actions in the face of cosmic destiny.
shlokas.meaning: I am mighty Time, the destroyer of worlds, engaged in destroying all beings. Even without your participation, all the warriors arrayed in the opposing armies shall cease to exist.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand the transient nature of life and the importance of detachment. It encourages acceptance of change and loss as natural parts of existence. In facing personal challenges or losses, one can find solace in recognizing the larger cosmic order at play. It also promotes humility by highlighting the limits of human agency in the face of greater forces, inspiring individuals to focus on their duties without being overly attached to outcomes.

shlokas.name: Shloka 33
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तस्मात्त्वमुत्तिष्ठ यशो लभस्व
जित्वा शत्रून्भुङ्क्ष्व राज्यं समृद्धम् |
मयैवैते निहताः पूर्वमेव
निमित्तमात्रं भव सव्यसाचिन् ||
shlokas.transliteration: tasmāt tvam uttiṣṭha yaśo labhasva jitvā śatrūn bhuṅkṣva rājyaṁ samṛddham mayaivaite nihatāḥ pūrvam eva nimittamātraṁ bhava savyasācin
shlokas.interpretation: This verse encapsulates Krishna's call to action for Arjuna, emphasizing the concept of divine will and the role of humans as instruments of that will. It highlights the importance of fulfilling one's duty (dharma) without attachment to the outcome, as the results are predetermined by the divine. The verse also touches on the philosophical concept of free will versus determinism, suggesting a balance between human effort and divine plan.
shlokas.meaning: Therefore, arise and attain glory. Conquer your enemies and enjoy a prosperous kingdom. These warriors have already been slain by Me. You, O Savyasachin (Arjuna), are merely an instrument.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in situations where one faces difficult decisions or challenging tasks. It encourages taking action without being paralyzed by fear of consequences. In professional life, it teaches to perform one's duties to the best of ability, leaving the results to a higher power. In personal struggles, it provides comfort by suggesting that larger forces are at play, and one's role is to act with integrity and without attachment to outcomes. This perspective can reduce stress and anxiety in decision-making processes and help maintain focus on present actions rather than worrying about future results.

shlokas.name: Shloka 34
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
द्रोणं च भीष्मं च जयद्रथं च
कर्णं तथान्यानपि योधवीरान् ।
मया हतांस्त्वं जहि मा व्यथिष्ठा
युध्यस्व जेतासि रणे सपत्नान् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: droṇaṁ ca bhīṣmaṁ ca jayadrathaṁ ca karṇaṁ tathānyānapi yodhavīrān mayā hatāṁstvaṁ jahi mā vyathiṣṭhā yudhyasva jetāsi raṇe sapatnān
shlokas.interpretation: This verse represents Krishna's assurance to Arjuna about the predetermined outcome of the war. It emphasizes the concept of divine will and the role of individuals as instruments of that will. Krishna is reminding Arjuna that the warriors he's hesitant to fight are already slain by divine decree, and Arjuna's duty is to be the instrument of this divine plan without emotional attachment.
shlokas.meaning: Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and other great warriors have already been slain by Me. Do not be afraid. Fight, and you shall conquer your enemies in battle.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to perform our duties without fear or hesitation, understanding that larger forces are at play beyond our immediate perception. It encourages us to have faith in a higher power or purpose when facing challenging situations. In practical life, this can help in overcoming fear of failure, making difficult decisions, and maintaining composure in high-pressure situations by focusing on our actions rather than the outcomes.

shlokas.name: Shloka 35
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
एतच्छ्रुत्वा वचनं केशवस्य
कृताञ्जलिर्वेपमान: किरीटी |
नमस्कृत्वा भूय एवाह कृष्णं
सगद्गदं भीतभीत: प्रणम्य ||
shlokas.transliteration: etac chrutvā vacanaṁ keśavasya kṛtāñjalir vepamānaḥ kirīṭī namasakṛtvā bhūya evāha kṛṣṇaṁ sagadgadaṁ bhītabhītaḥ praṇamya
shlokas.interpretation: This verse depicts Arjuna's reaction to witnessing Krishna's cosmic form. It illustrates the overwhelming nature of divine revelation and the humbling effect it has on even the most accomplished individuals. The verse emphasizes the importance of reverence and humility in the face of the divine, and how spiritual experiences can profoundly impact one's emotional and physical state.
shlokas.meaning: After hearing these words of Krishna, Arjuna, trembling with folded hands and wearing a crown, bowed down. Overwhelmed with fear, he spoke to Krishna again with a faltering voice, prostrating himself.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to approach life's profound moments with humility and reverence. When faced with overwhelming situations or realizations, it's important to acknowledge our limitations and respond with respect and openness. This attitude can help us navigate challenging experiences, foster personal growth, and deepen our understanding of life's mysteries. It also reminds us to remain humble in the face of knowledge or power, recognizing that there is always something greater than ourselves.

shlokas.name: Shloka 36
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अर्जुन उवाच
स्थाने हृषीकेश तव प्रकीर्त्या
जगत्प्रहृष्यत्यनुरज्यते च |
रक्षांसि भीतानि दिशो द्रवन्ति
सर्वे नमस्यन्ति च सिद्धसङ्घा: ||
shlokas.transliteration: arjuna uvāca sthāne hṛṣīkeśa tava prakīrtyā jagat prahṛṣyaty anurajyate ca rakṣāṁsi bhītāni diśo dravanti sarve namasyanti ca siddhasaṅghāḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse captures Arjuna's awe and reverence for Krishna's cosmic form. It emphasizes the universal impact of the divine manifestation, affecting all beings from the most exalted to the most fearsome. The verse illustrates the concept of bhakti (devotion) and the power of divine glory to inspire both love and fear.
shlokas.meaning: Arjuna says: O Lord of the senses, the world rejoices upon hearing Your name, and all become attached to You. While the perfected beings bow to You, the evil forces flee in fear to all directions.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us about the power of divine presence in our lives. It encourages cultivating a sense of awe and respect for the supreme reality, which can lead to inner peace and spiritual growth. In practical terms, it reminds us to align ourselves with positive forces in life, to respect the power of goodness, and to understand that our actions have far-reaching consequences in the cosmic order.

shlokas.name: Shloka 37
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
कस्माच्च ते न नमेरन्महात्मन्
गरीयसे ब्रह्मणोऽप्यादिकर्त्रे |
अनन्त देवेश जगन्निवास
त्वमक्षरं सदसत्तत्परं यत् ||
shlokas.transliteration: kasmāc ca te na nameran mahātman garīyase brahmaṇo 'py ādikartre | ananta deveśa jagannivāsa tvam akṣaraṁ sad-asat tat paraṁ yat ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse expresses Arjuna's awe and reverence for Krishna's cosmic form. It acknowledges Krishna as the supreme being, greater than even Brahma, the creator. The verse emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of Krishna, describing him as infinite, the lord of all gods, and the abode of the universe. It also touches on the philosophical concept of Krishna being both the manifest and unmanifest, transcending duality.
shlokas.meaning: O Great Soul, why should they not bow to You, who are greater than all and the primal cause, even of Brahma? O infinite Lord of gods, abode of the universe, You are the imperishable, the manifest and unmanifest, and beyond both.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize and revere the divine in all aspects of existence. It encourages humility and surrender to a higher power, which can help in overcoming ego and pride. Understanding our place in the vast cosmic order can provide perspective in dealing with life's challenges and promote a sense of interconnectedness with all beings. It also inspires us to look beyond surface-level differences and recognize the underlying unity in diversity.

shlokas.name: Shloka 38
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
त्वमादिदेवः पुरुषः पुराणस्त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम् ।
वेत्तासि वेद्यं च परं च धाम त्वया ततं विश्वमनन्तरूप ॥
shlokas.transliteration: tvamādidevah purushah purānastvamasya vishvasya param nidhānam vettāsi vedyam cha param cha dhāma tvayā tatam vishvamanantarūpa
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the supreme nature of Krishna as the ultimate, all-encompassing divine being. It portrays Him as the primordial God, the eternal person, and the foundation of the entire universe. The verse also highlights Krishna's omniscience, describing Him as the knower of all that is to be known and the supreme abode. The concept of His infinite forms permeating the entire universe underscores the idea of divine immanence and transcendence simultaneously.
shlokas.meaning: You are the primeval God, the oldest person. You are the ultimate resting place of all the universe. You are the knower, the object of knowledge, and the supreme abode. O Lord of infinite forms, You pervade the entire universe.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a deeper understanding of the interconnectedness of all existence, fostering a sense of unity and respect for all life forms. It encourages seeking knowledge and wisdom, recognizing that the divine permeates everything. In practical terms, it can inspire people to approach life's challenges with humility, knowing that there is a higher power or cosmic order at play. This perspective can lead to reduced ego, increased compassion, and a more holistic approach to problem-solving in personal and professional life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 39
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
वायुर्यमोऽग्निर्वरुण: शशाङ्क:
प्रजापतिस्त्वं प्रपितामहश्च।
नमो नमस्तेऽस्तु सहस्रकृत्व:
पुनश्च भूयोऽपि नमो नमस्ते॥
shlokas.transliteration: vāyur yamo 'gnir varuṇaḥ śaśāṅkaḥ prajāpatis tvaṁ prapitāmahaś ca | namo namas te 'stu sahasrakṛtvaḥ punaś ca bhūyo 'pi namo namas te ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse is part of Arjuna's awe-struck reaction to witnessing Krishna's universal form. It emphasizes the all-encompassing nature of the Divine, equating Krishna with various cosmic forces and deities. The repetitive salutations underscore Arjuna's profound reverence and humility in the face of this overwhelming revelation.
shlokas.meaning: You are the wind, death, fire, water god, the moon, the creator, and the great-grandfather. I offer my obeisances to You a thousand times, and again and again I bow down to You.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine presence in all aspects of existence, fostering a sense of reverence for the world around us. It encourages humility by reminding us of our place within a vast, interconnected universe. In daily life, this perspective can help in developing respect for nature, practicing mindfulness, and approaching challenges with a broader, more spiritual outlook.

shlokas.name: Shloka 40
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
नमः पुरस्तादथ पृष्ठतस्ते
नमोऽस्तु ते सर्वत एव सर्व ।
अनन्तवीर्यामितविक्रमस्त्वं
सर्वं समाप्नोषि ततोऽसि सर्वः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: namaḥ purastād atha pṛṣṭhatas te namo 'stu te sarvata eva sarva | ananta-vīryāmita-vikramas tvaṁ sarvaṁ samāpnoṣi tato 'si sarvaḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse expresses Arjuna's awe and reverence for Krishna's universal form. It acknowledges the omnipresence and omnipotence of the Divine, emphasizing that God pervades all directions and encompasses all of existence. The shloka highlights the infinite power and immeasurable prowess of the Supreme Being, reinforcing the concept of God's all-pervasiveness and ultimate reality.
shlokas.meaning: Salutations to You from the front and the rear, and salutations to You from all sides! O Lord of limitless might, You are the master of infinite power. You pervade everything, and therefore You are everything.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine presence in all aspects of life, encouraging a perspective of reverence and humility. It can help individuals overcome ego and develop a sense of interconnectedness with all beings. In practical terms, this understanding can lead to greater respect for nature, improved interpersonal relationships, and a more holistic approach to problem-solving by considering the broader impact of our actions on the whole.

shlokas.name: Shloka 41
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सखेति मत्वा प्रसभं यदुक्तं
हे कृष्ण हे यादव हे सखेति |
अजानता महिमानं तवेदं
मया प्रमादात्प्रणयेन वापि ||
shlokas.transliteration: sakheti matvā prasabhaṁ yad uktaṁ he kṛṣṇa he yādava he sakheti ajānatā mahimānaṁ tavedaṁ mayā pramādāt praṇayena vāpi
shlokas.interpretation: This verse represents Arjuna's realization and apology for his casual behavior towards Krishna before witnessing His divine form. It highlights the importance of recognizing the divine nature of the Supreme Being and the need for appropriate reverence. The verse also underscores the theme of human limitations in comprehending the true nature of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: O Krishna, whatever I have said carelessly, addressing You as 'O Krishna,' 'O Yadava,' 'O my friend,' without knowing Your glories, either due to negligence or in affection, I beg Your forgiveness for that.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to be mindful of our interactions with others, especially those we respect or who hold authority. It reminds us to avoid taking relationships for granted and to acknowledge our mistakes when we realize them. In professional settings, it encourages maintaining appropriate boundaries and respect, even in familiar relationships. Personally, it promotes self-reflection and the courage to apologize when we've acted inappropriately, fostering better interpersonal relationships and personal growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 42
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
नमो नमस्तेऽस्तु सहस्रकृत्वः
पुनश्च भूयोऽपि नमो नमस्ते।
नमः पुरस्तादथ पृष्ठतस्ते
नमोऽस्तु ते सर्वत एव सर्व॥
shlokas.transliteration: namo namaste'stu sahasrakṛtvaḥ punaśca bhūyo'pi namo namaste | namaḥ purastādatha pṛṣṭhataste namo'stu te sarvata eva sarva ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse represents the pinnacle of Arjuna's devotion and awe upon witnessing Krishna's cosmic form. It emphasizes the importance of complete surrender and reverence to the Divine. The repetitive use of 'namah' (salutations) signifies the overwhelming nature of the divine vision and Arjuna's inability to express his feelings adequately. It also illustrates the omnipresence of the Divine, as Arjuna offers salutations in all directions, recognizing God's all-pervasive nature.
shlokas.meaning: Salutations to You a thousand times, and again salutations, yet again! Salutations to You from the front and the rear, and salutations to You from all sides, O All! You are everything.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of humility and gratitude in our lives. It encourages us to recognize the divine in everything around us, fostering a sense of respect for all creation. In practical terms, this can translate to treating others with kindness and respect, regardless of their status or position. It also reminds us to approach life's challenges with a sense of reverence and acceptance, understanding that there's a greater purpose behind every experience. This attitude can help in reducing stress, improving relationships, and finding inner peace amidst life's complexities.

shlokas.name: Shloka 43
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
पितासि लोकस्य चराचरस्य
त्वमस्य पूज्यश्च गुरुर्गरीयान् ।
न त्वत्समोऽस्त्यभ्यधिकः कुतोऽन्यो
लोकत्रयेऽप्यप्रतिमप्रभाव ॥
shlokas.transliteration: pitāsi lokasya carācarasya tvamasya pūjyaśca gururgarīyān na tvatsamo'styabhyadhikaḥ kuto'nyo lokatraye'pyapratimaprabhāva
shlokas.interpretation: This verse represents Arjuna's realization of Krishna's supreme cosmic form. It acknowledges Krishna as the ultimate father, teacher, and most worshipable being in all of existence. The verse emphasizes the incomparable nature of Krishna's power and influence across all three worlds, highlighting the concept of God's omnipresence and supremacy in Hindu philosophy.
shlokas.meaning: You are the father of this moving and unmoving creation, the greatest teacher and the most worshipable. No one is equal to You, so how can there be anyone greater than You in all three worlds? Your power is unparalleled and incomparable.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize and respect the divine in all aspects of life. It encourages humility and devotion, reminding us that there is always a higher power guiding the universe. In practical terms, it can help individuals develop a sense of cosmic connection, reducing ego and promoting a more harmonious approach to relationships and challenges in life. It also emphasizes the importance of respecting teachers and elders, as they represent divine wisdom in human form.

shlokas.name: Shloka 44
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तस्मात्प्रणम्य प्रणिधाय कायं
प्रसादये त्वामहमीशमीड्यम् ।
पितेव पुत्रस्य सखेव सख्युः
प्रियः प्रियायार्हसि देव सोढुम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: tasmātpraṇamya praṇidhāya kāyaṁ prasādaye tvāmahamīśamīḍyam pitevaputrasya sakheva sakhyuḥ priyaḥ priyāyārhasi deva soḍhum
shlokas.interpretation: This verse represents Arjuna's humble surrender to Krishna's cosmic form. It illustrates the complex relationship between the devotee and the divine, encompassing various aspects of human relationships like father-son, friend-friend, and lover-beloved. The verse emphasizes the importance of complete submission and seeking forgiveness, while also highlighting the multifaceted nature of the divine-human connection.
shlokas.meaning: Therefore, bowing down and prostrating my body before You, I seek Your grace, O adorable Lord. As a father forgives his son, a friend forgives his friend, or a lover forgives his beloved, please, O Divine One, forgive my transgressions.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of humility and seeking forgiveness in our relationships, both with the divine and with fellow humans. It encourages us to approach conflicts and misunderstandings with a spirit of reconciliation, recognizing that forgiveness is a divine quality. In professional settings, it reminds leaders to be compassionate and understanding, fostering an environment of trust and mutual respect. On a personal level, it inspires us to cultivate deeper, more meaningful relationships by being willing to admit our faults and seek reconciliation.

shlokas.name: Shloka 45
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अदृष्टपूर्वं हृषितोऽस्मि दृष्ट्वा
भयेन च प्रव्यथितं मनो मे।
तदेव मे दर्शय देवरूपं
प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास॥
shlokas.transliteration: adṛṣṭapūrvaṁ hṛṣito'smi dṛṣṭvā bhayena ca pravyathitaṁ mano me tadeva me darśaya devarūpaṁ prasīda deveśa jagannivāsa
shlokas.interpretation: This verse captures Arjuna's complex emotional state upon witnessing Krishna's cosmic form. It illustrates the human response to the divine - a mixture of awe, joy, and fear. Arjuna's request to see Krishna's familiar form again demonstrates the human need for a relatable, comprehensible image of the divine, even after experiencing its vast, incomprehensible nature.
shlokas.meaning: Having seen what was never seen before, I am delighted, yet my mind is troubled with fear. Show me that form of yours as God again. O God of gods, O abode of the universe, be gracious.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to balance our pursuit of spiritual growth with our human limitations. While seeking higher truths and experiences, we should also acknowledge our need for familiarity and comfort. It encourages us to approach the unknown with courage, but also reminds us that it's okay to seek reassurance and return to what we know when overwhelmed. In life, this can apply to personal growth, career changes, or any situation where we're pushing our boundaries - it's important to challenge ourselves, but also to know when to step back and regroup.

shlokas.name: Shloka 46
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रहस्तम्
इच्छामि त्वां द्रष्टुमहं तथैव |
तेनैव रूपेण चतुर्भुजेन
सहस्रबाहो भव विश्वमूर्ते ||
shlokas.transliteration: kirīṭinaṁ gadinaṁ cakrahastam icchāmi tvāṁ draṣṭumahaṁ tathaiva tenaiva rūpeṇa caturbhujena sahasrabāho bhava viśvamūrte
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in Arjuna's experience of Krishna's cosmic form. Overwhelmed by the terrifying vision of the Universal Form, Arjuna expresses his desire to see Krishna in His familiar four-armed form. This request signifies Arjuna's preference for a more personal and relatable aspect of the Divine, highlighting the human tendency to seek comfort in the familiar even when faced with the ultimate reality.
shlokas.meaning: O thousand-armed one, O Universal Form, I wish to see You in Your four-armed form, with a crown, holding a mace and discus. Please manifest Yourself in that form again.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us about the importance of finding a balance between understanding the vastness of the universe and maintaining a personal connection with the divine. In life, we often face overwhelming situations that can make us feel small and insignificant. However, like Arjuna, we can seek comfort in a more relatable and personal aspect of our beliefs or values. This approach can help us navigate complex situations while maintaining our emotional and spiritual equilibrium.

shlokas.name: Shloka 47
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मया प्रसन्नेन तवार्जुनेदं
रूपं परं दर्शितमात्मयोगात् |
तेजोमयं विश्वमनन्तमाद्यं
यन्मे त्वदन्येन न दृष्टपूर्वम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: mayā prasannena tavārjunedaṁ rūpaṁ paraṁ darśitamātmayogāt | tejomayaṁ viśvamanantamādyaṁ yanme tvadanyena na dṛṣṭapūrvam ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita where Lord Krishna reveals His cosmic form to Arjuna. It emphasizes the special grace bestowed upon Arjuna and the uniqueness of this divine vision. The verse highlights the supreme nature of God's universal form, which is described as radiant, infinite, and primordial. It underscores the rarity and privilege of such a divine revelation, indicating that this vision is not accessible through ordinary means but only through God's grace and the power of yoga.
shlokas.meaning: By My grace and through My divine yoga power, O Arjuna, I have shown you this supreme, radiant, universal, infinite, and primordial form, which no one else has ever seen before.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us about the power of divine grace and the importance of spiritual practice. In life, we often seek profound experiences or insights. This shloka reminds us that true spiritual enlightenment comes not just from our efforts, but also through divine grace. It encourages us to cultivate a relationship with the divine through devotion and yoga, while remaining open to unexpected revelations. It also teaches humility, reminding us that there are aspects of reality beyond our normal perception, encouraging a sense of wonder and respect for the mysteries of existence.

shlokas.name: Shloka 48
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
न वेदयज्ञाध्ययनैर्न दानै-
र्न च क्रियाभिर्न तपोभिरुग्रैः ।
एवंरूपः शक्य अहं नृलोके
द्रष्टुं त्वदन्येन कुरुप्रवीर ॥
shlokas.transliteration: na vedayajñādhyayanair na dānair na ca kriyābhir na tapobhir ugraiḥ | evaṁrūpaḥ śakya ahaṁ nṛloke draṣṭuṁ tvadanyena kurupravīra ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the extraordinary nature of Krishna's cosmic form and the impossibility of perceiving it through conventional means. It highlights the supremacy of divine grace over human efforts in spiritual realization. The verse also underscores the unique position of Arjuna, who has been granted this vision not through his own merits but through Krishna's favor.
shlokas.meaning: Neither by the study of the Vedas and sacrifices, nor by charity, nor by rituals, nor by severe austerities can I be seen in this cosmic form in the human world by anyone other than you, O great hero of the Kurus.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of humility and surrender in spiritual pursuit. It reminds us that while personal efforts are necessary, ultimate spiritual realization comes through divine grace. In daily life, this principle can be applied by balancing hard work with faith, and by recognizing that some achievements are beyond our control and require a higher intervention. It encourages us to persist in our endeavors while remaining open to unexpected blessings and insights that transcend our limited understanding.

shlokas.name: Shloka 49
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मा ते व्यथा मा च विमूढभावो
दृष्ट्वा रूपं घोरमीदृङ्ममेदम् |
व्यपेतभीः प्रीतमनाः पुनस्त्वं
तदेव मे रूपमिदं प्रपश्य ||
shlokas.transliteration: mā te vyathā mā ca vimūḍhabhāvo dṛṣṭvā rūpaṁ ghoramīdṛṅmamedam vyapetabhīḥ prītamanāḥ punastvam tadeva me rūpamidaṁ prapaśya
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita where Krishna, having shown Arjuna His cosmic form, now comforts him. It illustrates the compassionate nature of the Divine, who recognizes the limitations of human perception and offers reassurance. The verse also emphasizes the importance of overcoming fear and confusion when faced with the overwhelming aspects of reality, encouraging a return to a state of love and devotion.
shlokas.meaning: Do not be fearful or bewildered by seeing this terrible form of Mine. Be free from fear and with a joyful heart, behold again My familiar form.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied to situations where we face overwhelming challenges or truths that seem beyond our comprehension. It teaches us to approach life's difficulties with courage and faith, knowing that behind the apparent chaos and complexity, there is a benevolent force. In personal growth, it encourages us to confront our fears and limitations, trusting that we will emerge stronger and more enlightened. In leadership roles, it reminds us to be compassionate towards those who may be intimidated by change or new responsibilities, offering reassurance and guidance.

shlokas.name: Shloka 50
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सञ्जय उवाच
इत्यर्जुनं वासुदेवस्तथोक्त्वा
स्वकं रूपं दर्शयामास भूयः।
आश्वासयामास च भीतमेनं
भूत्वा पुनः सौम्यवपुर्महात्मा॥
shlokas.transliteration: sañjaya uvāca ityarjunaṁ vāsudevas tathoktvā svakaṁ rūpaṁ darśayām āsa bhūyaḥ āśvāsayām āsa ca bhītam enaṁ bhūtvā punaḥ saumyavapur mahātmā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a pivotal moment in the Bhagavad Gita, where Krishna transitions from his cosmic form back to his familiar human-like appearance. It highlights the compassionate nature of the Divine, who recognizes and responds to the devotee's emotional state. The verse also underscores the concept of divine grace, as Krishna willingly reveals and conceals his true nature to guide Arjuna's spiritual journey.
shlokas.meaning: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Arjuna, Krishna revealed his own gentle form again. He reassured the frightened Arjuna by assuming his pleasing form once more.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us about the importance of adapting our approach when guiding or leading others. Just as Krishna shifted his form to comfort Arjuna, we too should be sensitive to others' emotional states and adjust our communication style accordingly. It also reminds us that in times of fear or uncertainty, we can find solace in familiar and comforting presences, whether spiritual or personal. Furthermore, it encourages us to balance awe-inspiring experiences with gentleness and compassion in our interactions with others.

shlokas.name: Shloka 51
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
दृष्ट्वेदं मानुषं रूपं तव सौम्यं जनार्दन।
इदानीमस्मि संवृत्तः सचेताः प्रकृतिं गतः॥
shlokas.transliteration: dṛṣṭvedaṁ mānuṣaṁ rūpaṁ tava saumyaṁ janārdana idānīmasmi saṁvṛttaḥ sacetāḥ prakṛtiṁ gataḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks a significant moment in Arjuna's spiritual journey. After witnessing Krishna's cosmic form, Arjuna is relieved to see Krishna return to his gentle human form. This transition symbolizes the accessibility of the divine, showing that while God's universal form is awe-inspiring, His personal form is what allows for intimate connection and devotion. It also highlights the importance of balance between understanding God's supremacy and relating to Him personally.
shlokas.meaning: O Janardana, seeing this gentle human form of Yours, I have now become composed and have returned to my normal state.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us about managing overwhelming experiences and finding balance. In life, we may encounter situations that shake us to our core, much like Arjuna's vision of the cosmic form. The lesson here is to seek and appreciate the familiar and comforting aspects of our spiritual practice or relationships to regain our composure. It encourages us to cultivate a personal, intimate connection with the divine or our higher principles, which can serve as an anchor during turbulent times. This approach can help in stress management, dealing with existential crises, and maintaining emotional stability in the face of life's profound experiences.

shlokas.name: Shloka 52
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
सुदुर्दर्शमिदं रूपं दृष्टवानसि यन्मम ।
देवा अप्यस्य रूपस्य नित्यं दर्शनकाङ्क्षिण: ॥
shlokas.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca sudurdarśam idaṁ rūpaṁ dṛṣṭavān asi yan mama devā apy asya rūpasya nityaṁ darśana-kāṅkṣiṇaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the rarity and significance of Arjuna's divine vision. Lord Krishna reveals that even the gods constantly yearn to witness this cosmic form, highlighting the exceptional nature of Arjuna's experience. It underscores the profound spiritual privilege granted to Arjuna and the immense grace of the Divine in revealing its true nature to a devoted seeker.
shlokas.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: This form of Mine which you have seen is very difficult to behold. Even the gods are ever eager to see this form.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to cultivate deep devotion and spiritual practices, as they can lead to profound spiritual experiences. It teaches us to appreciate rare spiritual insights when they occur and to remain humble in our spiritual journey. In daily life, it reminds us to seek and value the extraordinary in the ordinary, to be open to moments of divine revelation in our everyday experiences, and to persist in our spiritual endeavors despite challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 53
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
नाहं वेदैर्न तपसा न दानेन न चेज्यया ।
शक्य एवंविधो द्रष्टुं दृष्टवानसि मां यथा ॥
shlokas.transliteration: nāhaṁ vedair na tapasā na dānena na cejyayā śakya evaṁvidho draṣṭuṁ dṛṣṭavānasi māṁ yathā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the supremacy of divine grace over ritualistic practices or intellectual pursuits in attaining a vision of God's cosmic form. Krishna states that the magnificent form Arjuna has witnessed cannot be seen through conventional means of spiritual practice or knowledge acquisition. It underscores the importance of devotion and divine favor in experiencing the highest spiritual truths.
shlokas.meaning: Neither by the study of the Vedas, nor by austerities, nor by charity, nor by rituals can I be seen in this cosmic form as you have seen Me.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us that while spiritual practices and knowledge are important, they are not sufficient for the highest spiritual realizations. It encourages us to cultivate sincere devotion and surrender to the divine, reminding us that in our spiritual journey, grace plays a crucial role. In practical life, this can be applied by balancing our efforts with faith, humility, and openness to divine guidance, rather than relying solely on our own abilities or rigid practices.

shlokas.name: Shloka 54
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
भक्त्या त्वनन्यया शक्य अहमेवंविधोऽर्जुन |
ज्ञातुं द्रष्टुं च तत्त्वेन प्रवेष्टुं च परन्तप ||
shlokas.transliteration: bhaktyā tv ananyayā śakya aham evaṁvidho 'rjuna | jñātuṁ draṣṭuṁ ca tattvena praveṣṭuṁ ca parantapa ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the supreme importance of unwavering devotion (bhakti) in realizing the Divine. Krishna reveals that only through single-minded devotion can one truly understand, see, and enter into His cosmic form. It highlights the power of bhakti as a means to transcend the limitations of human perception and intellect, enabling a direct, experiential understanding of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: Only through unwavering devotion, O Arjuna, can I be known, seen in this form, and truly entered into.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us the importance of dedication and single-minded focus in achieving our goals. In our personal and professional lives, we can apply this principle by cultivating unwavering commitment to our chosen path. Whether it's in relationships, career, or personal growth, maintaining steadfast devotion and eliminating distractions can lead to deeper understanding, clearer vision, and ultimate success in our endeavors.

shlokas.name: Shloka 55
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मत्कर्मकृन्मत्परमो मद्भक्त: सङ्गवर्जित: |
निर्वैर: सर्वभूतेषु य: स मामेति पाण्डव ||
shlokas.transliteration: mat-karma-kṛn mat-paramo mad-bhaktaḥ saṅga-varjitaḥ nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣu yaḥ sa mām eti pāṇḍava
shlokas.interpretation: This verse encapsulates the essence of devotion and the path to attain Krishna. It outlines the qualities of a true devotee who can reach the Divine. The verse emphasizes the importance of selfless action, devotion, detachment, and universal love as key elements in spiritual progress. It suggests that by embodying these qualities, one can transcend the material world and unite with the Supreme.
shlokas.meaning: One who performs all actions for Me, who considers Me the Supreme, who is devoted to Me, free from attachment, and without enmity toward any being, comes to Me, O Pandava.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in daily life by encouraging individuals to perform their duties with a sense of devotion, viewing work as worship. It teaches the importance of maintaining equanimity and avoiding hatred or resentment towards others. By cultivating detachment from the fruits of one's actions and fostering universal love, one can lead a more peaceful and spiritually fulfilling life. This approach can help in managing stress, improving relationships, and finding purpose in one's actions.
