shlokas.name: Shloka 1
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
परं भूयः प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञानानां ज्ञानमुत्तमम् ।
यज्ज्ञात्वा मुनयः सर्वे परां सिद्धिमितो गताः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: śrī-bhagavān uvāca paraṁ bhūyaḥ pravakṣyāmi jñānānāṁ jñānam uttamam yaj jñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṁ siddhim ito gatāḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse marks the beginning of Chapter 14, where Lord Krishna introduces the highest knowledge among all forms of knowledge. It emphasizes the supreme importance of understanding the three gunas (modes of material nature) and their influence on the embodied soul. Krishna suggests that this knowledge is so profound that it has led all sages to attain the highest perfection. The verse sets the stage for a deeper exploration of the nature of existence and the path to liberation.
shlokas.meaning: The Supreme Lord said: I shall again declare to you this supreme wisdom, the best of all knowledge, knowing which all the sages have attained the highest perfection.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to seek the highest form of knowledge for personal growth and spiritual evolution. It can be applied in life by motivating one to pursue deeper understanding of the self and the nature of reality. This pursuit can lead to better decision-making, reduced attachment to material outcomes, and a more balanced approach to life's challenges. By understanding the influence of the gunas on our thoughts and actions, we can work towards achieving a state of equilibrium and eventually transcend the material modes altogether, leading to inner peace and spiritual advancement.

shlokas.name: Shloka 2
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
इदं ज्ञानमुपाश्रित्य मम साधर्म्यमागताः ।
सर्गेऽपि नोपजायन्ते प्रलये न व्यथन्ति च ॥
shlokas.transliteration: idaṁ jñānam upāśritya mama sādharmyam āgatāḥ | sarge 'pi nopajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the transformative power of spiritual knowledge. Krishna explains that those who attain this knowledge become one with His nature, transcending the cycle of birth and death. It highlights the ultimate goal of spiritual practice: liberation from the material world and union with the Divine. The verse also implies that this knowledge leads to a state of equanimity, where one is unaffected by the cosmic cycles of creation and dissolution.
shlokas.meaning: Those who take refuge in this knowledge attain My nature. They are not born at the time of creation, nor do they suffer at the time of dissolution.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied to overcome fear of death and existential anxiety. By cultivating spiritual knowledge and understanding our true nature beyond the physical body, we can face life's challenges with greater courage and peace. It encourages us to focus on inner growth and self-realization rather than being overly concerned with worldly achievements or losses. This perspective can help in maintaining emotional balance during both success and failure, and in developing a sense of purpose that transcends material existence.

shlokas.name: Shloka 3
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मम योनिर्महद्ब्रह्म तस्मिन्गर्भं दधाम्यहम् |
सम्भवः सर्वभूतानां ततो भवति भारत ||
shlokas.transliteration: mama yonir mahad brahma tasmin garbhaṁ dadhāmy aham sambhavaḥ sarvabhūtānāṁ tato bhavati bhārata
shlokas.interpretation: This verse reveals the cosmic process of creation, emphasizing the role of Brahman (the Supreme) as the source of all existence. Krishna describes himself as the father who impregnates the womb of Brahman (prakriti or material nature) with the seeds of all living entities. This illustrates the interplay between the divine masculine and feminine principles in the creation of the universe, highlighting the fundamental duality in nature while asserting the ultimate unity of all existence in the Supreme.
shlokas.meaning: The great Brahman is My womb, and in it I place the seed. From this comes the birth of all beings, O Bharata.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to recognize the divine origin of all beings, fostering a sense of unity and equality among all life forms. It can help in developing a more compassionate and inclusive worldview, reducing discrimination and promoting environmental stewardship. Understanding our common source can also lead to greater self-awareness and a deeper connection with the universe, potentially alleviating feelings of isolation or meaninglessness in life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 4
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सर्वयोनिषु कौन्तेय मूर्तयः सम्भवन्ति याः।
तासां ब्रह्म महद्योनिरहं बीजप्रदः पिता॥
shlokas.transliteration: sarvayoniṣu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ sambhavanti yāḥ | tāsāṁ brahma mahadyonirahaṁ bījapradaḥ pitā ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the universal nature of creation and the divine role in it. It establishes Krishna (the Supreme Being) as the ultimate father of all creation, while Prakriti (material nature) is seen as the mother. This concept underlines the fundamental duality in creation - the interplay between consciousness (Purusha) and matter (Prakriti). It also highlights the omnipresence of the divine in all forms of existence.
shlokas.meaning: O son of Kunti, for all species of life that are produced, the material nature is the womb, and I am the seed-giving father.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals develop a sense of unity with all life forms, fostering compassion and respect for nature and all beings. It encourages seeing the divine in everything, which can lead to a more harmonious and less judgmental approach to life. Understanding one's spiritual essence can also boost self-worth and promote a sense of responsibility towards the world, as we recognize our connection to the supreme consciousness.

shlokas.name: Shloka 5
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसम्भवाः।
निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनमव्ययम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: sattvam rajas tama iti gunah prakritisambhavah nibadhnanti mahabaho dehe dehinam avyayam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the three gunas (qualities) that are fundamental to Samkhya philosophy and Vedantic thought. It explains how these gunas, which originate from prakriti (nature), bind the eternal soul to the physical body. The verse emphasizes the pervasive influence of these qualities on all aspects of material existence and how they affect the consciousness of living entities.
shlokas.meaning: Sattva (goodness), rajas (passion), and tamas (ignorance) are the qualities born of nature. They bind the imperishable soul to the body, O mighty-armed Arjuna.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the three gunas helps in self-awareness and personal growth. By recognizing which qualities dominate our thoughts and actions, we can make conscious efforts to cultivate more sattva (goodness) in our lives. This knowledge can be applied to improve decision-making, manage emotions, and develop a more balanced and harmonious lifestyle. It also encourages us to transcend these material qualities altogether, aiming for spiritual liberation.

shlokas.name: Shloka 6
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम् ।
सुखसङ्गेन बध्नाति ज्ञानसङ्गेन चानघ ॥
shlokas.transliteration: tatra sattvaṁ nirmalatvāt prakāśakam anāmayam sukha-saṅgena badhnāti jñāna-saṅgena cānagha
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the nature of sattva guna, one of the three fundamental qualities in Vedic philosophy. It emphasizes sattva's purity and illuminating nature, while also pointing out its potential to bind the soul through attachment to happiness and knowledge. This paradox highlights the subtle nature of spiritual bondage, where even positive qualities can become obstacles to ultimate liberation if one becomes attached to them.
shlokas.meaning: Among these, sattva, being pure, is illuminating and free from evil. It binds through attachment to happiness and knowledge, O sinless one.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life by recognizing that even positive traits and experiences can become hindrances to personal growth if we become overly attached to them. It encourages a balanced approach to self-improvement, where we cultivate positive qualities while remaining aware of the potential for attachment. In practical terms, this might mean pursuing knowledge and happiness, but not allowing them to become sources of ego or complacency, and remaining open to new perspectives and experiences.

shlokas.name: Shloka 7
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम् ।
तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: rajo rāgātmakaṁ viddhi tṛṣṇāsaṅgasamudbhavam tannibadhnāti kaunteya karmasaṅgena dehinam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the nature of the rajas guna, one of the three fundamental qualities in Vedic philosophy. It emphasizes how rajas, characterized by passion and desire, binds the embodied soul to action and material attachments. The verse highlights the cyclical nature of desire, attachment, and action, showing how rajas perpetuates the cycle of karma and rebirth.
shlokas.meaning: Know that rajas is of the nature of passion, giving rise to craving and attachment. It binds the embodied soul through attachment to action, O son of Kunti.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the influence of rajas can help individuals recognize and manage their desires and attachments. By cultivating awareness of how passion-driven actions can lead to bondage, one can strive for balance in life, making more conscious choices that are not solely driven by desire or ambition. This knowledge can be applied to improve decision-making, reduce stress from unfulfilled desires, and foster a more balanced approach to work, relationships, and personal goals.

shlokas.name: Shloka 8
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
तमो रजस्तमश्चैव सत्त्वं प्रकृतिसम्भवाः।
निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनमव्ययम्॥
shlokas.transliteration: tamo rajastamascaiva sattvam prakrtisambhavah nibadhnanti mahabaho dehe dehinamavyayam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of the three gunas (qualities) of nature - tamas, rajas, and sattva - and their binding effect on the eternal soul within the body. It emphasizes the pervasive influence of these qualities on all beings and highlights the challenge faced by the soul in transcending these material influences.
shlokas.meaning: The three qualities born of nature - ignorance, passion, and goodness - bind the imperishable soul to the body, O mighty-armed Arjuna.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the three gunas helps in self-awareness and personal growth. By recognizing which qualities dominate our thoughts and actions, we can work towards cultivating more sattva (goodness) in our lives. This knowledge can be applied to manage emotions, make better decisions, and progress spiritually by gradually transcending the influence of these material qualities.

shlokas.name: Shloka 9
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जयति रजः कर्मणि भारत।
ज्ञानमावृत्य तु तमः प्रमादे सञ्जयत्युत॥
shlokas.transliteration: sattvam sukhe sañjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde sañjayatyuta
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the effects of the three gunas (qualities of nature) on human behavior and consciousness. Sattva, associated with purity and knowledge, leads to happiness and contentment. Rajas, linked with passion and activity, drives one towards action and attachment to work. Tamas, representing ignorance and inertia, clouds one's judgment and leads to negligence and delusion. The verse emphasizes the importance of understanding these gunas and their influence on our lives to achieve spiritual growth and self-realization.
shlokas.meaning: Sattva attaches one to happiness, rajas to action, O Bharata, while tamas, veiling knowledge, binds one to negligence.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the three gunas can help individuals identify their dominant qualities and work towards balancing them. By cultivating more sattva, one can increase happiness and clarity of mind. Recognizing the influence of rajas can help in managing stress and overactivity. Awareness of tamas can motivate one to overcome laziness and ignorance. This knowledge can be applied in personal development, stress management, decision-making, and spiritual growth, leading to a more balanced and fulfilling life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 10
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
रजस्तमश्चाभिभूय सत्त्वं भवति भारत।
रजः सत्त्वं तमश्चैव तमः सत्त्वं रजस्तथा॥
shlokas.transliteration: rajas tamaś cābhibhūya sattvaṁ bhavati bhārata | rajaḥ sattvaṁ tamaś caiva tamaḥ sattvaṁ rajas tathā ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the dynamic interplay between the three gunas (sattva, rajas, and tamas) in nature and human consciousness. It illustrates how these qualities are in constant flux, with one guna temporarily dominating the others at different times. This understanding is crucial for spiritual aspirants to recognize the ever-changing nature of their mental states and to strive for a higher state of consciousness beyond the influence of the gunas.
shlokas.meaning: O Bharata (Arjuna), sometimes sattva dominates by subduing rajas and tamas; at other times rajas dominates by subduing sattva and tamas; and still at other times tamas dominates by subduing sattva and rajas.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the fluctuating nature of the gunas can help individuals become more self-aware and better manage their emotions and behaviors. By recognizing which guna is dominant at any given time, one can make conscious efforts to cultivate more sattvic qualities, leading to greater peace, clarity, and spiritual growth. This knowledge can be applied in stress management, decision-making, and personal development, enabling one to navigate life's challenges with greater wisdom and equanimity.

shlokas.name: Shloka 11
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन्प्रकाश उपजायते।
ज्ञानं यदा तदा विद्याद्विवृद्धं सत्त्वमित्युत॥
shlokas.transliteration: sarvadvāreṣu dehe'smin prakāśa upajāyate | jñānaṁ yadā tadā vidyād vivṛddhaṁ sattvam ityuta ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the manifestation of sattva guna (mode of goodness) in an individual. When sattva increases, it illuminates all the gates (senses) of the body with knowledge and understanding. This illumination is metaphorical, representing clarity of thought, purity of mind, and spiritual awareness. The verse emphasizes the importance of cultivating sattva for spiritual growth and self-realization.
shlokas.meaning: When the light of knowledge illuminates all the gates of the body, it should be known that sattva (goodness) is predominant.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life by consciously cultivating sattva through practices like meditation, study of scriptures, and maintaining a pure lifestyle. By increasing sattva, one can improve decision-making abilities, enhance mental clarity, and progress on the spiritual path. It encourages individuals to seek knowledge and understanding in all aspects of life, leading to better self-awareness and more harmonious relationships with others and the environment.

shlokas.name: Shloka 12
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
लोभः प्रवृत्तिरारम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा ।
रजस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे भरतर्षभ ॥
shlokas.transliteration: lobhaḥ pravṛttirārambhaḥ karmaṇāmaśamaḥ spṛhā | rajasyetāni jāyante vivṛddhe bharatarṣabha ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the characteristics that manifest when the mode of passion (rajas) predominates in an individual. It highlights how rajas leads to increased material desires, restlessness, and attachment to action. The verse emphasizes the cyclical nature of rajasic qualities, as they tend to reinforce and amplify each other, potentially trapping an individual in a cycle of constant activity and desire.
shlokas.meaning: Greed, intense activity, undertaking of new projects, restlessness, and intense desire arise when the quality of passion increases, O best of the Bharatas.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the influence of rajas can help individuals recognize patterns of excessive ambition, workaholism, or constant dissatisfaction in their lives. By being aware of these tendencies, one can strive for balance by cultivating more sattvic qualities like contentment and mindfulness. This knowledge can be applied to manage stress, improve decision-making, and develop a more balanced approach to work and personal goals.

shlokas.name: Shloka 13
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्च प्रमादो मोह एव च।
तमस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे कुरुनन्दन॥
shlokas.transliteration: aprakāśo'pravṛttiśca pramādo moha eva ca tamasyetāni jāyante vivṛddhe kurunandana
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the manifestations of tamas guna (the mode of ignorance) when it predominates in an individual. It highlights how tamas leads to a lack of clarity, inaction, carelessness, and delusion. The verse emphasizes the importance of recognizing these qualities to overcome the influence of tamas and progress spiritually.
shlokas.meaning: When the mode of ignorance (tamas) increases, O son of Kuru, it gives rise to darkness of mind, inertness, negligence, and delusion.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the qualities of tamas can help individuals identify periods of low motivation, confusion, or lethargy in their lives. By recognizing these symptoms, one can take proactive steps to counteract tamas, such as engaging in physical exercise, seeking knowledge, practicing meditation, or surrounding oneself with positive influences. This awareness can lead to improved decision-making, increased productivity, and better mental health in daily life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 14
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सत्त्वे प्रवृद्धे तु प्रलयं याति देहभृत् |
उत्तमविदां लोकानमलान्प्रतिपद्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration: sattve pravṛddhe tu pralayaṁ yāti dehabhṛt uttamavidāṁ lokān amalān pratipadyate
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of cultivating sattva guna (mode of goodness) and its effects on one's afterlife. It suggests that those who die when sattva is predominant attain higher realms of existence, implying a connection between one's mental state at death and their future destination. The verse also emphasizes the purity and superiority of sattvik realms, encouraging spiritual aspirants to cultivate sattva in their lives.
shlokas.meaning: When one dies in the state of goodness, they attain the pure worlds of those who have the highest knowledge.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied to cultivate a positive and pure mindset in daily life, knowing that our mental state influences our future. It encourages individuals to engage in activities that promote sattva, such as meditation, study of scriptures, and selfless service. In facing life's challenges, one can strive to maintain a sattvic outlook, which can lead to better decision-making, peace of mind, and spiritual growth. It also motivates people to be mindful of their thoughts and actions, especially during critical moments, as they can have far-reaching consequences.

shlokas.name: Shloka 15
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम् ।
तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: rajo rāgātmakaṁ viddhi tṛṣṇāsaṅgasamudbhavam tannibadhnāti kaunteya karmasaṅgena dehinam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the nature and effects of the rajas guna, one of the three fundamental qualities in Vedic philosophy. It emphasizes how rajas, characterized by passion and desire, binds the embodied soul to action and material attachments. The verse highlights the cyclical nature of desire, attachment, and action, illustrating how rajas perpetuates the cycle of karma and rebirth.
shlokas.meaning: Know that rajas is of the nature of passion, giving rise to craving and attachment. It binds the embodied soul through attachment to action, O son of Kunti.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the influence of rajas can help individuals recognize and manage their desires and attachments. By cultivating awareness of how passion-driven actions lead to further entanglement in material life, one can strive for balance and detachment. This knowledge can be applied to make more conscious choices, reduce impulsive behavior, and work towards spiritual growth by gradually reducing the dominance of rajas in one's life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 16
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
कर्मणः सुकृतस्याहुः सात्त्विकं निर्मलं फलम् |
रजसस्तु फलं दुःखमज्ञानं तमसः फलम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: karmaṇaḥ sukṛtasyāhuḥ sāttvikaṁ nirmalaṁ phalam rajastu phalaṁ duḥkhamajñānaṁ tamasaḥ phalam
shlokas.interpretation: This verse elucidates the consequences of actions influenced by the three gunas (modes of material nature). It emphasizes that actions performed under the influence of sattva (goodness) yield pure and beneficial results, while those driven by rajas (passion) lead to suffering, and actions rooted in tamas (ignorance) result in delusion and lack of knowledge. This shloka underscores the importance of cultivating sattvic qualities to achieve spiritual growth and inner peace.
shlokas.meaning: The fruit of good action is said to be sattvic and pure. The fruit of passionate action is pain, while the fruit of ignorant action is darkness and delusion.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can guide individuals in making conscious choices in their daily lives. By understanding the nature of their actions and their consequences, one can strive to cultivate more sattvic qualities, such as calmness, clarity, and purity of thought. This can lead to better decision-making, reduced stress and anxiety, improved relationships, and overall personal growth. In professional settings, it encourages ethical behavior and long-term thinking over short-term gains driven by passion or ignorance.

shlokas.name: Shloka 17
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च |
प्रमादमोहौ तमसो भवतोऽज्ञानमेव च ||
shlokas.transliteration: sattvāt sañjāyate jñānaṁ rajaso lobha eva ca | pramāda-mohau tamaso bhavato 'jñānam eva ca ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse delineates the distinct qualities that arise from the three gunas (modes of material nature). It emphasizes how sattva guna leads to knowledge and clarity, while rajas guna results in greed and attachment. Tamas guna, being the lowest, produces negative qualities like carelessness, delusion, and ignorance. This shloka provides insight into the psychological and spiritual effects of these fundamental forces of nature on human consciousness and behavior.
shlokas.meaning: From sattva arises knowledge, from rajas arises greed, and from tamas arise negligence, delusion, and ignorance.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding the influence of these gunas can help individuals identify the dominant forces in their lives and make conscious efforts to cultivate more sattvik qualities. By recognizing the source of negative emotions and behaviors (rajas and tamas), one can work towards developing more balanced, peaceful, and enlightened states of being. This knowledge can be applied in personal development, stress management, decision-making processes, and in fostering healthier relationships by being aware of the underlying qualities influencing oneself and others.

shlokas.name: Shloka 18
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ऊर्ध्वं गच्छन्ति सत्त्वस्था मध्ये तिष्ठन्ति राजसाः।
जघन्यगुणवृत्तिस्था अधो गच्छन्ति तामसाः॥
shlokas.transliteration: ūrdhvaṁ gacchanti sattvasthā madhye tiṣṭhanti rājasāḥ jaghanya-guṇa-vṛtti-sthā adho gacchanti tāmasāḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the consequences of the three gunas (modes of material nature) on the soul's journey. It illustrates how one's predominant guna influences their spiritual progress and future incarnations. The shloka emphasizes the importance of cultivating sattva guna for spiritual advancement and warns against the detrimental effects of tamas guna.
shlokas.meaning: Those situated in the mode of goodness gradually go upward to the higher planets; those in the mode of passion live on the earthly planets; and those in the abominable mode of ignorance go down to the lower planets.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to cultivate sattvic qualities like purity, knowledge, and harmony to progress spiritually and improve their life circumstances. It motivates people to overcome tamasic tendencies like ignorance and laziness, which can lead to degradation. In daily life, one can apply this teaching by consciously choosing activities, thoughts, and associations that promote sattva, thus enhancing personal growth, mental clarity, and overall well-being.

shlokas.name: Shloka 19
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
नान्यं गुणेभ्यः कर्तारं यदा द्रष्टानुपश्यति |
गुणेभ्यश्च परं वेत्ति मद्भावं सोऽधिगच्छति ||
shlokas.transliteration: nānyaṁ guṇebhyaḥ kartāraṁ yadā draṣṭānupaśyati guṇebhyaśca paraṁ vetti madbhāvaṁ so'dhigacchati
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of transcending the three gunas (modes of material nature) and recognizing the Supreme Being as the ultimate source of all actions. It suggests that true spiritual realization comes when one sees beyond the material qualities and understands the divine nature that pervades everything.
shlokas.meaning: When the seer realizes that there is no doer other than the three gunas, and knows That which is beyond these gunas, he attains My nature.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life by helping individuals detach from the outcomes of their actions and the influence of material qualities. It encourages developing a higher perspective on life's events, reducing stress and anxiety by understanding that ultimate control lies beyond our limited selves. This realization can lead to greater peace, equanimity, and spiritual growth in facing life's challenges.

shlokas.name: Shloka 20
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
गुणानेतानतीत्य त्रीन्देही देहसमुद्भवान् |
जन्ममृत्युजरादुःखैर्विमुक्तोऽमृतमश्नुते ||
shlokas.transliteration: guṇān etān atītya trīn dehī deha-samudbhavān janma-mṛtyu-jarā-duḥkhair vimukto 'mṛtam aśnute
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the state of transcendence beyond the three gunas (modes of material nature). It suggests that when an embodied soul rises above the influences of sattva, rajas, and tamas, which are responsible for the creation of the physical body, they become free from the cycle of birth, death, old age, and the associated sufferings. This transcendental state leads to the experience of immortality or the eternal spiritual nature.
shlokas.meaning: When the embodied being transcends these three gunas that originate in the body, they are freed from birth, death, old age, and all sorrows, and attain immortality.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to strive for spiritual growth beyond material attachments. In practical life, one can apply this teaching by cultivating awareness of how the gunas influence thoughts and actions, and gradually working towards detachment from these material influences. This can lead to reduced stress, anxiety, and fear of death, promoting a more peaceful and purposeful existence focused on spiritual evolution rather than material pursuits.

shlokas.name: Shloka 21
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
कार्यकारणकर्तृत्वे हेतुः प्रकृतिरुच्यते।
पुरुषः सुखदुःखानां भोक्तृत्वे हेतुरुच्यते॥
shlokas.transliteration: kāryakāraṇakartṛtve hetuḥ prakṛtirucyate puruṣaḥ sukhaduḥkhānāṁ bhoktṛtve heturucyate
shlokas.interpretation: This verse delineates the relationship between Prakriti (Nature) and Purusha (Soul) in the context of human experience. It explains that Prakriti is responsible for the chain of cause and effect in the material world, while Purusha is the experiencer of the resulting pleasures and pains. This distinction is crucial in understanding the Sankhya philosophy that underlies much of the Gita's teachings, highlighting the interplay between the active principle (Prakriti) and the conscious observer (Purusha).
shlokas.meaning: Nature is said to be the cause in the creation of effects and causes; the soul is said to be the cause in the experience of pleasure and pain.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals detach from the outcomes of their actions and the experiences of pleasure and pain. By recognizing that our true self (Purusha) is distinct from the workings of nature (Prakriti), we can cultivate a sense of equanimity in the face of life's ups and downs. This perspective can be particularly useful in managing stress, overcoming attachment to results, and maintaining emotional balance in challenging situations.

shlokas.name: Shloka 22
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
प्रकाशं च प्रवृत्तिं च मोहमेव च पाण्डव |
न द्वेष्टि सम्प्रवृत्तानि न निवृत्तानि काङ्क्षति ||
shlokas.transliteration: prakāśaṁ ca pravṛttiṁ ca moham eva ca pāṇḍava | na dveṣṭi sampravṛttāni na nivṛttāni kāṅkṣati ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the characteristics of a person who has transcended the three gunas (modes of material nature). Such a person remains equanimous in all situations, neither hating unfavorable circumstances nor craving for favorable ones. They maintain a balanced perspective, unaffected by the fluctuations of the material world, embodying true spiritual wisdom.
shlokas.meaning: O Pandava, one who neither hates illumination, activity, and delusion when they are present, nor longs for them when they are absent.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to cultivate emotional balance and detachment in our daily lives. By not getting overly excited during good times or depressed during challenging times, we can maintain mental peace and clarity. This approach helps in making better decisions, reducing stress, and fostering personal growth. It encourages us to accept life's ups and downs with grace, focusing on our inner development rather than external circumstances.

shlokas.name: Shloka 23
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
उदासीनवदासीनो गुणैर्यो न विचाल्यते।
गुणा वर्तन्त इत्येव योऽवतिष्ठति नेङ्गते॥
shlokas.transliteration: udāsīnavadāsīno guṇairyo na vicālyate | guṇā vartanta ityeva yo'vatiṣṭhati neṅgate ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the state of a person who has transcended the three gunas (modes of material nature). Such an individual remains detached and unaffected by the fluctuations of the gunas, maintaining a state of equanimity. They understand that it is only the gunas that are operating in the material world, and this knowledge allows them to remain steadfast in their spiritual consciousness.
shlokas.meaning: One who sits as a neutral observer, unshaken by the qualities of nature, knowing that the qualities alone are active, and remains steady and unmoved.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life to maintain emotional balance and mental peace amidst challenging situations. By cultivating a witness consciousness, one can avoid being overly affected by success or failure, praise or criticism. This approach helps in making more objective decisions, reducing stress, and maintaining focus on one's spiritual growth regardless of external circumstances.

shlokas.name: Shloka 24
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
समदुःखसुखः स्वस्थः समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः।
तुल्यप्रियाप्रियो धीरस्तुल्यनिन्दात्मसंस्तुतिः॥
shlokas.transliteration: sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ svasthaḥ sama-loṣṭāśma-kāñcanaḥ tulya-priyāpriyo dhīras tulya-nindātma-saṁstutiḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the qualities of a person who has transcended the three gunas (modes of material nature). Such a person is equanimous in all situations, treating pleasure and pain, praise and blame, and even different materials like gold and stone with equal regard. This state of mind represents spiritual maturity and detachment from worldly dualities.
shlokas.meaning: One who is steady and equipoised in happiness and distress, who regards a clod of earth, a stone, and gold as of equal value, who is equal toward the desirable and the undesirable, who is steady, and who treats alike both blame and praise.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to cultivate emotional stability and mental equilibrium in our daily lives. By practicing detachment from external circumstances and maintaining a balanced perspective, we can reduce stress, make better decisions, and achieve inner peace. It encourages us to focus on our inner growth rather than being swayed by external praise, criticism, or material possessions, leading to a more fulfilling and purposeful life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 25
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मानापमानयोस्तुल्यस्तुल्यो मित्रारिपक्षयोः ।
सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी गुणातीतः स उच्यते ॥
shlokas.transliteration: mānāpamānayos tulyas tulyo mitrāripakṣayoḥ sarvārambhaparityāgī guṇātītaḥ sa ucyate
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the characteristics of a person who has transcended the three gunas (modes of material nature). Such a person remains equanimous in honor and dishonor, treats friends and enemies alike, and has renounced all selfish initiatives. This state represents spiritual evolution beyond the influence of material qualities, indicating a high level of self-realization and detachment from worldly dualities.
shlokas.meaning: One who is equal in honor and dishonor, balanced towards friends and enemies, and who has renounced all selfish undertakings is said to have transcended the qualities of nature.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to cultivate emotional stability and mental equilibrium in the face of life's ups and downs. By practicing non-attachment to outcomes, treating all beings with equal respect, and focusing on selfless service rather than personal gain, we can overcome stress, anxiety, and conflict in our daily lives. This approach leads to inner peace, better relationships, and a more purposeful existence aligned with spiritual growth.

shlokas.name: Shloka 26
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्तियोगेन सेवते।
स गुणान्समतीत्यैतान्ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते॥
shlokas.transliteration: mām ca yo'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate | sa guṇān samatītyaitān brahmabhūyāya kalpate ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the power of unwavering devotion (bhakti yoga) as a means to transcend the three gunas of material nature. It suggests that through single-minded devotion to the Supreme, one can overcome the influence of sattva, rajas, and tamas, and become eligible for liberation or union with Brahman. The verse highlights the superiority of bhakti yoga as a spiritual practice that can lead to the highest spiritual realization.
shlokas.meaning: One who serves Me with unswerving devotion, transcends these three gunas and becomes qualified to attain the state of Brahman.
shlokas.life_application: This teaching can be applied in daily life by cultivating unwavering focus and dedication in one's spiritual practices or chosen path. It encourages individuals to develop a consistent, devoted attitude in their pursuits, whether spiritual or worldly. By maintaining steady devotion and avoiding distractions, one can overcome the fluctuations of the mind and emotions, leading to greater peace, clarity, and progress in all aspects of life. This principle can help in overcoming obstacles, maintaining motivation, and achieving long-term goals.

shlokas.name: Shloka 27
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ब्रह्मणो हि प्रतिष्ठाहममृतस्याव्ययस्य च |
शाश्वतस्य च धर्मस्य सुखस्यैकान्तिकस्य च ||
shlokas.transliteration: brahmano hi pratishthāham amritasyāvyayasya cha shāshvatasya cha dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya cha
shlokas.interpretation: This verse establishes Krishna as the ultimate foundation of Brahman, the eternal, imperishable, and absolute. It emphasizes that Krishna is not only the source of the impersonal Brahman but also the origin of immortality, eternal dharma, and absolute bliss. This shloka is crucial in understanding the supremacy of Krishna in Vedantic philosophy, bridging the gap between personal and impersonal aspects of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: I am the basis of the impersonal Brahman, which is immortal, imperishable, eternal, and is the foundation of ultimate happiness and everlasting dharma.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages seekers to recognize the divine presence in all aspects of existence, fostering a sense of unity and purpose. It can help individuals find stability and peace by connecting with the eternal and unchanging aspect of reality amidst life's fluctuations. By understanding oneself as part of this supreme reality, one can cultivate inner strength, maintain ethical conduct (dharma), and work towards lasting happiness and fulfillment in life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 1
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ऊर्ध्वमूलमधःशाखमश्वत्थं प्राहुरव्ययम् ।
छन्दांसि यस्य पर्णानि यस्तं वेद स वेदवित् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: ūrdhva-mūlam adhaḥ-śākham aśvatthaṁ prāhur avyayam chandāṁsi yasya parṇāni yas taṁ veda sa veda-vit
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of the inverted cosmic tree, symbolizing the material world. The roots above represent the Supreme Being, while the branches below signify the manifested universe. This imagery conveys the interconnectedness of all existence and the divine origin of creation. The reference to Vedic hymns as leaves emphasizes the importance of spiritual knowledge in understanding this cosmic structure.
shlokas.meaning: There is an imperishable banyan tree with its roots upward and branches below. Its leaves are the Vedic hymns. One who knows this tree is the knower of the Vedas.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to seek a deeper understanding of our existence and its connection to the divine. It teaches us to look beyond the apparent physical reality and recognize the spiritual essence that permeates all things. In practical terms, this can help us develop a more holistic worldview, make decisions with greater awareness of their far-reaching consequences, and cultivate respect for all forms of life and knowledge.

shlokas.name: Shloka 2
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा
गुणप्रवृद्धा विषयप्रवालाः ।
अधश्च मूलान्यनुसन्ततानि
कर्मानुबन्धीनि मनुष्यलोके ॥
shlokas.transliteration: adhaś cordhvaṁ prasṛtās tasya śākhā guṇapravṛddhā viṣayapravālāḥ adhaś ca mūlāny anusantatāni karmānubandhīni manuṣyaloke
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the complex nature of material existence using the metaphor of an inverted banyan tree. The branches, representing the various manifestations of material nature, grow both upwards and downwards, nourished by the three gunas (modes of material nature). The twigs symbolize sense objects that entice living beings. The roots, extending downwards into the human world, represent the karmic bonds that tie individuals to the cycle of birth and death. This imagery illustrates the intricate web of material existence and the challenge of transcending it.
shlokas.meaning: The branches of this tree extend below and above, nourished by the three gunas, with sense objects as its twigs. Below, its roots stretch into the world of humans, bound by the chains of karmic actions.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages self-reflection on our attachments and actions in the material world. It reminds us to be mindful of how our desires and actions create karmic bonds, potentially trapping us in cycles of suffering. By understanding this complex web of material existence, we can strive to detach ourselves from sensory pleasures and focus on spiritual growth. In practical terms, this might involve practicing mindfulness, cultivating dispassion towards material objects, and performing actions without attachment to their fruits, thus gradually freeing ourselves from the binding nature of karma.

shlokas.name: Shloka 3
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते
नान्तो न चादिर्न च सम्प्रतिष्ठा ।
अश्वत्थमेनं सुविरूढमूल-
मसङ्गशस्त्रेण दृढेन छित्त्वा ॥
shlokas.transliteration: na rūpam asyeha tathopalabhyate nānto na cādir na ca sampratiṣṭhā aśvattham enaṁ suvirūḍha-mūlam asaṅga-śastreṇa dṛḍhena chittvā
shlokas.interpretation: This verse uses the metaphor of the Ashvattha tree to describe the nature of material existence. It emphasizes the illusory and ever-changing nature of the world, which has no discernible beginning, end, or stable foundation. The verse suggests that to break free from this cycle, one must use the weapon of detachment to cut through the deeply rooted attachments to the material world.
shlokas.meaning: The form of this tree cannot be perceived here in this world, nor its end, nor its origin, nor its foundation. Having cut down this firmly rooted Ashvattha tree with the strong axe of detachment,
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the transient nature of worldly experiences and attachments. By cultivating detachment, we can free ourselves from unnecessary worries, fears, and desires tied to material pursuits. This approach helps in maintaining emotional balance, making clearer decisions, and focusing on spiritual growth. It encourages us to seek a deeper, more permanent reality beyond the ever-changing material world, leading to inner peace and true fulfillment.

shlokas.name: Shloka 4
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ततः पदं तत्परिमार्गितव्यं
यस्मिन्गता न निवर्तन्ति भूयः ।
तमेव चाद्यं पुरुषं प्रपद्ये
यतः प्रवृत्तिः प्रसृता पुराणी ॥
shlokas.transliteration: tataḥ padaṁ tatparimārgitavyaṁ yasmin gatā na nivartanti bhūyaḥ | tam eva cādyaṁ puruṣaṁ prapadye yataḥ pravṛttiḥ prasṛtā purāṇī ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the ultimate goal of spiritual seekers - to attain the supreme state from which there is no return to the cycle of birth and death. It highlights the importance of surrendering to the Primordial Person, the source of all creation, as the means to reach this state. The shloka underscores the eternal nature of the cosmic manifestation and the significance of seeking refuge in the Divine to transcend the material realm.
shlokas.meaning: One must seek that supreme state, having gone to which, they never return. I take refuge in that primeval Purusha from whom has streamed forth the eternal activity of creation.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied to overcome the fear of death and the cycle of rebirth by encouraging individuals to focus on spiritual growth and self-realization. It teaches the importance of detachment from material pursuits and attachment to the Divine, which can help in reducing stress and anxiety in daily life. The concept of taking refuge in the Supreme can provide emotional stability and a sense of purpose, guiding one's actions towards higher spiritual goals and ethical living.

shlokas.name: Shloka 5
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा
अध्यात्मनित्या विनिवृत्तकामाः ।
द्वन्द्वैर्विमुक्ताः सुखदुःखसंज्ञैर्
गच्छन्त्यमूढाः पदमव्ययं तत् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: nirmānamohā jitasaṅgadoṣā adhyātmanityā vinivṛttakāmāḥ dvandvairvimuktāḥ sukhaduḥkhasaṁjñair gacchantyamūḍhāḥ padamavyayaṁ tat
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the qualities of those who have attained spiritual enlightenment and are ready to reach the eternal abode. It emphasizes the importance of overcoming ego, attachments, and desires, while maintaining a constant focus on self-realization. The verse also highlights the state of equanimity achieved by such individuals, who are no longer affected by the dualities of pleasure and pain.
shlokas.meaning: Those who are free from false prestige, illusion, and false association, who understand the eternal, who are done with material lust, who are freed from the dualities of happiness and distress, and who, unbewildered, know how to surrender unto the Supreme Person attain to that eternal kingdom.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to cultivate humility, overcome attachments, and focus on spiritual growth. In daily life, we can apply these teachings by practicing mindfulness, letting go of ego-driven desires, and maintaining emotional balance in the face of life's ups and downs. By developing these qualities, we can find inner peace and make progress on our spiritual journey, leading to a more fulfilling and purposeful life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 6
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः।
यद्गत्वा न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम॥
shlokas.transliteration: na tad bhāsayate sūryo na śaśāṅko na pāvakaḥ yad gatvā na nivartante tad dhāma paramaṁ mama
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the supreme abode of the Divine, which is beyond the reach of material illumination. It emphasizes the transcendental nature of the spiritual realm, which is self-luminous and eternal. The verse suggests that once a soul reaches this supreme abode, it attains liberation and does not return to the material world, highlighting the finality and perfection of spiritual realization.
shlokas.meaning: Neither the sun, nor the moon, nor fire can illuminate that supreme abode of Mine. Having gone there, one does not return to this material world.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to seek spiritual enlightenment beyond material pursuits. It can be applied to overcome attachment to worldly pleasures and possessions, inspiring one to focus on inner growth and self-realization. The teaching can help in developing detachment from temporary situations and maintaining equanimity in the face of life's challenges, knowing that ultimate peace lies in spiritual attainment.

shlokas.name: Shloka 7
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः।
मनःषष्ठानीन्द्रियाणि प्रकृतिस्थानि कर्षति॥
shlokas.transliteration: mamaivāṁśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ manaḥṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛtisthāni karṣati
shlokas.interpretation: This verse establishes the eternal relationship between the individual soul (jiva) and the Supreme Being. It emphasizes that each living entity is a fragmental part of the Divine, possessing the same spiritual quality. However, due to its conditioned state in the material world, the soul struggles with the senses and the mind, which are rooted in material nature. This highlights the soul's dual nature - divine in essence but bound by materiality in its conditioned state.
shlokas.meaning: The eternal individual soul in this world of living beings is a fragment of My own self. In its conditioned state, it struggles with the six senses, including the mind, which are rooted in material nature.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals recognize their inherent divine nature and the root cause of their struggles. By realizing that our true self is beyond the material body and mind, we can work towards detachment from sensory pleasures and mental fluctuations. This knowledge encourages spiritual practices like meditation and self-inquiry to reconnect with our divine essence. It also promotes a sense of unity with all beings, as we recognize everyone as part of the same Divine source, fostering compassion and reducing ego-driven conflicts.

shlokas.name: Shloka 8
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वर: ।
गृहीत्वैतानि संयाति वायुर्गन्धानिवाशयात् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: śarīraṁ yad avāpnoti yac cāpy utkrāmatīśvaraḥ gṛhītvaitāni saṁyāti vāyur gandhān ivāśayāt
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the process of transmigration of the soul. It illustrates how the soul, referred to as 'Ishvara' (the lord of the body), carries the subtle body (consisting of mind, intelligence, and false ego) from one physical body to another. The analogy of the wind carrying aromas is used to explain this subtle process, emphasizing the imperceptible nature of the soul's journey.
shlokas.meaning: When the soul acquires a new body and when it leaves the old one, it carries the subtle body with it, just as the wind carries aromas from their source.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this concept can help individuals develop detachment from the physical body and focus on spiritual growth. It encourages one to cultivate positive thoughts and actions, as these mental impressions are carried forward. This knowledge can provide comfort during loss, as it suggests the continuity of consciousness beyond death, and motivate ethical living to ensure a better future incarnation.

shlokas.name: Shloka 9
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च |
अधिष्ठाय मनश्चायं विषयानुपसेवते ||
shlokas.transliteration: śrotraṁ cakṣuḥ sparśanaṁ ca rasanaṁ ghrāṇameva ca adhiṣṭhāya manaścāyaṁ viṣayānupasevate
shlokas.interpretation: This verse describes the relationship between the soul, the senses, and the mind. It emphasizes that the soul, while residing in the body, experiences the world through the five senses and the mind. This highlights the concept of the soul as the observer and experiencer, while the senses and mind act as instruments for worldly interactions. The verse also implies the subtle nature of the soul's presence in the body and its role in consciousness.
shlokas.meaning: The soul, while situated in this body, uses the ears, eyes, sense of touch, tongue, and nose, as well as the mind, to experience various sense objects.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals understand the nature of their experiences and perceptions. By recognizing that the soul is distinct from the senses and mind, one can cultivate detachment from sensory experiences and mental fluctuations. This awareness can lead to better emotional regulation, reduced stress, and increased mindfulness in daily life. It also encourages individuals to look beyond surface-level experiences and seek deeper spiritual understanding.

shlokas.name: Shloka 10
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
उत्क्रामन्तं स्थितं वापि भुञ्जानं वा गुणान्वितम् ।
विमूढा नानुपश्यन्ति पश्यन्ति ज्ञानचक्षुषः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: utkrāmantaṁ sthitaṁ vāpi bhuñjānaṁ vā guṇānvitam vimūḍhā nānupaśyanti paśyanti jñānacakṣuṣaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the contrast between the spiritually enlightened and the deluded. It emphasizes that the Supreme Self (Paramatma) is present in all states of existence, but only those with spiritual wisdom can perceive this truth. The verse underscores the importance of developing spiritual knowledge to understand the omnipresence of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: The deluded do not perceive the soul as it departs from the body, or as it dwells within, or as it experiences the senses. Those with the eyes of knowledge can see this.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages us to cultivate spiritual wisdom to see beyond material appearances. In daily life, it can be applied by developing mindfulness and awareness of the divine presence in all situations. It teaches us to look beyond surface-level judgments and seek a deeper understanding of ourselves and others, fostering compassion and reducing prejudice. This perspective can help in dealing with life's challenges by maintaining a broader, more spiritual outlook.

shlokas.name: Shloka 11
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यतन्तो योगिनश्चैनं पश्यन्त्यात्मन्यवस्थितम् |
यतन्तोऽप्यकृतात्मानो नैनं पश्यन्त्यचेतसः ||
shlokas.transliteration: yatanto yoginaścainaṁ paśyantyātmanyavasthitam yatanto'pyakṛtātmāno nainaṁ paśyantyacetasaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse highlights the contrast between those who have attained spiritual realization and those who have not. It emphasizes the importance of self-discipline, spiritual practice, and purification of the mind in perceiving the divine presence within oneself. The verse suggests that mere effort without proper spiritual development is insufficient for experiencing the ultimate truth.
shlokas.meaning: Striving yogis perceive the Self established within; but the unrefined and unintelligent, even though striving, fail to see it.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to engage in sincere spiritual practices and self-purification to develop the ability to perceive the divine within. It teaches that mere intellectual understanding or half-hearted efforts are not enough for spiritual growth. To solve life's existential questions and find inner peace, one must commit to consistent spiritual practice, cultivate self-awareness, and purify the mind through meditation, self-reflection, and righteous living.

shlokas.name: Shloka 12
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यदादित्यगतं तेजो जगद्भासयतेऽखिलम् |
यच्चन्द्रमसि यच्चाग्नौ तत्तेजो विद्धि मामकम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: yadādityagataṁ tejo jagad bhāsayate'khilam | yaccandramasi yaccāgnau tattejo viddhi māmakam ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the omnipresence and all-pervasive nature of the Supreme Being. It illustrates that the divine energy is present in all sources of light and illumination in the universe. By attributing the radiance of the sun, moon, and fire to Himself, Krishna is conveying His supreme position as the source of all energy and brilliance in creation. This verse also hints at the concept of Brahman, the all-encompassing absolute reality in Vedantic philosophy.
shlokas.meaning: The light which is in the sun and illuminates the whole world, and that which is in the moon and in fire - know that all that light is Mine.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can help individuals recognize the divine presence in all aspects of life, fostering a sense of reverence for nature and the universe. It encourages people to see beyond the physical world and recognize the underlying spiritual essence in everything. This understanding can lead to greater environmental consciousness, respect for all forms of life, and a more harmonious existence. It also promotes humility by reminding us that our own brilliance and capabilities are ultimately derived from a higher source.

shlokas.name: Shloka 13
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
गाम् आविश्य च भूतानि धारयाम्यहम् ओजसा ।
पुष्णामि चौषधीः सर्वाः सोमो भूत्वा रसात्मकः ॥
shlokas.transliteration: gām āviśya ca bhūtāni dhārayāmyaham ojasā puṣṇāmi cauṣadhīḥ sarvāḥ somo bhūtvā rasātmakaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse illustrates the all-pervasive nature of the Supreme Being, emphasizing His role in sustaining and nourishing all life forms. It depicts the divine presence in the most fundamental aspects of existence, from the earth's core to the essence of plant life. The verse also highlights the interconnectedness of all beings and the cosmic order, showing how the Divine supports and maintains the entire creation through His energy.
shlokas.meaning: Entering the earth, I support all beings with My energy. Becoming the nourishing moon, I feed all plants with their essential juices.
shlokas.life_application: This verse teaches us to recognize the divine presence in all aspects of nature and life. It encourages a holistic and respectful approach to the environment, reminding us of our interconnectedness with all beings. In daily life, it can inspire us to be more conscious of our actions and their impact on others and the world around us. It also promotes gratitude for the sustenance we receive from nature and the importance of preserving ecological balance.

shlokas.name: Shloka 14
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
अहं वैश्वानरो भूत्वा प्राणिनां देहमाश्रितः ।
प्राणापानसमायुक्तः पचाम्यन्नं चतुर्विधम् ॥
shlokas.transliteration: ahaṁ vaiśvānaro bhūtvā prāṇināṁ deham āśritaḥ prāṇāpāna-samāyuktaḥ pacāmy annaṁ catur-vidham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse reveals Krishna's cosmic form as the digestive fire within all living beings. It emphasizes the interconnectedness of all life and the divine presence in even the most basic bodily functions. The verse also alludes to the concept of Brahman pervading all aspects of existence, from the cosmic to the microcosmic level.
shlokas.meaning: I am the fire of digestion in every living body, and I am the incoming and outgoing breath. I am united with the prana and apana, and I digest the four kinds of food.
shlokas.life_application: This verse reminds us to be mindful of our body's processes and to treat our physical form with respect as it houses the divine. It encourages gratitude for the food we consume and the life-sustaining processes within us. In practice, this can lead to better dietary habits, mindful eating, and a deeper appreciation for the interconnectedness of all life, promoting both physical and spiritual well-being.

shlokas.name: Shloka 15
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो
मत्त: स्मृतिर्ज्ञानमपोहनं च |
वेदैश्च सर्वैरहमेव वेद्यो
वेदान्तकृद्वेदविदेव चाहम् ||
shlokas.transliteration: sarvasya cāhaṁ hṛdi sanniviṣṭo mattaḥ smṛtir jñānam apohanaṁ ca vedaiś ca sarvair aham eva vedyo vedānta-kṛd veda-vid eva cāham
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the omnipresence and omniscience of the Supreme Being. It highlights that the divine consciousness resides in the hearts of all beings, guiding their memory, knowledge, and reasoning. The Supreme Being is the source of all wisdom, including the Vedas, and is the ultimate goal of all spiritual knowledge.
shlokas.meaning: I am seated in the hearts of all beings, and from Me come memory, knowledge, and forgetfulness. I am the object of knowledge in all the Vedas, the author of Vedanta, and the knower of the Vedas.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to recognize the divine presence within themselves and others, fostering respect and compassion. It emphasizes the importance of seeking knowledge and wisdom from within, trusting one's intuition, and understanding that true knowledge comes from aligning with the divine consciousness. In daily life, this can be applied by cultivating self-awareness, practicing mindfulness, and approaching learning with humility and openness.

shlokas.name: Shloka 16
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
द्वाविमौ पुरुषौ लोके क्षरश्चाक्षर एव च |
क्षरः सर्वाणि भूतानि कूटस्थोऽक्षर उच्यते ||
shlokas.transliteration: dvāvimau puruṣau loke kṣaraścākṣara eva ca | kṣaraḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni kūṭastho'kṣara ucyate ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of two types of beings in the universe: the perishable (kshara) and the imperishable (akshara). It emphasizes the fundamental duality in creation and points towards the ultimate reality beyond both these categories. The verse sets the stage for understanding the nature of the Supreme Being, which transcends both the mutable and immutable aspects of existence.
shlokas.meaning: There are two types of beings in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All created beings are perishable, while the unchanging is called imperishable.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals gain perspective on the impermanent nature of worldly experiences and material possessions, encouraging detachment and spiritual growth. It can also provide solace in times of loss by reminding us of the eternal, unchanging aspect of existence. This knowledge can guide one to focus on cultivating inner peace and seeking higher truths beyond the transient aspects of life.

shlokas.name: Shloka 17
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
उत्तमः पुरुषस्त्वन्यः परमात्मेत्युदाहृतः।
यो लोकत्रयमाविश्य बिभर्त्यव्यय ईश्वरः॥
shlokas.transliteration: uttamaḥ puruṣas tv anyaḥ paramātmety udāhṛtaḥ | yo loka-trayam āviśya bibharty avyaya īśvaraḥ ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse introduces the concept of the Supreme Person, who is distinct from both the fallible and infallible beings mentioned in previous verses. It emphasizes the transcendental nature of the Paramatma (Supreme Soul) who pervades and sustains the three worlds. This verse highlights the omnipresence and omnipotence of the Supreme Being, establishing His superiority over all other entities in existence.
shlokas.meaning: But distinct from these is the Supreme Person, who is called the Paramatma (Supreme Soul). He is the imperishable Lord who enters the three worlds and sustains them.
shlokas.life_application: Understanding this verse can help individuals develop a broader perspective on existence, recognizing a higher power that permeates and sustains all of creation. It encourages seeking connection with this Supreme Being for guidance and support in life's challenges. This knowledge can foster a sense of humility, interconnectedness, and responsibility towards all beings, as well as provide comfort in difficult times by reminding us of the presence of a supreme, sustaining force in the universe.

shlokas.name: Shloka 18
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यस्मात्क्षरमतीतोऽहमक्षरादपि चोत्तमः।
अतोऽस्मि लोके वेदे च प्रथितः पुरुषोत्तमः॥
shlokas.transliteration: yasmāt kṣaram atīto 'ham akṣarād api cottamaḥ ato 'smi loke vede ca prathitaḥ puruṣottamaḥ
shlokas.interpretation: This verse establishes Krishna's supreme position in the cosmic hierarchy. He transcends both the perishable material world (kshara) and the imperishable spiritual realm (akshara). By declaring Himself as Purushottama, the Supreme Person, Krishna asserts His position as the ultimate reality beyond both manifest and unmanifest existence. This verse is crucial in understanding the Vedantic concept of Brahman and its relationship with the personal aspect of the Divine.
shlokas.meaning: Because I am transcendental to the perishable beings and also superior to the imperishable, I am celebrated as the Supreme Person in the world and in the Vedas.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to seek the highest truth beyond material and even subtle spiritual realms. It teaches us to look beyond temporary pleasures and even spiritual achievements to connect with the Supreme Reality. In practical life, it inspires us to cultivate a broader perspective, to not be limited by worldly or even otherworldly concepts, and to strive for the ultimate realization of our relationship with the Divine. This understanding can help in decision-making, dealing with life's challenges, and finding true purpose and fulfillment beyond material success or spiritual accomplishments.

shlokas.name: Shloka 19
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
यो मामेवमसम्मूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम् |
स सर्वविद्भजति मां सर्वभावेन भारत ||
shlokas.transliteration: yo mām evam asammūḍho jānāti puruṣottamam | sa sarva-vid bhajati māṁ sarva-bhāvena bhārata ||
shlokas.interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of recognizing Krishna as the Supreme Person. It suggests that those who understand Krishna's true nature, without delusion, possess complete knowledge. Such individuals worship Krishna with their entire being, indicating a state of complete surrender and devotion. The verse implies that true wisdom lies in recognizing the divine nature of Krishna and aligning oneself fully with this understanding.
shlokas.meaning: One who knows Me as the Supreme Person without doubt worships Me with his entire being. O Bharata, such a person is the knower of everything and engages in My devotional service with all his heart.
shlokas.life_application: This verse can be applied in life by encouraging individuals to seek deeper understanding and knowledge in their spiritual pursuits. It teaches the importance of unwavering faith and complete dedication in one's chosen path or beliefs. In practical terms, it can inspire people to approach their work, relationships, or personal growth with full commitment and without doubt, leading to more fulfilling and purposeful lives. It also emphasizes the value of recognizing and respecting higher principles or ideals in guiding one's actions and decisions.

shlokas.name: Shloka 20
shlokas.sanskrit_text:
इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयानघ |
एतद्बुद्ध्वा बुद्धिमान्स्यात्कृतकृत्यश्च भारत ||
shlokas.transliteration: iti guhyatamaṁ śāstram idam uktaṁ mayānagha etad buddhvā buddhimān syāt kṛtakṛtyaś ca bhārata
shlokas.interpretation: This verse concludes the fifteenth chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, emphasizing the supreme importance of the knowledge imparted. Lord Krishna states that this teaching is the most confidential part of the Vedic scriptures. By understanding and assimilating this knowledge, one becomes truly wise and fulfilled. The verse underscores the transformative power of spiritual wisdom and its ability to bring about a state of complete satisfaction and accomplishment in life.
shlokas.meaning: Thus, O sinless one, I have explained to you this most confidential knowledge. One who understands this will become wise, and his efforts in this world will be fulfilled, O Bharata.
shlokas.life_application: This verse encourages individuals to seek and apply spiritual knowledge in their lives. It suggests that true wisdom and fulfillment come from understanding one's spiritual nature and relationship with the Divine. In practical terms, this can be applied by dedicating time to study and reflect on spiritual teachings, practicing meditation or contemplation, and aligning one's actions with higher principles. By doing so, one can find greater purpose, contentment, and a sense of accomplishment in life, regardless of external circumstances.
